('94', 0, 1, 2, 44) 1. A LETTER
('94', 0, 2, 3, 56) DEVIPUR , February 17, 1947 My reply to your previous letter was still pending when I got this second one from you.
('94', 0, 2, 4, 172) But there was nothing in your first letter that needed immediate reply.
('94', 0, 2, 5, 244) At present there is great strain on me, both physical and mental.
('94', 0, 2, 6, 310) My work here instead of getting easier is becoming more difficult each day, as oppsition is increasing.
('94', 0, 2, 7, 414) All the same, my faith and courage are steadily growing.
('94', 0, 2, 8, 471) After all, I am here to do or die, am I not?
('94', 0, 2, 9, 516) There is no middle course here.
('94', 0, 2, 10, 548) 1 It is not certain when the third stage of my tour will begin.
('94', 0, 2, 11, 612) I have to reach Haimchar on the 24th.
('94', 0, 2, 12, 650) 2 The further programme will depend on how exhausted I feel.
('94', 0, 2, 13, 711) I shall be satisfied if God sustains me through the programme even up to the 24th.
('94', 0, 2, 14, 794) [From Gujarati]
('94', 0, 3, 15, 810) Eklo Jane Re, p.
('94', 0, 4, 16, 827) 2. ADVICE TO A CONGRESS WORKER 3
('94', 0, 5, 17, 860) DEVIPUR , February 17, 1947 Did you realize that by indulging in this vain display you would acerbate communal passions?
('94', 0, 5, 18, 981) This display means nothing to me.
('94', 0, 6, 19, 1015) but it will leave a legacy of ill will behind which will continue to poison the communal relations in this village for a long time to come.
('94', 0, 6, 20, 1155) You are a Congressman.
('94', 0, 6, 21, 1178) Did not it occur to you, knowing my strong views on khadi, that ribbons and buntings made of mill cloth would only hurt me?
('94', 0, 6, 22, 1302) I wouldn’t have felt so hurt if, instead of floral decorations, you had presented me with garlands of yarn.
('94', 0, 6, 23, 1410) They are decorative, and
('94', 0, 7, 24, 1435) 1 Omissions as in the source 2 Ibid 3 A grand reception had been arranged for Gandhiji at Devipur.
('94', 0, 7, 25, 1534) The village had been decorated with flags, buntings, streamers and garlands of yarn.
('94', 0, 7, 26, 1619) It jarred on Gandhiji.
('94', 0, 7, 27, 1642) As soon as his weekly silence was over, he sent for the principal worker.
('94', 0, 7, 28, 1716) 4 Omission as in the source
('94', 1, 0, 1, 1744) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('94', 1, 1, 2, 1784) afterwards can be used for making cloth also.
('94', 1, 1, 3, 1830) So nothing is wasted.
('94', 1, 1, 4, 1852) It seems there is a lot of money in this village.
('94', 1, 1, 5, 1902) Otherwise you would never have thought of making such costly ephemeral garlands in these hard times.
('94', 1, 1, 6, 2003) You are mistaken if you have done this to express your love for me.
('94', 1, 1, 7, 2071) That does not show your love at all.
('94', 1, 1, 8, 2108) It is enough if, out of love for me, you do as I say.
('94', 1, 1, 9, 2162) I just cannot imagine how after this terrible massacre of your own people you could ever think of spending anything over these flowers.
('94', 1, 2, 10, 2298) The day’s experience has set me thinking furiously.
('94', 1, 2, 11, 2350) Would my colleagues, too, if they ever became Ministers, betray the same weakness for garlands and the like?
('94', 1, 2, 12, 2459) I claim no extraordinary virtue for my workers.
('94', 1, 2, 13, 2507) But this much I do expect of them that even as Ministers they would never forget the ideals that the Congress has professed and fought for all these years.
('94', 1, 2, 14, 2663) What I have seen today, however, makes me wonder whether I am not living in a fool’s paradise.
('94', 1, 2, 15, 2758) It seems that God has woken me up with a rude shock to enable me to see where I stand.
('94', 1, 3, 16, 2845) Mahatma Gandhi—The Last Phase, Vol. I, Book II, p.

('94', 1, 4, 18, 2922) 3. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 2
('94', 1, 5, 19, 2952) DEVIPUR , February 17, 1947
('94', 1, 6, 20, 2980) Gandhiji drew attention to two things that had been brought to his notice.
('94', 1, 6, 21, 3055) The first was that a complaint, in sending which he was unfortunately an instrument, had been found on enquiry by the officers to be without foundation.
('94', 1, 6, 22, 3208) The articles which were reported to have been looted were mostly found in the very place from where they were said to have been looted.
('94', 1, 6, 23, 3344) This was a serious matter.
('94', 1, 6, 24, 3371) It was the second case that had come under his notice.
('94', 1, 6, 25, 3426) Yesterday some Muslim friends had come to him and admitted that the Muslims had undoubtedly gone mad in October last but though they had not been so bad as the Hindus had been in Bihar, the Hindus were making up for it by putting the Muslims to inconvenience by lodging false complaints against some of them.
('94', 1, 6, 26, 3735) They said that false complaints were far larger in number than true ones.
('94', 1, 6, 27, 3809) That was not the way to bring the two together.
('94', 1, 6, 28, 3857) He said that all those who lodged false complaints should be prosecuted and severely punished on conviction.
('94', 1, 6, 29, 3966) If he was the Superintendent of Police or a Minister, he would certainly institute proceedings and
('94', 1, 7, 30, 4065) 1 This paragraph is translated from Eklo Jane Re.
('94', 1, 7, 31, 4115) 2 Extracted from “Gandhiji’s Walking Tour Diary”
('94', 2, 0, 1, 4164) VOL. 94: 17 FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947 3
('94', 2, 1, 2, 4208) bring the perjurers to justice.
('94', 2, 1, 3, 4240) As for himself, as a citizen desirous of serving his country he would only be able to do something if the names and addresses of perjured complainants were given to him.
('94', 2, 1, 4, 4410) So far he had received no such names.
('94', 2, 1, 5, 4448) The only case that was sent to him could not be supported when the complainant was requested to support his complaint.
('94', 2, 1, 6, 4567) Generally he would say that the Hindus who lodged false complaints injured themselves, their co religionists and the whole country.
('94', 2, 2, 7, 4699) The other thing he wished to draw attention to was a letter he had received from a responsible person who was doing the work of bringing about peace between the two, that a Hindu lad was molested by some Muslims and that the latter had threatened the Hindus that they were to expect more drastic measures than last October’s after he had left Noakhali or, which was the same thing, after his death.
('94', 2, 2, 8, 5098) He would like to think that this statement was untrue, but he feared it was not.
('94', 2, 2, 9, 5179) But he did hope that the poison was restricted to a few illmannered persons.
('94', 2, 2, 10, 5256) Whether, however, it was restricted to a few or whether it was a widespread trait, he ventured to think it was wholly against Islam.
('94', 2, 2, 11, 5389) This he said with apologies to Fazlul Huq but no less firmly on that account.
('94', 2, 2, 12, 5467) It would be an evil day for Islam or for any religion when it was impatient of outside criticism.
('94', 2, 2, 13, 5565) He did not believe himself to be an outsider.
('94', 2, 2, 14, 5611) He respected Islam as he respected every other religion as his own and therefore he claimed to be a sympathetic and friendly critic.
('94', 2, 2, 15, 5744) It was up to every good Muslim to take up a firm and unequivocal stand against what he believed to be vicious propaganda.
('94', 2, 3, 16, 5866) Harijan, 16 3 1947
('94', 2, 4, 17, 5885) 4. A NOTE 1
('94', 2, 5, 18, 5897) ALUNIA , February 18, 1947 I was very much upset today.
('94', 2, 5, 19, 5953) Such is my nonattachment.
('94', 2, 5, 20, 5979) I felt disgusted with myself.
('94', 2, 5, 21, 6009) I even wonder whether I am really going to pass the test of my ahimsa.
('94', 2, 5, 22, 6080) It is God’s infinite kindness that He bears with me and sustains me.
('94', 2, 5, 23, 6149) Be vigilant.
('94', 2, 6, 24, 6162) BAPU [From Gujarati]
('94', 2, 7, 25, 6183) Eklo Jane Re, p.

('94', 3, 2, 3, 6346) NOAKHALI, February 18, 1947 When all parties become displeased with one it is generally a sure sign of one’s having done one’s duty.
('94', 3, 2, 4, 6479) May it be so with you.

('94', 3, 4, 6, 6545) 6. LETTER TO HARI SINGH GOUR
('94', 3, 5, 7, 6574) KAZIRKHIL, RAMGANJ P.S., NOAKHALI DISTT., February 18, 1947
('94', 3, 6, 8, 6634) DEAR SIR HARI SINGH GOUR, I have yours of the 5th February delivered to me only today.
('94', 3, 6, 9, 6721) Please do not ask me to make any public statement.
('94', 3, 6, 10, 6772) With the support of so many distinguished men whom you mention you should find no difficulty.
('94', 3, 6, 11, 6866) My own way of thinking always tells me that everything which has intrinsic merit succeeds sooner than later because it is like a straight line which is the shortest distance between any two points.
('94', 3, 6, 12, 7064) If you have the League support your project will have plain sailing.
('94', 3, 6, 13, 7133) But I see that you had not even an acknowledgement from Quaid e Azam Jinnah at the time you wrote to me.
('94', 3, 6, 14, 7238) I hope you will secure his approval.
('94', 3, 7, 15, 7275) Your sincerly,
('94', 3, 8, 16, 7290) From a copy: Pyarelal Papers.
('94', 3, 8, 17, 7320) Nehru Memorial Museum and Library.
('94', 3, 8, 18, 7355) Courtesy: Beladevi Nayyar and Dr. Sushila Nayyar

('94', 3, 9, 20, 7553) Some Calcutta Muslims told me that the Chief Minister got annoyed with me because I did not take action to prevent police and military zulum (oppression) upon the Muslims.
('94', 3, 9, 21, 7725) Another source informs .
('94', 3, 9, 22, 7750) that my differences .
('94', 3, 9, 23, 7772) with some British officers were the real cause.

('94', 3, 9, 25, 7833) gave different statements to different parties .
('94', 3, 9, 26, 7882) I do not bother .
('94', 3, 9, 27, 7900) as long as I am sure that my conscience is quite clear.”

('94', 4, 1, 2, 8001) 7. LETTER TO RUKMINI DEVI ARUNDALE 1
('94', 4, 2, 3, 8038) KAZIRKHIL, RAMGANJ P.S., NOAKHALI DISTT., February 18, 1947 I have yours of the 6th instant delivered to me today.
('94', 4, 2, 4, 8153) Much as I should like to have you here you can have no idea of the trouble you have to undergo in coming here unless you travel by air transport.
('94', 4, 2, 5, 8299) Even so I am in a part of the country where there are no motor roads worth the name.
('94', 4, 2, 6, 8384) I am at a far distance from the nearest aerodrome which is in Comilla.
('94', 4, 2, 7, 8455) I am in no mood to shoulder any burden whilst I am carrying the one in Noakhali.
('94', 4, 2, 8, 8536) I am in full agreement with you that the worthy project that Dr. Arundale initiated has to be carried to fruition and that most of all by you.
('94', 4, 2, 9, 8679) Of course I love to see you, veena in hand, leading the people into the way of truth and peace.
('94', 4, 3, 10, 8775) SHRIMATI RUKMINI DEVI PRESIDENT KALAKSHETRA ADYAR MADRAS
('94', 4, 4, 11, 8832) From a copy: Pyarelal Papers.
('94', 4, 4, 12, 8862) Nehru Memorial Museum and Library.
('94', 4, 4, 13, 8897) Courtesy: Beladevi Nayyar and Dr. Sushila Nayyar
('94', 4, 5, 14, 8946) 8. LETTER TO MANILAL B. DESAI
('94', 4, 6, 15, 8976) February 18, 1947
('94', 4, 7, 16, 8994) MANILAL,
('94', 4, 8, 17, 9003) Your letter of November 14, 1946 reached me only three or four days ago.
('94', 4, 8, 18, 9076) Such is the confusion here.
('94', 4, 8, 19, 9104) You have, of course relieved me of my worries and so I feel completely at ease.
('94', 4, 8, 20, 9184) I think almost all the questions in your letter have been answered in my last letter to you.
('94', 4, 8, 21, 9277) Jehangirji and Dr. Dinshaw must be among the trustees, for they are completely loyal and were members
('94', 4, 9, 22, 9379) 1 Eminent dancer and wife of the English Theosophist George Sydney Arundale; founder of Kalakshetra, Madras
('94', 5, 0, 1, 9487) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('94', 5, 1, 2, 9527) of the original Trust.
('94', 5, 1, 3, 9550) It might be objected that they did not fully agree with my views.
('94', 5, 1, 4, 9616) But I think that cannot be helped.
('94', 5, 1, 5, 9651) I am sure they will not do or order anything there against my wishes.
('94', 5, 1, 6, 9721) The other trustees to be selected will be persons who will have to be there.
('94', 5, 1, 7, 9798) I approve of Gulbai's name.
('94', 5, 1, 8, 9826) About Maganbhai also I have written to you.
('94', 5, 1, 9, 9870) If you can be sure that the well can be sunk for anything up to four or five thousand rupees, the expense is worth incurring.
('94', 5, 1, 10, 9996) But let me know first if anybody is prepared to give such assurance.
('94', 5, 1, 11, 10065) I would approve of a partner cultivator, but not of loaning him money for buying bullocks and other requirements.
('94', 5, 1, 12, 10179) We are not property owners, but trustees.
('94', 5, 1, 13, 10221) A trustee can be appointed only for a specific purpose.
('94', 5, 1, 14, 10277) Our object is Nature Cure.
('94', 5, 1, 15, 10304) we cannot incur such expenditure in pursuit of that object.
('94', 5, 1, 16, 10364) We may do what is possible with our own labour.
('94', 5, 1, 17, 10412) In either case, however, we will need water.
('94', 5, 1, 18, 10457) If, therefore, you can obtain an assurance that the scheme will succeed, we will incur the expenditure.
('94', 5, 1, 19, 10561) About crops, we may grow only what we can with our own labour.
('94', 5, 1, 20, 10624) We can raise the vegetables and fruits we need.
('94', 5, 1, 21, 10672) We cannot grow foodgrains.
('94', 5, 1, 22, 10699) We do need milk, and therefore the provision of cows is essential.
('94', 5, 1, 23, 10766) We have got to incur the expense necessary for that purpose.
('94', 5, 1, 24, 10827) If and when a building is ready, we shall have to spend some money for buying mattresses, etc.
('94', 5, 1, 25, 10922) If Datar himself undertakes to look after the construction of the building, I shall take it that the problem has been solved.
('94', 5, 1, 26, 11048) There has, of course, been some misunderstanding in regard to the woman whom Appasaheb has sent, but if she is otherwise good and ready for hard work, we have no option but to overlook her not wearing khadi.
('94', 5, 1, 27, 11256) You may gradually persuade her to change over to khadi.
('94', 5, 1, 28, 11312) If you want, I am prepared to write to Appasaheb.
('94', 5, 1, 29, 11362) But think over the matter carefully and let me know.
('94', 5, 1, 30, 11415) I will wait till I hear from you.
('94', 5, 1, 31, 11449) I understand about Paramanand.
('94', 5, 1, 32, 11480) Parasuram has left me.
('94', 5, 1, 33, 11503) At present he is working for Harijan.
('94', 5, 1, 34, 11541) Sushila (Dr.) has gone to Sevagram to look into the affairs of the hospital there.
('94', 5, 1, 35, 11624) Sushila Pai, Amtussalaam, Abha, Kanu and Pyarelal have been working in different villages and I am camping at some distance from them.
('94', 5, 1, 36, 11759) Therefore, we are unable to meet one another often.
('94', 5, 1, 37, 11811) A map of my tour has been published in the newspapers there too.
('94', 5, 1, 38, 11876) I suppose you consult it from time to time.
('94', 5, 1, 39, 11920) Manu sleeps with me.
('94', 5, 1, 40, 11941) She is as a granddaughter to me, for her grandfather is the son of my father's elder brother.
('94', 5, 1, 41, 12035) She is, therefore, really a granddaughter to me.
('94', 6, 0, 1, 12084) VOL. 94: 17 FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947 7
('94', 6, 1, 2, 12128) She came to stay with me at Sevagram when she was just a little girl.

('94', 6, 1, 5, 12259) If you have any comments to make after reading that letter, you may write to me.

('94', 6, 4, 9, 12484) 9. LETTER TO BALKRISHNA BHAVE
('94', 6, 5, 10, 12514) February 18, 1947
('94', 6, 6, 11, 12532) BALKRISHNA,
('94', 6, 7, 12, 12544) Your letter of November 14, 1946, reached me only three days ago.
('94', 6, 7, 13, 12610) Such is the confusion in the postal arrangements here.
('94', 6, 7, 14, 12665) It is also true, of course that I am, from the point of view of postal communication, in a rather inaccessible place.
('94', 6, 7, 15, 12783) Your health seems to be sufficiently restored now.
('94', 6, 7, 16, 12834) Do you experience any difficulty in singing?
('94', 6, 7, 17, 12879) If you do not, you should freely use your gift for the service of the people.
('94', 6, 7, 18, 12957) But of course not at the cost of your health.
('94', 6, 7, 19, 13003) You will see the letter I have written to Manibhai.
('94', 6, 7, 20, 13055) The problems there are quite complicated and you will be able to play an important part in solving them.
('94', 6, 7, 21, 13160) Probably you do not know that Manubehn (Jaisukhlal's) sleeps with me.
('94', 6, 7, 22, 13230) This has pained Bhai Kishorelal, Narahari, Swami and others and they have, therefore, stopped their connection with Harijan.
('94', 6, 7, 23, 13355) Sardar also is very angry with me.
('94', 6, 7, 24, 13390) For me Manu's sleeping with me is a matter of dharma, and I am resolved to drive home the lesson that a person cannot give up what is a matter of dharma to him for the love of those who are dear to him or out of fear of anybody.
('94', 6, 7, 25, 13619) If in a situation like this I give up what I believe to be my dharma through false regard for friends or fear or love, my yajna would remain incomplete and bear no fruit.
('94', 6, 7, 26, 13790) This is my side of the case.
('94', 6, 7, 27, 13819) Kishorelal's side, as far as I can understand it, is the opposite.
('94', 6, 7, 28, 13886) He thinks that I have come to regard adharma as dharma and that, therefore, my practice dishonours my brahmacharya and sets a bad example to people.
('94', 6, 7, 29, 14035) The thought that a man like me should set a bad example is intolerable to

('94', 7, 0, 1, 14154) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('94', 7, 1, 2, 14194) them, and, therefore, these friends have started non co operation with me.
('94', 7, 1, 3, 14269) They are free to take whatever further step they choose.
('94', 7, 1, 4, 14326) I do not know what Vinoba thinks.
('94', 7, 1, 5, 14360) But the friends named above have corresponded with him and therefore I also have written to him and asked for his opinion.
('94', 7, 1, 6, 14483) 1 Either be guided by Vinoba's reply to my letter or think for yourself and write to me what you think.
('94', 7, 1, 7, 14587) I have discussed this matter in three of my speeches.
('94', 7, 1, 8, 14641) I send copies herewith.
('94', 7, 1, 9, 14665) You need not return them.
('94', 7, 1, 10, 14691) Show them to the friends there.

('94', 7, 4, 17, 15052) 10. LETTER TO SARLA
('94', 7, 5, 18, 15072) February 18, 1947
('94', 7, 7, 19, 15090) I got your letter.
('94', 7, 7, 20, 15109) The characters are well formed and the words well spaced out, and the handwriting, therefore, is pleasing to the eye.
('94', 7, 7, 21, 15227) However, your composite letters are not correct.
('94', 7, 7, 22, 15276) You have misspelt 'gram'.
('94', 7, 7, 23, 15302) I am glad you wish to come to me.
('94', 7, 7, 24, 15336) But there are bound to be all kinds of problems when I am daily on the move and moving from one village to another.
('94', 7, 7, 25, 15452) Touring through villages involves several inconveniences: insufficient accommodation, very bad water, and so on.
('94', 7, 7, 26, 15565) In such circumstances I simply don't have the courage to ask you to come.
('94', 7, 7, 27, 15639) I, therefore, advise you to have some patience.
('94', 7, 7, 28, 15687) God willing, the time will come when you will be able to stay with me.
('94', 7, 7, 29, 15758) I can see from the account given by you that you are doing excellent work.
('94', 7, 7, 30, 15833) Go on with it and continue your progress.
('94', 7, 7, 31, 15875) Master the art of weaving.
('94', 7, 7, 32, 15902) If in spinning also you acquire firstclass skill you can make yourself an indispensable worker, for your services will then be in demand everywhere.
('94', 7, 7, 33, 16051) I am sure you will have improved your Marathi.
('94', 7, 8, 34, 16098) 1 Vide “Letter to Vinoba Bhave”, 10 2 1947
('94', 8, 0, 1, 16141) VOL. 94: 17 FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947 9
('94', 8, 1, 2, 16185) Complete your study and learn everything about nature cure.
('94', 8, 1, 3, 16245) Acquire the highest proficiency in the Urdu script and language.
('94', 8, 1, 4, 16310) Learn Sanskrit.
('94', 8, 1, 5, 16326) And all this you should do as if you were merely amusing yourself.
('94', 8, 1, 6, 16393) If you do so, you will not even know how time passes.
('94', 8, 1, 7, 16447) Keep up contact with me through letters.
('94', 8, 1, 8, 16488) I am not happy that Shashi's 1 fever has still not left him.
('94', 8, 1, 9, 16549) If you study nature cure all over again—and it is easy to study it—you yourself will be able to cure it.
('94', 8, 1, 10, 16654) All that is necessary is to be careful about his diet and give him hipbath and frictionbath and treat him with mud packs.
('94', 8, 1, 11, 16776) If this is done, he will soon get well.
('94', 8, 1, 12, 16816) He should of course remain calm.

('94', 8, 7, 18, 17073) League Government or the majority community agrees to give us due compensation?
('94', 8, 8, 19, 17153) A. He had supported the proposition from the non violent standpoint.

('94', 8, 10, 22, 17303) the Government do if the majority had become so hostile that they would not tolerate
('94', 8, 11, 23, 17388) the presence of the minority community?
('94', 8, 11, 24, 17428) In his opinion it would be improper for
('94', 8, 12, 25, 17468) them to force the majority into submission, nor could they undertake to protect the
('94', 8, 13, 26, 17552) minority at the point of the bayonet.
('94', 8, 13, 27, 17590) Suppose for instance that the majority would
('94', 8, 14, 28, 17635) not tolerate Ram

('94', 9, 9, 11, 18038) 13. LETTER TO MRIDULA SARABHAI
('94', 9, 10, 12, 18069) ALUNIA , February 19, 1947
('94', 9, 11, 13, 18096) MRIDU, I got your two telegrams, and that was yesterday.
('94', 9, 11, 14, 18153) I am today sending you a telegram in reply.
('94', 9, 11, 15, 18197) You are worried but there is no cause at all for worry.
('94', 9, 11, 16, 18253) So far my life has been running its course smoothly.
('94', 9, 11, 17, 18306) More and more each day I see that it is all to the good.
('94', 9, 11, 18, 18363) What I did at Sevagram was by way of an experiment.
('94', 9, 11, 19, 18415) An experiment may be stopped any time.
('94', 9, 11, 20, 18454) So for the sake of the colleagues, I had postponed it.
('94', 9, 11, 21, 18509) I did not publish the statement for your sake or Bapa’s sake.
('94', 9, 11, 22, 18571) Here the situation is totally different.
('94', 9, 11, 23, 18612) Sleeping with Manu is for me aninseparable part of the yajna.
('94', 9, 11, 24, 18674) Why it is so need not be explained here.
('94', 9, 11, 25, 18715) I shall explain when you come.
('94', 9, 11, 26, 18746) Since this act of mine has caused an uproar, a great deal of my time is taken up with arguing with colleagues and pacifying them.
('94', 9, 11, 27, 18876) But inasmuch as I consider this act part of the yajna, sparing that much time does not irk me.
('94', 9, 11, 28, 18971) So you should carry on your work without getting upset.
('94', 9, 11, 29, 19027) If you want to come only for this thing, I would urge you not to come.
('94', 9, 11, 30, 19098) Kishorelalbhai by himself should be sufficient to persuade me to desist.
('94', 9, 11, 31, 19171) But you wanted to come even otherwise, so I shall not stop you.
('94', 9, 11, 32, 19235) Whatever it is, write to me freely.
('94', 9, 11, 33, 19271) Ask me anything you want.

('94', 10, 12, 17, 20128) 15. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 2
('94', 10, 13, 18, 20159) CHARDUKHIA, February 19, 1947
('94', 10, 14, 19, 20189) Q. What should a Hindu worker do when he is being deliberately misrepresented by interested parties in Noakhali?
('94', 10, 15, 20, 20302) A. The answer in terms of ahimsa, generally, would be that acts should be allowed to speak for themselves.
('94', 10, 15, 21, 20409) Whilst this was good as a general proposition there were occasions when to speak and explain was a duty and not to speak would amount to falsehood.
('94', 10, 15, 22, 20557) Therefore wisdom dictated that on occasions speech must accompany action.
('94', 10, 15, 23, 20631) Of course, one could conceive the possibility of mere thought taking the place of speech and action.
('94', 10, 15, 24, 20732) Such was the attribute of the Almighty and might be almost possible for one in a billion, but he knew no such instance.
('94', 10, 16, 25, 20852) Q. You have advised 3 evacuation if the majority become irrevocably hostile.
('94', 10, 16, 26, 20929) But you have also maintained that a truly nonviolent man should never give up hope of converting his opponent by love.
('94', 10, 16, 27, 21048) Under these circumstances, how can a nonviolent man accept defeat and evacuate?
('94', 10, 17, 28, 21128) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('94', 10, 17, 29, 21155) 2 Extracted from “Gandhiji’s Walking Tour Diary” 3 Vide the preceding page.
('94', 11, 0, 1, 21231) 12 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('94', 11, 1, 2, 21272) A. As to this question, it was perfectly correct that a non violent man would not move out of his place.
('94', 11, 1, 3, 21377) For such a one there would be no question of compensation.
('94', 11, 1, 4, 21436) He would simply die at his post and prove that his presence was not a danger to the State or the community.
('94', 11, 1, 5, 21544) He knew that the Hindus of Noakhali made no such pretension.
('94', 11, 1, 6, 21605) They were simple folk who loved the world and wanted to live in the world in peace and safety.
('94', 11, 1, 7, 21700) Such persons would consult their honour if the Government honourably offered them compensation in order to see the majority living in peace.
('94', 11, 1, 8, 21841) If the mere presence of the Hindus irritated the Muslims who were in the majority, he would consider it to be the duty of the Government to offer compensation as it would be of the Government in a Hindu majority province to offer compensation to the Muslims if their presence irritated the majority community.
('94', 11, 2, 9, 22151) Q. In case of evacuation, under advice from the Government, should the evacuees ask for compensation for (a) all their movable and immovable property, (b) loss of business?
('94', 11, 2, 10, 22324) In other words, what would you consider to be adequate compensation?
('94', 11, 3, 11, 22393) A. Gandhiji said that the Government would be obliged to compensate for both immovable and movable property when the latter could not be or were not carried away with him by the evacuee.
('94', 11, 3, 12, 22580) Loss of business was a ticklish question.
('94', 11, 3, 13, 22622) He could not conceive the possibility of any Government shouldering the burden of such compensation.
('94', 11, 3, 14, 22723) He would understand the proposition that asked for a reasonable sum for enabling the person concerned to start business in a new place.
('94', 11, 4, 15, 22859) Whilst he examined and admitted the possibility of evacuation, his experience of all India told him that the Hindus and the Muslims knew how to live at peace among themselves.
('94', 11, 4, 16, 23035) He declined to believe that people had said goodbye to their senses so as to make it impossible to live at peace with each other as they had done for generations.
('94', 11, 4, 17, 23198) For he believed with the late poet Iqbal that the Hindus and the Muslims who had lived together long under the shadow of the mighty Himalayas and had drunk the waters of the Ganges and the Jamuna had a unique message for the world.
('94', 11, 5, 18, 23430) Harijan, 16 3 1947
('94', 12, 0, 1, 23449) VOL. 94: 17 FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947 13

('94', 13, 1, 2, 25154) 19. LETTER TO E. STANLEY JONES
('94', 13, 2, 3, 25185) KAZIRKHIL, RAMGANJ P.S., NOAKHALI DISTT., February 20, 1947
('94', 13, 3, 4, 25245) DEAR DR.
('94', 13, 3, 5, 25254) STANLEY JONES 1, It almost appears as if you had never gone to America.
('94', 13, 3, 6, 25326) Trains and steamers have very effectively reduced distances.
('94', 13, 3, 7, 25387) Air transport marks a further stage in that reduction.
('94', 13, 3, 8, 25442) Nevertheless, I am not satisfied that it has increased the real happiness of mankind.
('94', 13, 3, 9, 25528) You have kindly referred to my tour in Noakhali.
('94', 13, 3, 10, 25577) The result is in God’s hands.
('94', 13, 3, 11, 25607) You have mentioned Bihar in the same breath.
('94', 13, 3, 12, 25652) I do think that the Bihar crime was much greater than that of Noakhali in magnitude.
('94', 13, 3, 13, 25737) Man became brute, I hope temporarily only in both the places.
('94', 13, 3, 14, 25799) But I haven’t yet seen the light leading me to Bihar.
('94', 13, 3, 15, 25853) If I can see that, I should have no hesitation in going there.
('94', 13, 3, 16, 25916) I am in constant touch with the ministers and the people of Bihar.
('94', 13, 3, 17, 25983) So far as I can see there is real repentance.
('94', 13, 3, 18, 26029) But I cannot positively swear that I am not being misled.
('94', 13, 3, 19, 26087) Immediately I feel the call I should interrupt my work in Noakhali and hasten to Bihar.
('94', 13, 3, 20, 26175) All I can say today is that I am on the watch.
('94', 13, 3, 21, 26222) One thing I would add.
('94', 13, 3, 22, 26245) I have come here to put my Ahimsa to test.
('94', 13, 3, 23, 26288) I have no misgiving as to the effect of Ahimsa.
('94', 13, 3, 24, 26336) But I am fully conscious that I may not know the whole technique and may not even be living up to what I do know.
('94', 13, 3, 25, 26450) Therefore, I have submitted myself for examination here.
('94', 13, 3, 26, 26507) Hence, if that examination demands my presence in Bihar I shall go.
('94', 13, 3, 27, 26575) I am glad you are organizing vigils of prayer.
('94', 13, 3, 28, 26622) As to the letter you have enclosed 2 I do not know that I can render any service in the shape of sending a contribution.
('94', 13, 3, 29, 26743) I do not think that I can send anything effective.

('94', 16, 4, 10, 30533) 24. DISCUSSION WITH AMIYA CHAKRAVARTY 1
('94', 16, 5, 11, 30573) February 20, 1947 Even if I fail, truth will not have failed.
('94', 16, 5, 12, 30635) I must strive and carry this issue towards light.
('94', 16, 5, 13, 30685) I live or perish in the attempt.
('94', 16, 5, 14, 30718) Noakhali and Tipperah are not an isolated problem but it is a problem which India must solve for herself and for humanity.
('94', 16, 5, 15, 30841) Fortunately or unfortunately I have had success in the most difficult ventures of my life.
('94', 16, 5, 16, 30932) But I do not know what will happen this time.
('94', 16, 5, 17, 30978) The greatest trial is given to us but it is never beyond our power to overcome it.
('94', 16, 5, 18, 31061) Truth is God.
('94', 16, 5, 19, 31075) And He is discoverable only to non violence and all it means.
('94', 16, 5, 20, 31137) Here will be decided the clear issue.
('94', 16, 5, 21, 31175) Those who think of separation must know where we stand.
('94', 16, 5, 22, 31231) Let the facts be faced.
('94', 16, 5, 23, 31255) If people will not tolerate differences in religion, usage, food, dress or individuality and will insist on boycott, then they cannot do so without the help of the Government which represents the people.
('94', 16, 5, 24, 31459) If boycott is the policy of the Government, we must know about it.
('94', 16, 5, 25, 31526) A community cannot take action by itself.
('94', 16, 5, 26, 31568) Bengal as well as other provinces must understand this.
('94', 16, 6, 27, 31624) As to changeability of human nature to normality, if opportunity was given, Mahatma Gandhi said: If I did not believe so, I would not be here.
('94', 16, 7, 28, 31767) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 24 2 1968
('94', 16, 8, 29, 31799) 1 Professor at Calcutta University; at one time served as secretary to Rabindranath Tagore
('94', 17, 0, 1, 31890) 18 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('94', 17, 1, 2, 31931) 25. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('94', 17, 2, 3, 31962) CHAR LARUA, February 20, 1947
('94', 17, 3, 4, 31992) Q. If you think the Government may boycott, i.
('94', 17, 3, 5, 32039) e., remove the minority community after giving adequate compensation, may not people take time by the forelock and go?
('94', 17, 4, 6, 32158) A. As to this he said that those who felt that they would take time by the forelock and form a Hindu corporation to take the Hindus away, he had nothing in common with them.
('94', 17, 4, 7, 32332) He could not be party to any such scheme.
('94', 17, 4, 8, 32374) The burden lay entirely on the majority community and the Government.
('94', 17, 4, 9, 32444) He merely meant that when they declared bankruptcy of wisdom, the minority should go if they were adequately compensated.
('94', 17, 4, 10, 32566) The other way was the way of violence, i.
('94', 17, 4, 11, 32608) e., civil war, not of non violence.
('94', 17, 5, 12, 32644) Q. You have said castes should go.
('94', 17, 5, 13, 32679) But then will Hinduism survive?
('94', 17, 5, 14, 32711) Why do you thus mix up Hinduism with the progressive religions like Christianity or Islam?
('94', 17, 6, 15, 32802) A. He maintained that caste as it was understood must go if Hinduism was to survive.
('94', 17, 6, 16, 32887) He did not believe that Christianity and Islam were progressive and Hinduism static, i.
('94', 17, 6, 17, 32975) e., retrogressive.
('94', 17, 6, 18, 32994) As a matter of fact he noticed no definite progress in any religion.
('94', 17, 6, 19, 33063) The world would not be the shambles it had become if the religions of the world were progressive.
('94', 17, 6, 20, 33161) There was room for varna, as a duty.
('94', 17, 6, 21, 33198) This was true of all religions whether the name used was other than varna.
('94', 17, 6, 22, 33273) What was a Muslim Maulvi or a Christian priest but a Brahmin if he taught his flock its true duty not for money but because he possessed the gift of interpretation?
('94', 17, 6, 23, 33438) And this was true of the other divisions.
('94', 17, 7, 24, 33480) Q. As you are an advocate of the abolition of caste, are we to take it that you favour intercaste marriages?
('94', 17, 7, 25, 33589) Many occupations are now the monopoly of specific castes.
('94', 17, 7, 26, 33647) Should not this be abolished?
('94', 17, 8, 27, 33677) A. He was certainly in favour of intercaste marriage.
('94', 17, 8, 28, 33731) The question did not arise when all became casteless.
('94', 17, 8, 29, 33785) When this happy event took place, monopoly of occupations would go.
('94', 17, 9, 30, 33853) Q. If there is only one God, should there not be only one religion?
('94', 17, 10, 31, 33921) A. This was a strange question.
('94', 17, 10, 32, 33953) Just as a tree had a million leaves similarly though God was one, there were as many religions as there were men and women though they were rooted in one God.
('94', 17, 10, 33, 34112) They did not see this plain truth because they were followers of different prophets and claimed as many religons as there were prophets.
('94', 17, 10, 34, 34249) As a matter of fact whilst he believed himself to be a Hindu, he knew that he did not worship God in the same manner as one or all of them.
('94', 17, 10, 35, 34389) Harijan, 16 3 1947
('94', 17, 11, 36, 34408) 1 Extracted from “Gandhiji’s Walking Tour Diary”
('94', 18, 0, 1, 34457) VOL. 94 : 17, FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947 19
('94', 18, 1, 2, 34504) 26. LETTER TO E. W. ARYANAYAKUM 1
('94', 18, 2, 3, 34538) February 21, 1947 You have given me a cutting from the Hindustan Standard purporting to report the views of Maulana Abul Kalam Azad 2 on education.
('94', 18, 2, 4, 34686) Assuming the correctness of the report I say categorically that it is inconsistent with the line followed by the Hindustani Talimi Sangh.
('94', 18, 2, 5, 34824) It is in the villages of India where India lives, not in the few Westernized cities which are the citadels of a foreign power.
('94', 18, 2, 6, 34951) I do not believe that the State can concern itself or cope with religious education.
('94', 18, 2, 7, 35036) I believe that religious education must be the sole concern of religious associations.
('94', 18, 2, 8, 35123) Do not mix up religion and ethics.
('94', 18, 2, 9, 35158) I believe that fundamental ethics is common to all religions.
('94', 18, 2, 10, 35220) Teaching of fundamental ethics is undoubtedly a function of the State.
('94', 18, 2, 11, 35291) By religion I have not in mind fundamental ethics but what goes by the name of denominationalism.
('94', 18, 2, 12, 35389) We have suffered enough from State aided religion and State Church.
('94', 18, 2, 13, 35457) A society or a group, which depends partly or wholly on State aid for the existence of its religion, does not deserve or, better still, does not have any religion worth the name.
('94', 18, 2, 14, 35636) I do not need to give any illustrations in support of this obvious truth as it is to me.
('94', 18, 2, 15, 35725) The second point deserving attention in the report in question is regarding the replacing of the Urdu and Nagari scripts by the Roman script.
('94', 18, 2, 16, 35867) However attractive the proposition may appear to be and whatever is true of the Indian soldiers, in my opinion the replacing would be a fatal blunder and we would find ourselves in the fire out of the frying pan.

('94', 21, 4, 7, 41715) 29. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 3
('94', 21, 5, 8, 41746) KAMALAPUR, February 21, 1947
('94', 21, 6, 9, 41775) Gandhiji congratulated the audience on having come from the surrounding villages.
('94', 21, 6, 10, 41857) He however sympathized with them for being exposed to the sun.
('94', 21, 6, 11, 41920) He also hoped that they were not afraid of the Indian sun, perhaps the greatest gift from God.
('94', 21, 6, 12, 42015) Happy was India which had clear blue sky for the larger part of the year.
('94', 21, 7, 13, 42089) He then referred to the fact that he had gone to Chandpur more than once whilst India’s grand old son Shri Haradayal Nag 4 was alive.
('94', 21, 7, 14, 42223) He was then his guest.
('94', 21, 7, 15, 42246) He knew, therefore, what importance Chandpur had.
('94', 21, 7, 16, 42296) He was glad that Chandpur had played its part in looking after the refugees.
('94', 21, 7, 17, 42373) But he deplored the disregard of the laws of sanitation and cleanliness.
('94', 21, 7, 18, 42446) If they rigidly carried out these rules they would not have to live in constant dread of the plague and other diseases which were the brood of insanitation.
('94', 21, 8, 19, 42603) He then told them that they must not harbour ill will against their Muslim neighbours.
('94', 21, 8, 20, 42690) He appealed to both the parties to live at peace with each other.
('94', 21, 8, 21, 42756) But he held that even if the Hindus alone harboured no ill will against the Muslims, or vice versa, strife would abate.
('94', 21, 8, 22, 42876) If however both harboured ill will, one against the other, strifes were bound to be the result.
('94', 21, 8, 23, 42972) There was a mantra in the Upanishads [which says] that man became what he thought.
('94', 21, 8, 24, 43055) 5 How true it was found in every walk of life!
('94', 21, 8, 25, 43102) Let them beware of harbouring an evil thought.
('94', 21, 9, 26, 43149) 1 Devprakash Nayyar 2 Nirmal Kumar Bose, a professor of Calcutta University, was touring with Gandhiji as his “companion and interpreter”.
('94', 21, 9, 27, 43288) Vide “Silence Day Note to N. K. Bose”, 18 11 1946 and “Statement to the Press”, 20 11 1946 3 Extracted from “Gandhiji’s Walking Tour Diary” 4 (1853 1942); participated in the non co operation movement and Salt Satyagraha; devoted his life to constructive work 5 “According as one acts, according as one behaves, so does he become.
('94', 21, 9, 28, 43619) The doer of good becomes good, the doer of evil becomes evil.
('94', 21, 9, 29, 43681) One becomes virtuous by virtuous action.
('94', 21, 9, 30, 43722) Others, however, say that a person consists of desires.
('94', 21, 9, 31, 43778) As is his desire, so is his will; as is his will, so is the deed he does, whatever deed he does, that he attains.” Brihadanranyakopanishad, IV.
('94', 22, 0, 1, 43922) VOL. 94 : 17, FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947 23
('94', 22, 1, 2, 43969) He then came to the two questions before him.
('94', 22, 1, 3, 44015) The first was:
('94', 22, 2, 4, 44030) You advocate inter caste marriages.
('94', 22, 2, 5, 44066) Do you also favour marriages between Indians professing different religions?
('94', 22, 2, 6, 44143) Should they declare themselves as belonging to no denomination, or can they continue their old religious practices and yet inter marry?
('94', 22, 2, 7, 44279) If so, what form should the marriage ceremony take?
('94', 22, 2, 8, 44331) Is it to be a purely civil function or a religious function?
('94', 22, 2, 9, 44392) Do you consider religion to be an exclusively personal matter?
('94', 22, 3, 10, 44455) Though he admitted that he had not always held the view, he had come to the conclusion long ago, that an inter religious marriage was a welcome event whenever it took place.
('94', 22, 3, 11, 44629) His stipulation was that such a connection was not to be a product of lust.
('94', 22, 3, 12, 44705) In his opinion [if it was a product of lust] 1 it was no marriage.
('94', 22, 3, 13, 44772) It was illicit intercourse.
('94', 22, 3, 14, 44800) Marriage in his estimation was a sacred institution.
('94', 22, 3, 15, 44853) Hence there must be mutual friendship, either party having equal respect for the religion of the other.
('94', 22, 3, 16, 44957) There was no question in this of conversion.
('94', 22, 3, 17, 45002) Hence the marriage ceremony would be performed by priests belonging to both faiths.
('94', 22, 3, 18, 45086) This happy event could take place when the communities shed mutual enmity and had regard for the religions of the world.
('94', 22, 4, 19, 45207) Should religious instruction form part of the school curriculum as approved by the State?
('94', 22, 4, 20, 45297) Do you favour separate schools for children belonging to different denominations for facility of religious instruction?
('94', 22, 4, 21, 45417) Or, should religious instruction be left in the hands of private bodies?
('94', 22, 4, 22, 45490) If so, do you think it is right for the State to subsidize such bodies?
('94', 22, 5, 23, 45562) As to this question he said that he did not believe in State religion even though the whole community had one religion.
('94', 22, 5, 24, 45682) State interference would probably always be unwelcome.
('94', 22, 5, 25, 45737) Religion was a purely personal matter.
('94', 22, 5, 26, 45776) There were in reality as many religions as minds.
('94', 22, 5, 27, 45826) Each mind had a different conception of God from the other.
('94', 22, 5, 28, 45886) He was also opposed to State aid, partly or wholly, to religious bodies.
('94', 22, 5, 29, 45959) For he knew that an institution or group, which did not manage to finance its own religious teaching, was a stranger to true religion.
('94', 22, 5, 30, 46094) This did not mean that the State schools would not give ethical teaching.
('94', 22, 5, 31, 46168) Fundamental ethics were common to all religions.
('94', 22, 6, 32, 46217) Harijan, 16 3 1947

('94', 23, 3, 20, 47629) But the outside din and noise have practically deadened it for the vast majority of people.
('94', 23, 3, 21, 47721) When that voice speaks I shall find myself in Bihar without any further prompting.

('94', 23, 3, 23, 47944) I continue with some caution to worry the officials immediately concerned.

('94', 27, 2, 6, 55007) 33. A LETTER
('94', 27, 3, 7, 55020) February 22, 1947 I say you cannot tread this path (the path of brahmacharya) if you fight shy of the thorns, stones and pitfalls in the way.
('94', 27, 3, 8, 55162) Maybe we shall stumble, our feet will bleed, we may even perish.
('94', 27, 3, 9, 55227) But we dare not turn back.
('94', 27, 3, 10, 55254) * * * If I am successful, the world will be enriched by my venture.
('94', 27, 3, 11, 55322) If on the other hand I am found to be a fraud or a misled fool, the world will reject me and I shall be debunked.
('94', 27, 3, 12, 55436) In either case the world will be the gainer.
('94', 27, 3, 13, 55481) This is as clear to me as two and two make four.
('94', 27, 4, 14, 55530) Mahatma Gandhi — The Last Phase, Vol. I, Bk.
('94', 27, 5, 15, 55575) 34. LETTER TO PYARELAL
('94', 27, 6, 16, 55598) February 22, 1947
('94', 27, 7, 17, 55616) PYARELAL, It is 6.15 now and I must stretch myself.
('94', 27, 7, 18, 55668) And if I feel sleepy, I must sleep.
('94', 27, 7, 19, 55704) That is why I am dictating this letter.
('94', 27, 7, 20, 55744) I read your lessons and I like them.
('94', 27, 7, 21, 55781) It would not do your spoiling your handwriting and then asking to be forgiven.

('94', 27, 7, 23, 55945) That would not be proper.

('94', 27, 7, 25, 56051) You may write less.
('94', 27, 7, 26, 56071) If you resolve that whatever you write will be in a beautiful handwriting, writing Manu’s lessons in a beautiful handwriting will not be burdensome to you.
('94', 27, 7, 27, 56227) Duty should never be a burden.
('94', 27, 7, 28, 56258) And it is one’s duty to make one’s handwriting beautiful like beads.
('94', 27, 7, 29, 56327) In spite of knowing this I myself do not follow this.

('94', 27, 7, 31, 56454) I have sampled your other roti too.

('94', 27, 7, 34, 56653) In other words you had started mixing in it lime or tamarind juice or tomato juice.
('94', 27, 7, 35, 56737) If you do that, the roti will be lighter and easily
('94', 28, 0, 1, 56789) VOL. 94 : 17, FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947 29

('94', 28, 1, 3, 56848) In case you do not do that, I have already suggested bhakhri.
('94', 28, 1, 4, 56910) It would turn out nice if you add sufficient oil in the dough.
('94', 28, 1, 5, 56973) Do not think that you have to send it to me.

('94', 29, 1, 2, 59083) 35. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('94', 29, 2, 3, 59114) CHAR KRISHNAPUR, February 22, 1947
('94', 29, 3, 4, 59149) At the outset Gandhiji said that he had received from a Muslim friend in Baluchistan a printed sheet containing what he thought were the sayings of the Prophet and the teachers.
('94', 29, 3, 5, 59327) The whole selection was good but he was attracted by the following from Prophet Mohamed’s sayings: When God made the earth it shook to and fro till He put mountains on it to keep it firm.
('94', 29, 3, 6, 59515) Then the Angels asked, O God, is there anything in Thy creation stronger than these mountains?
('94', 29, 3, 7, 59610) And God replied, iron is stronger than these mountains for it breaks them.
('94', 29, 3, 8, 59685) And is there anything in Thy creation stronger than iron?
('94', 29, 3, 9, 59743) Yes, fire is stronger than iron, for it melts it.
('94', 29, 3, 10, 59793) Is there anything stronger than fire?
('94', 29, 3, 11, 59831) Yes, water, for it quenches fire.
('94', 29, 3, 12, 59865) Is there anything stronger than water?
('94', 29, 3, 13, 59904) Yes, wind, for it puts water in motion.
('94', 29, 3, 14, 59944) O our Sustainer, is there anything stronger than wind?
('94', 29, 3, 15, 59999) Yes, a good man giving alms.
('94', 29, 3, 16, 60028) If he gives it with his right hand and conceals it from his left, he overcomes all things.
('94', 29, 3, 17, 60119) Every good act is charity.
('94', 29, 3, 18, 60146) Your smiling in your brother’s face, your putting a wanderer on the right road, your giving water to the thirsty, is charity.
('94', 29, 3, 19, 60272) A man’s true wealth hereafter is the good he has done to his fellowmen.
('94', 29, 3, 20, 60344) When he dies people will ask, what property he had left behind him?
('94', 29, 3, 21, 60412) But the Angels will ask, what good deeds has he sent before him?
('94', 29, 3, 22, 60477) Gandhiji then dealt with the following questions.
('94', 29, 3, 23, 60527) Q. Why should there be insistence on temple entry?
('94', 29, 3, 24, 60578) Of course, we understand that in case of objection, there is scope in it for satyagraha.
('94', 29, 3, 25, 60667) No caste dinners have a limited value; for those who join do not shed untoucha bility in their homes or during social ceremonies.
('94', 29, 3, 26, 60797) They look upon these dinners, organized by Congressmen or other progressives, as special occasions when caste rules are held in abeyance; something comparable to what one does when one goes to Jagannath Puri and partakes of cooked rice offered to Jagannath without reference to one’s caste.
('94', 29, 3, 27, 61088) Anti untouchability has not yet gone deep enough to affect the normal social life of individuals.
('94', 29, 3, 28, 61186) What can be done to break down barriers in private homes?
('94', 29, 3, 29, 61244) Even with regard to temple entry there is one question.
('94', 29, 3, 30, 61300) Do you think that priests in public service in free India will be drafted from among competent men and women without any reference to their former castes?
('94', 29, 4, 31, 61455) A. Gandhiji said that it was an apt question in this part of Bengal where there
('94', 29, 5, 32, 61535) 1 Extracted from “Gandhiji’s Walking Tour Diary”
('94', 30, 0, 1, 61584) VOL. 94 : 17, FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947 31
('94', 30, 1, 2, 61631) were the largest number of Namasudras.
('94', 30, 1, 3, 61670) He welcomed the question doubly because he had occupied the lowest rung of the Hindu ladder and because he did not believe in the ladder of castes.
('94', 30, 1, 4, 61818) He invited all to occupy that lowest rung.
('94', 30, 1, 5, 61861) Then there would be no occasions for such questions as were addressed to him.
('94', 30, 1, 6, 61939) Meanwhile, he was bound to deal with them.
('94', 30, 1, 7, 61982) He entirely endorsed the proposition that untouchability would be doomed and totally abolished when there was no prohibition applied against anyone by reason of his caste.
('94', 30, 1, 8, 62154) The only universal prohibition would be against insanitation, degradation, etc.
('94', 30, 1, 9, 62234) But he clung to the belief that temple entry took the first place in the programme of removal of untouchability and he made bold to say that social public dinners would precede as they were preceding the final conquest over the demon of untouchability.
('94', 30, 1, 10, 62487) He prophesied that Hinduism would be destroyed if untouchability was not destroyed, even as the British race would lose its name if British rule was not destroyed in toto, as it was certainly being dissolved before their very eyes.
('94', 30, 2, 11, 62719) Q. You wrote about economic equality in 1941. Do you hold that all persons who perform useful and necessary service in society, whether farmer or Bhangi, engineer or accountant, doctor or teacher, have a moral right only to equal wages with the rest?
('94', 30, 2, 12, 62970) Of course, it is understood, educational or other expenses shall be a charge of the State.
('94', 30, 2, 13, 63061) Our question is, should not all persons get the same wages for their personal needs?
('94', 30, 2, 14, 63146) Do you not think that if we work for this equality, it will cut sooner under the root of untouchability than any other process?
('94', 30, 3, 15, 63274) A. As to this Gandhiji had no doubt that if India was to live an exemplary life of independence which would be the envy of the world, all the Bhangis, doctors, lawyers, teachers, merchants and others would get the same wages for an honest day’s work.
('94', 30, 3, 16, 63525) Indian society may never reach the goal but it was the duty of every Indian to set his sail towards that goal and no other if India was to be a happy land.
('94', 30, 3, 17, 63681) Harijan, 16 3 1947

('94', 31, 2, 3, 64153) CHARSOLADI, February 23, 1947
('94', 31, 3, 4, 64183) Q. Namasudra girls are usually married off at the age of 12 or 13; formerly the
('94', 31, 4, 5, 64263) usual age was 8 or 9. The bridegroom has to pay a dowry of Rs. 150 for the bride.
('94', 31, 5, 6, 64345) average difference between the two is about 12 to 15 years.
('94', 31, 5, 7, 64405) As a result of this the
('94', 31, 6, 8, 64429) number of widows in the Namasudra society is rather large.
('94', 31, 6, 9, 64488) Among one section of the
('94', 31, 7, 10, 64513) caste widow marriage was prevalent.
('94', 31, 7, 11, 64549) But in imitation of another section which was
('94', 31, 8, 12, 64595) looked upon as superior, the former are giving up that practice.
('94', 31, 8, 13, 64660) What is your advice
('94', 31, 9, 14, 64680) regarding child marriage and widow remarriage?
('94', 31, 10, 15, 64727) A. Dealing with the question Gandhiji said that his opinion was definite.
('94', 31, 11, 16, 64801) the first instance there should be no possibility of child widows.
('94', 31, 11, 17, 64868) He was averse to
('94', 31, 12, 18, 64885) child marriages.
('94', 31, 12, 19, 64902) It was an evil custom which unfortunately the Namasudras had
('94', 31, 13, 20, 64963) perhaps taken from the so called higher castes.
('94', 31, 14, 21, 65011) Gandhiji was also against the system of dowry.
('94', 31, 14, 22, 65058) It was nothing but the sale of
('94', 31, 15, 23, 65089) That there should be castes even amongst Namasudras was deplorable and he
('94', 31, 16, 24, 65163) would strongly advise them to abolish all caste distinctions amongst themselves.
('94', 31, 17, 25, 65244) And in this they should bear in mind the opinion the speaker had often expressed that
('94', 31, 18, 26, 65330) all caste distinctions should be abolished, and there should be only one caste,
('94', 31, 19, 27, 65410) namely, Bhangis, and all Hindus should take pride in being called Bhangis and
('94', 31, 20, 28, 65488) nothing else.
('94', 31, 20, 29, 65502) This applied to the Namasudras as well.
('94', 31, 21, 30, 65542) When child marriages were abolished, naturally there would be few, if any, young widows.
('94', 31, 21, 31, 65631) As a general rule he was for one man one wife for life, and one woman one husband for life.
('94', 31, 21, 32, 65723) Custom had familiarized women in the so called higher castes with enforced widowhood.
('94', 31, 21, 33, 65809) Contrary was the rule with men.
('94', 31, 21, 34, 65841) He called it a disgrace, but whilst society was in that pitiable condition, he advocated widow remarriage for all young widows.
('94', 31, 21, 35, 65969) He believed in equality of the sexes and, therefore, he could only think of the same rights for women as men.
('94', 31, 22, 36, 66079) Q. You say that you are in favour of inter religious marriages 2 but at the same time you say that each party should retain his or her own religion and, therefore, you said, you tolerated even civil marriages.
('94', 31, 22, 37, 66289) Are there any instances of parties belonging to different religions keeping up their own religions to the end of their lives; and is not the institution of civil marriage a negation of religion and does it not tend towards laxity of religion?
('94', 31, 23, 38, 66532) 1 Extracted from “Gandhiji’s Walking Tour Diary”.
('94', 31, 23, 39, 66582) It being Gandhiji’s silence day the questions and answers were read out.
('94', 31, 23, 40, 66655) 2 Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 21 2 1947
('94', 32, 0, 1, 66700) VOL. 94 : 17, FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947 33
('94', 32, 1, 2, 66747) A. Gandhiji said that the questions were appropriate.
('94', 32, 1, 3, 66801) He had no instances in mind where the parties had clung to their respective faiths unto death because these friends whom he knew had not yet died.
('94', 32, 1, 4, 66948) He had, however, under his observation men and women professing different religions and each clinging to his or her own faith without abatement.
('94', 32, 1, 5, 67093) But he would go so far as to say that they need not wait for the discovery of past instances.
('94', 32, 1, 6, 67187) They should create new ones so that timid ones may shed their timidity.
('94', 32, 1, 7, 67259) As to civil marriages he did not believe in them but he welcomed the institution of civil marriage as a much needed reform for the sake of reform.
('94', 32, 1, 8, 67406) Harijan, 16 3 1947

('94', 35, 0, 1, 72118) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 36
('94', 35, 1, 2, 72159) 41. DISCUSSION WITH A. V. THAKKAR , February 24, 1947 1
('94', 35, 2, 3, 72215) BAPA: Why this experiment here?
('94', 35, 3, 4, 72247) GANDHIJI: You are mistaken, Bapa; it is not an experiment but an integral part of my yajna.
('94', 35, 3, 5, 72339) One may forgo an experiment, one cannot forgo one’s duty.
('94', 35, 3, 6, 72397) Now if I regard a thing as a part of my yajna — a sacred duty — I may not give it up even if public opinion is wholly against me.
('94', 35, 3, 7, 72527) I am engaged in achieving self purification.
('94', 35, 3, 8, 72572) The five cardinal observances are the five props of my spiritual striving.
('94', 35, 3, 9, 72647) Brahmacharya is one of them.
('94', 35, 3, 10, 72676) But all the five constitute an indivisible whole.
('94', 35, 3, 11, 72726) They are inter related and inter dependent.
('94', 35, 3, 12, 72770) If one of them is broken, all are broken.
('94', 35, 3, 13, 72812) That being so, if in practice I resile in regard to brahmacharya to please Mrs. Grundy, I jettison not only brahmacharya but truth, ahimsa and all the rest.
('94', 35, 3, 14, 72969) I do not allow myself any divergence between theory and practice in respect of the rest.
('94', 35, 3, 15, 73058) If then I temporize in the matter of brahmacharya, would it not blunt the edge of my brahmacharya and vitiate my practice of truth?
('94', 35, 3, 16, 73190) Ever since my coming to Noakhali, I have been asking myself the question, ‘What is it that is choking the action of my ahimsa?
('94', 35, 3, 17, 73317) Why does not the spell work?
('94', 35, 3, 18, 73346) May it not be because I have temporized in the matter of brahmacharya?’
('94', 35, 4, 19, 73418) B. Your ahimsa has not failed.
('94', 35, 4, 20, 73449) Do not miss the wood for the trees....
('94', 35, 4, 21, 73488) 2 Just think what would have been the fate of Noakhali if you had not come.
('94', 35, 4, 22, 73564) The world does not think of brahmacharya as you do.
('94', 35, 5, 23, 73616) G. If I accept your contention, then it would amount to this that I should give up what I hold to be right for me, for fear of displeasing the world.
('94', 35, 5, 24, 73766) I shudder to think where I should have been if I had proceeded like that in my life.
('94', 35, 5, 25, 73851) I should have found myself at the bottom of the pit.
('94', 35, 5, 26, 73904) You can have no idea, Bapa, but I can well picture it to myself.
('94', 35, 5, 27, 73969) I have called my present venture a yajna—a sacrifice, a penance.
('94', 35, 5, 28, 74034) It means utmost self purification.
('94', 35, 5, 29, 74069) How can there be that self purification when in my mind I entertain a thing which I dare not put openly into practice?
('94', 35, 5, 30, 74188) Does one need anyone’s approval or permission to do what one holds with all one’s being to be one’s duty?
('94', 35, 5, 31, 74294) Under the circumstances, there are only two courses open to friends.
('94', 35, 5, 32, 74363) Either they should have faith in me, in the purity of my motives and my bona
('94', 35, 6, 33, 74440) 1 From Amrita Bazar Patrika, 27 2 1947. The source, however, has “February 25”.

('94', 36, 1, 2, 74595) fides, even though they are unable to follow or agree with my reasoning, or they should part company with me.
('94', 36, 1, 3, 74705) There is no middle course.
('94', 36, 1, 4, 74732) I dare not shrink from putting into action the logical implications of my conviction when I am launched on a sacrifice which consists of the full practice of truth.
('94', 36, 1, 5, 74897) Nor must I hide or keep my convictions to myself.
('94', 36, 1, 6, 74947) That would be disloyalty to friends.
('94', 36, 1, 7, 74984) Let X, Y and Z, therefore, go the way they choose, but how can I run away from the test?
('94', 36, 1, 8, 75073) My mind is made up.
('94', 36, 1, 9, 75093) On the lonely way to God on which I have set out, I need no earthly companions.
('94', 36, 1, 10, 75173) Let those who will, therefore, denounce me, if I am the imposter they imagine me to be, though they may not say so in so many words.

('94', 36, 4, 21, 76129) B. I for one cannot imagine anything base in you.

('94', 37, 1, 2, 77124) 42. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('94', 37, 2, 3, 77155) HAIMCHAR, February 24, 1947
('94', 37, 3, 4, 77183) This being the last stage of the second part of his pilgrimage, Gandhiji thanked God for the happy ending of the second part.
('94', 37, 3, 5, 77309) He referred to the intense wish that Bapa, whom he described as the chief priest and servant of the Harijans, had expressed that he should include Haimchar in his programme.
('94', 37, 3, 6, 77483) He referred also to the origin of the distribution of workers in the villages that had suffered and how Bapa had instinctively selected the Haimchar area as the field of his service.
('94', 37, 4, 7, 77666) He then referred to the communications, telegraphic and otherwise, he had received for his opinion on Mr. Attlee’s statement 3. He said there were the Congress and the League, not to mention other associations, which would express authoritative opinions.
('94', 37, 4, 8, 77921) He would however permit himself to say that the statement had put the burden on the various parties of doing what they thought best.
('94', 37, 4, 9, 78054) It had declared that British rule would end before or during the month of June, 1948. It was up to the parties to make or mar the situation.
('94', 37, 4, 10, 78195) Nothing on earth could overturn their united wish.
('94', 37, 4, 11, 78246) And so far as he was concerned, he was emphatically of the opinion that if the Hindus and Muslims closed their ranks and came together without external pressure, they would not only better their political condition but they would affect the whole of India and probably the world.
('94', 37, 5, 12, 78526) It was an easy descent to what was uppermost in the mind of his audience composed mostly of Namasudras.
('94', 37, 5, 13, 78630) He warned them against considering themselves as fallen or untouchables.
('94', 37, 5, 14, 78703) Those so called higher castes were the guilty ones; they were responsible for what they had become.
('94', 37, 5, 15, 78803) If they realized the fact, they would never make the mistake of imitating the evil customs and habits of the higher classes.
('94', 37, 6, 16, 78928) He was sorry to hear that there were child marriages amongst them and that child widows were compelled in imitation of the higher castes to abstain from remarrying.
('94', 37, 6, 17, 79093) The result, he had learned, was that diseases which resulted from promiscuity were prevalent among them.
('94', 37, 6, 18, 79198) Their betterment would not come from the legislatures or from any other outside agency.
('94', 37, 6, 19, 79286) It depended on their own efforts.
('94', 37, 6, 20, 79320) they should remember what the late Malaviyaji 3 used to say, that children of God should confine themselves to earning an honest cowrie and eat what it could procure.
('94', 37, 6, 21, 79487) Then there would be happiness for them and untouchability would be a thing of the past.
('94', 37, 7, 22, 79575) 1 Extracted from “Gandhiji’s Walking Tour Diary” 2 Vide Appendix I. 3 Madan Mohan Malaviya (1861 1946); President, Indian National Congress, 1909 and 1918; Member, Legislative Assembly; founder of the Benares Hindu University and its Vice Chancellor from 1919 to 1939
('94', 38, 0, 1, 79843) VOL. 94 : 17, FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947 39
('94', 38, 1, 2, 79890) The higher castes so called would be ashamed of their sin against them.
('94', 38, 2, 3, 79962) Bapu pointed out the destruction that had been wrought.
('94', 38, 2, 4, 80018) He was sorry for it but he would not shed a tear for it nor harbour ill will against the destroyers.
('94', 38, 2, 5, 80119) Let them not bewail their lot.
('94', 38, 2, 6, 80150) They were used to hard labour or should be.
('94', 38, 2, 7, 80194) They might plead with the Government to do justice and that in time.
('94', 38, 2, 8, 80263) But they would not give in if that assistance did not come.
('94', 38, 2, 9, 80323) They must trust their hands and feet to set them up again in life.
('94', 38, 2, 10, 80390) God always helped those who helped themselves.
('94', 38, 2, 11, 80437) Their reliance must be on the living God and on the ever toiling masses.

('94', 41, 7, 26, 84585) Q. What is the difference between your non co operation and the non fraternization of the Allies?
('94', 41, 8, 27, 84683) A. The answer is obvious.
('94', 41, 8, 28, 84709) My non co operation was purely non violent in conception as also in effect.
('94', 41, 8, 29, 84785) This does not mean that its practice was always perfect.
('94', 41, 8, 30, 84842) Theory and practice hardly ever coincide even as Euclid’s line in practice never coincides with his theoretical definition.

('94', 42, 3, 5, 85773) 51. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING 3
('94', 42, 4, 6, 85804) HAIMCHAR, February 25, 1947 Unity between Hindus and Muslims is the first thing to be achieved to facilitate the work of village reconstruction and no work will be done without this.
('94', 42, 5, 7, 85987) Gandhiji said that instead of making schemes of great projects they should start in a humble way the construction of good roads for peasants and destruction of water hyacinths in tanks.
('94', 42, 5, 8, 86173) Cleanliness was the one thing necessary in villages in order to prevent diseases.
('94', 42, 5, 9, 86255) If the officers engaged in village uplift task wanted to work in co operation with the people they must let the latter know that they were their servants.
('94', 42, 5, 10, 86410) Concluding, Gandhiji said that as he was a servant of the people he would be glad to render all possible help in this regard.
('94', 42, 6, 11, 86536) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 28 2 1947

('94', 43, 0, 1, 87479) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 44
('94', 43, 1, 2, 87520) wanted the Kingdom of God on earth.
('94', 43, 1, 3, 87556) Surely we did not want to wait for anyone else to do so.
('94', 43, 2, 4, 87613) Then he dealt with the questions that were addressed to him.
('94', 43, 3, 5, 87674) Q. Do you not think that a strict enforcement of the purdah system would improve the moral condition of women?
('94', 43, 4, 6, 87785) A. He was warned by some Muslim critics against speaking on the purdah.
('94', 43, 4, 7, 87857) He had therefore some hesitation in speaking about it.
('94', 43, 4, 8, 87912) But he took heart when he turned round and saw that many Hindu women observed it and that numerous Malaya Muslim women among whom he had many friends did not observe the purdah.
('94', 43, 4, 9, 88090) He also knew many distinguished Muslim women of India who did not observe it.
('94', 43, 4, 10, 88168) Lastly, the real purdah was of the heart.
('94', 43, 4, 11, 88210) A woman who peeped through the purdah and contemplated a male on whom her gaze fell violated the spirit behind it.
('94', 43, 4, 12, 88325) If a woman observed it in spirit, she was truly carrying out what the great Prophet had said.
('94', 43, 5, 13, 88419) Q. To those who had lost all their trade your advice is that they should voluntarily turn themselves into labourers.
('94', 43, 5, 14, 88536) Who will then look after education, commerce and the like?
('94', 43, 5, 15, 88595) If you thus dissolve the division of labour, will not the cause of civilization suffer?
('94', 43, 6, 16, 88683) A. The question betrayed ignorance of his meaning.
('94', 43, 6, 17, 88734) If a man could not carry on his original mercantile business, it was not open to him but obligatory on him to take to physical labour, say, scavenging or breaking stones.
('94', 43, 6, 18, 88905) He believed in the division of labour or work.
('94', 43, 6, 19, 88952) But he did insist on equality of wages.
('94', 43, 6, 20, 88992) The lawyer, the doctor, or the teacher was entitled to no more than the Bhangi.
('94', 43, 6, 21, 89072) Then only would division of work uplift the nation or the earth.
('94', 43, 6, 22, 89137) There was no other royal road to true civilization or happiness.
('94', 43, 7, 23, 89202) Spirit giveth life, the letter killeth.
('94', 43, 7, 24, 89242) A Ganapati with an elephant’s head was a monster but as a representation of Om 1 was an uplifting symbol.
('94', 43, 7, 25, 89348) Ravana with ten heads was a fabled fool but if it meant a man who carried no head about him and was tossed to and fro by fleeting passions, he was a many headed demon.
('94', 43, 8, 26, 89516) Q. How can the caste Hindus look after the interests of the untouchables?
('94', 43, 8, 27, 89590) How can they realize the feelings of the classes who have suffered so long at their hands?
('94', 43, 8, 28, 89681) Is it not then better to entrust the interests of the untouchables to men of their own caste?
('94', 43, 9, 29, 89775) A. He was of the opinion that the caste Hindus owed a sacred duty to the so called untouchables.
('94', 43, 9, 30, 89872) He must become a Bhangi in name and action.
('94', 43, 9, 31, 89916) When that happened the untouchables would rise at a bound and Hinduism would leave a rich legacy to the world.
('94', 43, 9, 32, 90027) If that happened, the system of cleaning closets would undergo a transformation.
('94', 43, 9, 33, 90108) In England the real Bhangis were famous engineers and sanitarians.
('94', 43, 9, 34, 90175) That could not happen in India so long as society was sluggish and slothful.
('94', 43, 9, 35, 90252) Harijan, 23 3 1947
('94', 43, 10, 36, 90271) 1 The sacred syllable or Pranava

('94', 44, 5, 7, 90572) 54. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('94', 44, 6, 8, 90599) HAIMCHAR, February 26, 1947
('94', 44, 7, 9, 90627) Referring to the news about the Union Government’s refusal of passports and impounding the certificates of identity for Drs.
('94', 44, 7, 10, 90752) Dadoo and Naicker, Gandhiji said: The Union Government will not be able to sustain their anti Asiatic policy by such an action.
('94', 44, 8, 11, 90880) He added that the action was wholly unwarranted and arbitrary if the facts stated in the cablegram he had received in this connection were correct.
('94', 44, 9, 12, 91028) Gandhiji hoped that either there were some justifying peremptory reasons for the refusal and impounding or that second thoughts would convince the Government that it was a hasty step and therefore it would be cancelled.
('94', 44, 10, 13, 91248) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 28 2 1947
('94', 44, 11, 14, 91280) 55. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 4
('94', 44, 12, 15, 91311) HAIMCHAR, February 26, 1947
('94', 44, 13, 16, 91339) Q. When things are all going wrong at the Centre, what can common people do to restore unity?
('94', 44, 14, 17, 91433) A. There was a law of science which enunciated that two forces were simultaneously at work: the centripetal and the centrifugal.
('94', 44, 14, 18, 91562) He wanted to apply the law to life also.
('94', 44, 14, 19, 91603) The centre, therefore, of the Government attracted us all to it and in good government we would respond to that centripetal force.
('94', 44, 14, 20, 91734) Similar was the centrifugal force in obedience to which we, the villagers of Haimchar, attracted the
('94', 44, 15, 21, 91835) 1 The source has “6”, obviously a slip, since this letter was in reply to the addressee’s letter dated February 24, soliciting Gandhiji’s presence at the Inter Asian Relations Conference which was to be held in New Delhi from March 23. 2 Gandhiji ultimately did attend the Conference on April 1 and 2. 3 Vide footnote 3, “Letter to Jawaharlal Nehru”, 24 2 1947 4 Extracted from “Gandhiji’s Walking Tour Diary”
('94', 45, 0, 1, 92245) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 46
('94', 45, 1, 2, 92286) centre.
('94', 45, 1, 3, 92294) Thus, where these forces worked well there would be ordered and orderly government at the centre and the circumference.
('94', 45, 1, 4, 92414) When, however, the centre was going wrong, it should be pointless to dominate the seven hundred thousand villages.
('94', 45, 1, 5, 92529) On the other hand, the villagers would live in perfect amity if they were wise in leaving alone the centre to look after its so called high politics?
('94', 45, 2, 6, 92679) Q. A man who sacrifices self interest for the sake of his community is at least unselfish to that extent.
('94', 45, 2, 7, 92785) How can the heart of such a man be affected so that he will sacrifice communal interests for the interest of the nation?
('94', 45, 3, 8, 92906) A. A man whose spirit of sacrifice did not go beyond his own community became selfish himself and also made his community selfish.
('94', 45, 3, 9, 93037) In his opinion the logical conclusion of self sacrifice was that the individual sacrificed himself for the community, the community sacrificed itself for the district, the district for the province, the province for the nation and the nation for the world.
('94', 45, 3, 10, 93294) A drop torn from the ocean perished without doing any good.
('94', 45, 3, 11, 93354) If it remained a part of the ocean, it shared the glory of carrying on its bosom a fleet of mighty ships.
('94', 45, 4, 12, 93460) Q. In free India whose interest shall be supreme?
('94', 45, 4, 13, 93510) If a neighbouring State is in want, what should free India do?
('94', 45, 5, 14, 93573) A. Gandhiji said that the first part of the question had been answered in the above.
('94', 45, 5, 15, 93658) A truly independent free India was bound to run to the help of its neighbours in distress.
('94', 45, 5, 16, 93749) He instanced Afghanistan, Ceylon and Burma and said that the rule also applied to the neighbours of these three and thus, by implication, they became India’s neighbours too.
('94', 45, 5, 17, 93923) And thus, he said, if individual sacrifice was a living sacrifice, it embraced the whole of humanity.
('94', 45, 6, 18, 94025) Gandhiji gave to his ideal society the name Ramarajya.
('94', 45, 6, 19, 94080) Let no one commit the mistake of thinking that Ramarajya means a rule of the Hindus.
('94', 45, 6, 20, 94165) My Rama is another name for Khuda or God.
('94', 45, 6, 21, 94207) I want Khudai raj, which is the same thing as the Kingdom of God on earth.
('94', 45, 6, 22, 94282) The rule of the first four Caliphs was somewhat comparable to it.
('94', 45, 6, 23, 94348) The establishment of such a rajya would not only mean welfare of the whole of the Indian people but of the whole world.
('94', 45, 7, 24, 94468) Harijan, 23 3 1947, and Mahatma Gandhi—The Last Phase, Vol. I, Bk.
('94', 45, 7, 25, 94535) II, pp.
('94', 45, 8, 26, 94543) 1 What follows is reproduced from Mahatma Gandhi — The Last Phase.

('94', 47, 1, 2, 95733) 58. LETTER TO LUDWIG BORSCH
('94', 47, 2, 3, 95761) KAZIRKHIL, RAMGANJ P.S., NOAKHALI DISTT., BENGAL, February 27, 1947 DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter of the 11th ultimo.
('94', 47, 2, 4, 95881) 1 Distance lends enchantment to the scene.
('94', 47, 2, 5, 95924) I would, therefore, warn you against visiting India for the enrichment of your life.
('94', 47, 2, 6, 96009) Life, as it is found in India, is wholly different from the life described in the best books on ancient wisdom in the East.
('94', 47, 2, 7, 96133) I wish I could give you definite guidance on the selection of your diet.
('94', 47, 2, 8, 96206) We in India, not excluding myself, have learnt much from English and American literature on the diet question.
('94', 47, 2, 9, 96317) The ordinary Indian diet is unbalanced and is heavily spiced.
('94', 47, 2, 10, 96379) Therefore, I would advise you to consult the many American and English text books written on vegetarianism and more especially on the kind ofdiet.
('94', 47, 2, 11, 96526) You will gain much more than I could give from this literature if you used discretion.
('94', 47, 2, 12, 96613) LUDWIG BORSCH, ESQ.
