('94', 48, 5, 36, 99322) 60. TALK WITH FAZLUL HUQ
('94', 48, 6, 37, 99347) February 27, 1947
('94', 48, 7, 38, 99365) GANDHIJI: Oh, don’t stand up.
('94', 48, 7, 39, 99395) You were the Chief Minister when I met you last !
('94', 48, 8, 40, 99445) HUQ: I shall be frank with you.
('94', 48, 8, 41, 99477) It is no use saying one thing and having
('94', 49, 0, 1, 99518) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 50
('94', 49, 1, 2, 99559) something else up your sleeve.
('94', 49, 2, 3, 99590) Gandhiji nodded complete agreement.
('94', 49, 3, 4, 99626) The Maulvi Saheb began: Gandhiji had not gone to Bihar; his place was in Bihar rather than in Noakhali; Noakhali Muslims, far from being aggressors, were the victims of police repression.
('94', 49, 3, 5, 99814) Hindu police officers were harassing innocent Muslims and implicating them in false cases—they should be withdrawn; Muslims were not criminals, abductors of women, etc.; Islam never taught that.
('94', 49, 4, 6, 100009) Gandhiji again agreed so far as the teachings of Islam in the abstract were concerned.
('94', 49, 5, 7, 100096) HUQ: Very few understand Islam.
('94', 49, 5, 8, 100128) They call it the religion of the sword.
('94', 49, 5, 9, 100168) The minorities in the Muslim State were the special responsibility of the majority.
('94', 49, 5, 10, 100252) The non Muslims were zimmis.
('94', 49, 6, 11, 100281) The Maulvi Saheb’s last point was that far from the Hindus having cause to be afraid of the Muslim majority in Noakhali, it was the latter, in fact, who were afraid of Hindu domination.
('94', 49, 6, 12, 100467) The Hindus should shed their fear and accept Pakistan.
('94', 49, 6, 13, 100522) His Majesty’s Government’s statement 2 of 20th February, 1947, would only bring civil war to India.
('94', 49, 7, 14, 100622) G. (In a tone of light banter): So, if I come to Barisal, there is only the khal 3 for me, is it not?
('94', 49, 8, 15, 100724) HUQ: No, no, Mahatmaji, you are always welcome.
('94', 49, 8, 16, 100772) That was only a joke.
('94', 49, 8, 17, 100794) I never can let go a joke—even at the expense of my father.
('94', 49, 8, 18, 100854) That is my nature !
('94', 49, 9, 19, 100874) Gandhiji said that he had always asked Jinnah to convince him of the meaning and implications of Pakistan.
('94', 49, 9, 20, 100981) His formula 4 was before the Muslim League leader and the country and so far as he was concerned the offer still stood.
('94', 49, 9, 21, 101101) As regards withdrawal of criminal cases, it rested with the Bengal Government.
('94', 49, 9, 22, 101180) Regarding Bihar, he continued: I may shortly go there.
('94', 49, 9, 23, 101235) But it will not be to oblige you.
('94', 49, 10, 24, 101269) He was awaiting Dr. Mahmud’s 5 reply, he told the Maulvi Saheb, but if the latter could assure him that the majority community in Noakhali would stand guarantee for the safety and security of the minority community, he would feel free to leave Bengal immediately.
('94', 49, 10, 25, 101533) Could he give that assurance?
('94', 49, 11, 26, 101563) To this the Maulvi Saheb gave no straight reply.
('94', 49, 11, 27, 101612) Instead, he bagan to talk
('94', 49, 12, 28, 101638) 1 Who were required to pay a tax called jazia for protection by the State 2 Vide “Clement Attlee’s Statement”, 20 2 1947 3 A canal.
('94', 49, 12, 29, 101770) Fazlul Huq was reported to have said that as a non Muslim, Gandhiji should not preach the teachings of Islam, for, instead of Hindu Muslim unity, he was creating bitterness between the two communities.
('94', 49, 12, 30, 101972) Had he been to Barisal, he would have driven him into the canal.
('94', 49, 12, 31, 102037) Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 16 2 1947 4 Presumably the Rajaji Formula.
('94', 49, 12, 32, 102113) Vide “C. Rajagopalachari’s Formula” 5 Syed Mahmud, Minister for Development and Transport in Bihar
('94', 50, 0, 1, 102212) VOL. 94 : 17, FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947 51
('94', 50, 1, 2, 102259) about a coalition Government in Bengal as the only remedy for Bengal’s ills!
('94', 50, 2, 3, 102336) At this point one of Fazlul Huq’s companions broke in: “I was a worker in the Khilafat movement 1; you were the first leader who taught me politics.”
('94', 50, 3, 4, 102486) G. If you had taken your politics off me, you would have given a much better account of yourself.
('94', 50, 4, 5, 102584) G. (TO HUQ): What is this quarrel between you and Suhrawardy?
('94', 50, 4, 6, 102646) I do not like it.

('94', 50, 5, 8, 102787) Gandhiji thereupon twitted him for his spendthrift nature and sent him away laughing.

('94', 50, 7, 11, 102924) 61. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 2
('94', 50, 8, 12, 102955) HAIMCHAR, February 27, 1947
('94', 50, 9, 13, 102983) Q. Can a man serve his immediate neighbours and yet serve the whole of
('94', 50, 10, 14, 103054) humanity?
('94', 50, 10, 15, 103064) What is the true meaning of swadeshi?
('94', 50, 11, 16, 103102) A. Gandhiji said that the question had been answered by him on the previous
('94', 50, 12, 17, 103178) evening.
('94', 50, 12, 18, 103187) 3 He believed implicity in the truth that a man could serve his neighbours and
('94', 50, 13, 19, 103266) humanity at the same time, the condition being that the service of the neighbours was
('94', 50, 14, 20, 103352) in no way selfish or exclusive, i.e., did not in any way involve the exploitation of
('94', 50, 15, 21, 103437) any other human being.
('94', 50, 15, 22, 103460) The neighbours would then understand the spirit in which
('94', 50, 16, 23, 103517) such service was given.
('94', 50, 16, 24, 103541) They would also know that they would be expected to give
('94', 50, 17, 25, 103598) their services to their neighbours.
('94', 50, 17, 26, 103634) Thus considered, it would spread like the
('94', 50, 18, 27, 103676) proverbial snowball gathering strength in geometrical progression, encircling the
('94', 50, 19, 28, 103758) whole earth.
('94', 50, 20, 29, 103771) It followed that swadeshi was that spirit which dictated man to serve his next 
('94', 50, 21, 30, 103851) door neighbour to the exclusion of any other.
('94', 50, 21, 31, 103897) The condition that he had already
('94', 50, 22, 32, 103931) 1 Which was launched in 1919 “against the threatened dismemberment of Turkey and removal of the holy places of Islam from the Caliph’s control” 2 According to “Gandhiji’s Walking Tour Diary” from which this has been extracted, Gandhiji offered prayers in a temple which was destroyed during the riots and was rebuilt by the Government.
('94', 50, 22, 33, 104267) The idol in the temple, however, eescaped destruction because the resourceful priest had put it away in a safe place.
('94', 50, 22, 34, 104385) Gandhiji hoped that the old and rusty tins used in rebuilding the temple would be painted so as to prevent further deterioration.
('94', 50, 22, 35, 104515) 3 Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 26 2 1947
('94', 51, 0, 1, 104560) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 52
('94', 51, 1, 2, 104601) mentioned was that the neighbour thus served had in his turn to serve his own
('94', 51, 2, 3, 104679) neighbour.
('94', 51, 2, 4, 104690) In this sense swadeshi was never exclusive.
('94', 51, 2, 5, 104734) It recognized the scientific
('94', 51, 3, 6, 104763) limitation of human capacity for service.
('94', 51, 4, 7, 104805) Q. The Government has been introducing schemes of industrializing the
('94', 51, 5, 8, 104875) country for the maximum utilization of her raw materials, not of her abundant and
('94', 51, 6, 9, 104957) unused man power which is left to rot in idleness.
('94', 51, 6, 10, 105008) Can such schemes be considered
('94', 51, 7, 11, 105039) swadeshi?
('94', 51, 8, 12, 105049) A. Gandhiji remarked that the question had been well put.
('94', 51, 8, 13, 105107) He did not exactly
('94', 51, 9, 14, 105126) know what the Government plan was.
('94', 51, 9, 15, 105161) But he heartily endorsed the proposition that
('94', 51, 10, 16, 105207) any plan which exploited the raw materials of a country and neglected the potentially
('94', 51, 11, 17, 105293) more powerful man power was lopsided and could never tend to establish human
('94', 51, 12, 18, 105370) equality.
('94', 51, 13, 19, 105380) America was the most industrialized country in the world and yet it had not
('94', 51, 14, 20, 105456) banished poverty and degradation.
('94', 51, 14, 21, 105490) That was because it neglected the universal man 
('94', 51, 15, 22, 105539) power and concentrated power in the hands of the few who amassed fortunes at the
('94', 51, 16, 23, 105620) expense of the many.
('94', 51, 16, 24, 105641) The result was that its industrialization had become a menace to
('94', 51, 17, 25, 105706) its own poor and to the rest of the world.
('94', 51, 18, 26, 105749) If India was to escape such disaster, it had to imitate what was best in America and the other Western countries and leave aside its attractive looking but destructive economic policies.
('94', 51, 18, 27, 105936) Therefore, real planning consisted in the best utilization of the whole man power of India and the distribution of the raw products of India in her numerous villages instead of sending them outside and rebuying finished articles at fabulous prices.
('94', 51, 19, 28, 106185) After the questions had been answered, Gandhiji touched upon the fact that he had a visit from some members of the Scheduled Classes.
('94', 51, 19, 29, 106319) He had told them that his mission was to teach people how to be really brave.
('94', 51, 19, 30, 106397) They need not be afraid for their lives because the so called high caste men had not yet returned to their places.
('94', 51, 19, 31, 106512) If they shed their fear they would have no enemies.
('94', 51, 19, 32, 106564) The Muslims would be their friends when they recognized bravery in them.
('94', 51, 19, 33, 106637) Cowards were ever exposed to the enmity of all, whether Muslims or others.
('94', 51, 19, 34, 106712) The way to the attainment of that courage lay not in the possession of the sword and the efficiency to kill one’s opponent, but in the refusal to recognize in any other human being an enemy, along with the determination to lay down one’s life and yet not surrender at the point of the sword.
('94', 51, 20, 35, 107004) Gandhiji then referred in detail to some of the abuses current in local society, like child marriage, absence of widow remarriage, etc., which resulted in the lowering of the moral stature of the people.
('94', 51, 20, 36, 107208) If they could shed these weaknesses, they would gain the power to die for their faith and honour.
('94', 51, 20, 37, 107306) Harijan, 23 3 1947

('94', 54, 3, 9, 110012) 67. LETTER TO A. J. MUSTE
('94', 54, 4, 10, 110038) KAZIRKHIL, RAMGANJ P.S., NOAKHALI DISTT., February 28, 1947
('94', 54, 5, 11, 110098) DEAR FRIEND,
('94', 54, 6, 12, 110111) Muriel Lester has sent me your letter of the 27th September last which has remained on my file for some time.
('94', 54, 6, 13, 110221) She has also given me a brief description of your selfless labours.
('94', 54, 6, 14, 110289) How I wish I could send you some useful suggestions by way of help in what you very rightly term as crisis !
('94', 54, 6, 15, 110398) The aftermath of the last war is in reality much worse than the war itself if only because its bloodiness is so hidden from view that man deceives himself into the belief that he is at last safer than when the war was on.
('94', 54, 6, 16, 110620) I wish too that I could give you the assurance that India, when she has come to her own completely, will not join the race for the increase of armaments.
('94', 54, 6, 17, 110774) I can only say that whatever I can do to prevent any such misfortune will not be left undone.
('94', 54, 7, 18, 110868) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI A. J. MUSTE, ESQ.

('94', 55, 5, 13, 111706) 69. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('94', 55, 6, 14, 111733) HAIMCHAR, February 28, 1947 I have received a cablegram from the ex Natal Indian Congress which says that the Congress, the Transvaal Indian Congress, the Coloured People’s Organization and the African National Congress have decided on their part to refrain from taking part in or in any manner assisting in the celebrations in honour of the Royal visit to the Union of South Africa.
('94', 55, 6, 15, 112117) They feel that in view of the disabilities imposed upon the Asiatics and Africans and other coloured people it would be improper on their part to share in the rejoicings of the white people of South Africa.
('94', 55, 6, 16, 112324) The cablegram asked me to endorse the abstention which they describe by the name of “boycott”.
('94', 55, 6, 17, 112419) I take this opportunity of publicly endorsing the abstention as a natural and dignified step by any self respecting body of people.
('94', 55, 6, 18, 112551) The Hindu, 1 3 1947
('94', 55, 7, 19, 112571) 1 In which the addressee had requested Gandhiji to send him scientific or spiritual treatise on fasting.
('94', 56, 0, 1, 112676) VOL. 94 : 17, FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947 57
('94', 56, 1, 2, 112723) 70. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('94', 56, 2, 3, 112754) HAIMCHAR, February 28, 1947
('94', 56, 3, 4, 112782) Gandhiji took up the thread of his remarks of the previous evening about the Namasudras.
('94', 56, 3, 5, 112871) He had no time to refer to the question of education.
('94', 56, 3, 6, 112925) The blame for the neglect of education among them must lie solely upon the so called high caste Hindus.
('94', 56, 3, 7, 113029) It was preposterous to expect that those who were deliberately suppressed by Hindu society would themselves take to education.
('94', 56, 3, 8, 113156) What he, however, deplored was that there were men among them who taught them not to accept good things from the so called high caste Hindus.
('94', 56, 3, 9, 113298) He was of the opinion that it was mischievous propaganda.
('94', 56, 3, 10, 113356) Therefore, he expected the Namasudras to give definite assurance about land [for school] and the attendance of boys and girls.
('94', 56, 3, 11, 113483) In that case he had no doubt that there were enough penitent Hindus who would gladly take up the duty of educating these neglected children.
('94', 56, 3, 12, 113624) He invited the Namasudras to send the required assurance to Thakkar Bapa who might be trusted by them to do the rest and he hoped that there were enough local Hindus who would offer their money and ability for the performance of the honourable duty of educating these children.
('94', 56, 4, 13, 113902) He then referred to the prospect of his having to go to Bihar and to the atrocities that had been committed by the Hindus of Bihar before which the happenings in Noakhali or Tipperah paled into insignificance.
('94', 56, 4, 14, 114112) He had enough pressure put upon him by the Muslims in Bengal to go to Bihar.
('94', 56, 4, 15, 114189) He had refused to listen to the advice because he had the hope that he could work with equal effect among the Bihar Hindus without having to go there.
('94', 56, 4, 16, 114340) But he had a visit from the secretary of Dr. Syed Mahmud.
('94', 56, 4, 17, 114398) He had brought a long letter from Dr. Mahmud.
('94', 56, 4, 18, 114444) They should know that Dr. Mahmud was a valued friend of his.
('94', 56, 4, 19, 114505) He was himself Development Member of the Bihar Ministry.
('94', 56, 4, 20, 114562) In answer to his question, Dr. Mahmud had written to him asking him to visit Bihar as soon as he could.
('94', 56, 4, 21, 114666) He had said that all was not as rosy as it should be and that his presence in Bihar would ease the situation and reassure the Muslims that he was equally concerned about the welfare of the Muslims as of the Hindus.
('94', 56, 4, 22, 114881) He could not resist Dr. Mahmud’s letter.
('94', 56, 4, 23, 114922) He had, therefore, sent an urgent wire 2 to Bihar and it was highly likely that he might have to hurry to Bihar.
('94', 56, 4, 24, 115035) In that case, he would have to interrupt the tour in Noakhali and Tipperah.
('94', 56, 4, 25, 115111) But the message he would leave for the Hindus and Mussalmans here, during the short period he expected to be absent, was that they should live with one another as brothers.
('94', 56, 4, 26, 115284) This they could only do if they shed internal weaknesses and were prepared to lay down their lives without retaliation for the defence of what they considered sacred.
('94', 56, 5, 27, 115451) 1 Extracted from “Gandhiji’s Walking Tour Diary” 2 Vide”Telegram to Shrikrishna Sinha”, 28 2 1947 3 The following two paragraphs are reproduced from Amrita Bazar Patrika.
('94', 57, 0, 1, 115622) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 58
('94', 57, 1, 2, 115663) Gandhiji said that he was in constant communication with the authorities concerned on the Bihar situation and had been speaking unequivocally against the madness of Bihar Hindus.
('94', 57, 1, 3, 115842) He was sure that he was there where he could serve both the communities.
('94', 57, 1, 4, 115915) He had come to Noakhali to serve both the communities and not to create bitterness between them.
('94', 57, 2, 5, 116012) He had come here to create fearlessness among the affected people.
('94', 57, 2, 6, 116079) He asked them not to despair and told them that his associates would be working here as usual.
('94', 57, 2, 7, 116174) People here must not quarrel among themselves.
('94', 57, 2, 8, 116221) They must not antagonize Muslims but they must not also yield to threats.
('94', 57, 2, 9, 116295) They should rather lay down their lives.
('94', 57, 2, 10, 116336) Gandhiji emphatically said that he had decided to go to Bihar, not for the relief of Muslims, but to effect a change of mentality among the Hindus of Bihar.
('94', 57, 2, 11, 116493) He hoped that Hindus and Muslims would live together in amity all over India.
('94', 57, 3, 12, 116571) Gandhiji then passed on to a question which had been referred to him that evening.
('94', 57, 3, 13, 116654) It was with regard to the partition of Bengal into two pro vinces, one having a Hindu and the other a Muslim majority.
('94', 57, 3, 14, 116773) Bengalis had once fought against and successfully annulled the partition of their province.
('94', 57, 3, 15, 116865) 1 But according to some, he proceeded, the time had now come when such a division had become desirable in the interest of peace.
('94', 57, 3, 16, 116994) Gandhiji expressed the opinion that personally he had always been anti partition.
('94', 57, 3, 17, 117076) But it was not uncommon even for brothers to fight and separate from one another.
('94', 57, 3, 18, 117158) There were many things which India had to put up with in the past under compulsion, but he himself was built in a totally different way.
('94', 57, 4, 19, 117295) In a similar manner, if the Hindus, who formed the majority in the whole of India, desired to keep everyone united by means of compulsion, he would resist it in the same manner as before.
('94', 57, 4, 20, 117483) He was as much against forced partition as against forced unity.
('94', 57, 5, 21, 117548) Gandhiji then proceeded to say that whatever might have been the history of British rule in the past, there was no shadow of doubt that the British were going to quit India in the near future.
('94', 57, 5, 22, 117741) It was time, therefore, that the Hindus and the Muslims should determine to live in peace and amity.
('94', 57, 5, 23, 117842) The alternative was civil war which would only serve to tear the country to pieces.
('94', 57, 5, 24, 117926) One did not know what the future had in store for them.
('94', 57, 5, 25, 117982) If the people really and sincerely, and with a pure heart, wished unitedly for a particular thing, speaking in human language, it could be said that God, being the servant of His servants, would Himself carry out that will.
('94', 57, 6, 26, 118206) Harijan, 23 3 1947, and Amrita Bazar Patrika, 2 3 1947
('94', 57, 7, 27, 118261) 1 The partition of Bengal in 1905 was annulled in 1911.
('94', 58, 0, 1, 118317) VOL. 94 : 17, FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947 59

('94', 59, 1, 2, 119852) 73. LETTER TO H. S. SUHRAWARDY
('94', 59, 2, 3, 119883) KAZIRKHIL, RAMGANJ P.S., NOAKHALI DISTT., March 1, 1947
('94', 59, 3, 4, 119939) DEAR FRIEND,
('94', 59, 4, 5, 119952) I hope you heard from the S.D.O. Chandpur, Tipperah District that I am endeavouring to leave for Bihar tomorrow.
('94', 59, 4, 6, 120065) I wish I could say that I am trying to go because of your pressing advice to Fazlul Haq Sahib who spoke publicly the other day and repeated the same thing, though very courteously, on Thursday last when he was good enough to call on me.
('94', 59, 4, 7, 120302) The memorandum of Sardar Niranjan Singh Gill about which I wrote to you on February 22, had predisposed me towards a temporary visit to Bihar.
('94', 59, 4, 8, 120445) What decided me however was a long letter from Dr. Syed Mahmud who has sent it with his Private Secretary.
('94', 59, 4, 9, 120552) In order to come to a final decision I sent a peremptory message yesterday through the good offices of Khan Sahib, the S.D.O. of Chandpur, asking whether the Bihar Chief Minister had any objection to my immediately proceeding to Patna.
('94', 59, 4, 10, 120788) The reply may be received any minute.
('94', 59, 4, 11, 120826) If I go I would like you to give me hints as to what I should see.
('94', 59, 4, 12, 120893) The desire to go has arisen because suspicion has been created in my mind that all is not well in Bihar so far as the Hindu behaviour towards the Muslims of Bihar is concerned.
('94', 59, 4, 13, 121070) The cause in either case, in Bihar or Bengal, is identical.
('94', 59, 4, 14, 121130) There was consternation among the Hindus yesterday when I announced my intention of immediately proceeding to Bihar.
('94', 59, 4, 15, 121247) They said they were afraid of being molested as in October.
('94', 59, 4, 16, 121307) I hope that the fear will prove groundless and that you will do all you can to allay the fear.
('94', 59, 4, 17, 121402) It is said that all aid in the shape of rations will be stopped from the 15th instant.
('94', 59, 4, 18, 121489) If this information turns out to be true there would be widespread avoidable distress.
('94', 59, 4, 19, 121576) The machinery provided for relief is very slow.
('94', 59, 4, 20, 121624) Sufficient material for building is not there.
('94', 59, 4, 21, 121671) Weavers have got no yarn for weaving.
('94', 59, 4, 22, 121709) Fishermen have got none for making nets.
('94', 59, 4, 23, 121750) Carpenters have got no tools.
('94', 59, 4, 24, 121780) Agriculturists have no bullocks.
('94', 59, 4, 25, 121813) There are no seeds for sowing.
('94', 59, 4, 26, 121844) Thakkar Bapa mentioned the difficuly of merchants in Haimchar for a loan in order to enable them to start business.
('94', 59, 4, 27, 121960) He has prepared an application to be sent to you.
('94', 59, 4, 28, 122010) It makes a
('94', 60, 0, 1, 122021) VOL. 94 : 17, FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947 61
('94', 60, 1, 2, 122068) business like proposition.
('94', 60, 1, 3, 122095) I should have thought that people who have lost their all would be entitled to adequate grants for starting business.
('94', 60, 1, 4, 122213) On the contrary, however, he offers even interest if it is required for the loan he proposed.
('94', 60, 1, 5, 122307) I hope there will be no delay in granting the loan.
('94', 60, 1, 6, 122359) I would strongly urge that interest should not be asked in such cases.
('94', 60, 1, 7, 122430) There is a strong belief that there is boycott by the Muslims of Hindus so far as labour for them is concerned.
('94', 60, 1, 8, 122542) Of course I have said that no government can compel any community to labour for another.
('94', 60, 1, 9, 122631) Critics have no difficulty in agreeing to my proposition against compulsion.
('94', 60, 1, 10, 122708) They however suggest that boycott is approved, even encouraged, by your Government.
('94', 60, 1, 11, 122792) I hope that my information is wholly wrong.
('94', 60, 1, 12, 122836) I am leaving a copy of this letter with Satis Babu of Khadi Pratishthan who is at present stationed at Kazirkhil and who will represent me during my absence which I hope will be only temporary and will be attended by success.
('94', 60, 1, 13, 123062) Though my absence will be temporary, I cannot omit to mention that so far as I am personally concerned, the whole of the official world has been courteous and considerate to me and in this mention I include the police whom you have put to guard my person.
('94', 60, 1, 14, 123318) H. S. SUHRAWARDY SAHIB PRIME MINISTER BENGAL From a copy: Pyarelal Papers.
('94', 60, 1, 15, 123393) Nehru Memorial Museum and Library.
('94', 60, 1, 16, 123428) Courtesy: Beladevi Nayyar and Dr. Sushila Nayyar

('94', 60, 3, 19, 123590) I am ashamed that at this time of day you should think of the application of Section 93. There are many honourable ways of exposing the corruption no matter where it exists.
('94', 60, 3, 20, 123764) The application of Section 93 is not among them.

('94', 61, 3, 6, 124434) The Hindu, 3 3 1947
('94', 61, 4, 7, 124454) 76. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 2
('94', 61, 5, 8, 124485) HAIMCHAR, March 1, 1947
('94', 61, 6, 9, 124509) Gandhiji said that he would try to cover Bajpati also on his return.
('94', 61, 6, 10, 124578) 3 He could
('94', 61, 7, 11, 124589) not fix the time.
('94', 61, 7, 12, 124607) He was not leaving Noakhali or Tipperah without the establishment
('94', 61, 8, 13, 124673) of heart unity.
('94', 61, 8, 14, 124689) There was time for satisfying all reasonable expectations.
('94', 61, 8, 15, 124748) I hope to leave for Bihar tomorrow afternoon.
('94', 61, 8, 16, 124794) I will leave Haimchar at about three in the afternoon.
('94', 61, 8, 17, 124849) I will go to Calcutta and from there proceed to Bihar.
('94', 61, 9, 18, 124904) He did not expect to stay there long.
('94', 61, 9, 19, 124942) He would not be able to hold the prayer
('94', 61, 10, 20, 124982) meeting [tomorrow] in Haimchar but would like to have it in Chandpur.
('94', 61, 11, 21, 125052) Q. You have referred to numerous social abuses prevalent among us.
('94', 61, 11, 22, 125119) They are
('94', 61, 12, 23, 125128) there; but then if the men are unwilling to effect the necessary social changes what
('94', 61, 13, 24, 125213) can we women do about it?
('94', 61, 14, 25, 125239) A. Gandhiji said that there was no occasion for women to consider themselves
('94', 61, 15, 26, 125316) subordinate or inferior to men.
('94', 61, 15, 27, 125348) It was proclaimed that woman was half of man and by
('94', 61, 16, 28, 125400) parity of reasoning man was half of woman.
('94', 61, 16, 29, 125443) They were not two separate entities but
('94', 61, 17, 30, 125483) halves of one.
('94', 61, 17, 31, 125498) The English language went further and called woman the better half of
('94', 61, 18, 32, 125568) Therefore, he advised women to resort to civil rebellion against all undesirable
('94', 61, 19, 33, 125649) and unworthy restraints.
('94', 61, 19, 34, 125674) All restraints to be beneficial, must be voluntary.
('94', 61, 19, 35, 125726) There was
('94', 61, 20, 36, 125736) no possibility of harm resulting from civil rebellion.
('94', 61, 20, 37, 125791) It presupposed purity and a
('94', 61, 21, 38, 125819) reasoned resistance.
('94', 61, 22, 39, 125840) Q. Those who have lost their dear ones, or the homes which they built up
('94', 61, 23, 40, 125913) 1 The members of the delegation had asked Gandhiji the reason for differences in the youth movement in India.
('94', 61, 23, 41, 126023) 2 Extracted from “Gandhiji’s Walking Tour Diary” 3 People from Bajpati had complained that Bajpati had been dropped from Gandhiji’s programme.
('94', 61, 23, 42, 126166) 4 This paragraph is from Amrita Bazar Patrika.
('94', 62, 0, 1, 126213) VOL. 94 : 17, FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947 63
('94', 62, 1, 2, 126260) through years of patient care, find it extremely difficult to forgive and forget.
('94', 62, 2, 3, 126342) can they get over that feeling and look upon the community from which the
('94', 62, 3, 4, 126416) miscreants came with a feeling of brotherhood?
('94', 62, 4, 5, 126463) A. The speaker said the one way to forget and forgive was to contem plate Bihar which had done much worse than Noakhali and Tipperah.
('94', 62, 4, 6, 126597) Did they want the Muslims to take dire vengeance for the Hindu atrocities there?
('94', 62, 4, 7, 126678) They could not.
('94', 62, 4, 8, 126694) From this they should learn to forget and forgive, if they did not wish to descend to the lowest depths of barbarity.
('94', 62, 4, 9, 126812) Moreover, they must not harbour an inferiority complex.
('94', 62, 4, 10, 126868) They should be brave.
('94', 62, 4, 11, 126890) And forgiveness was an attribute and adornment of bravery.
('94', 62, 4, 12, 126949) Let them be truly brave.
('94', 62, 4, 13, 126974) True bravery refused to strike; it would suffer all infliction with patient cheerfulness.
('94', 62, 4, 14, 127064) That would be the truest way of disarming opposition.
('94', 62, 5, 15, 127118) Q. Speaking about the proposed partition of Bengal, one of the proposals is that there should be only two separate administrative divisions without any exchange of populations taking place.
('94', 62, 5, 16, 127308) This arrangement would keep each community in its place in peace.
('94', 62, 5, 17, 127374) What is your objection to such a proposal?
('94', 62, 5, 18, 127417) A. Gandhiji considered two administrative divisions to be as impracticable as exchange of populations.
('94', 62, 5, 19, 127520) That would result in an armed neutrality which was bound to kill all healthy growth.
('94', 62, 5, 20, 127605) The leaders of both the communities must come together as friends and reduce their differences and suffer them.
('94', 62, 5, 21, 127717) Any other way was the way of barbarism and subordination to a third power.
('94', 62, 6, 22, 127792) Harijan, 23 3 1947, and Amrita Bazar Patrika, 4 3 1947

('94', 66, 9, 10, 133902) I have your letter.
('94', 66, 9, 11, 133922) You are unnecessarily worrying yourself.
('94', 66, 9, 12, 133963) One for whom Ramanama is the unfailing cure would not beget [problems of] blood pressure and would not hear the drumming noise in his ears.
('94', 66, 9, 13, 134103) However, if both these do occur, he would bear them patiently and die while doing so.
('94', 66, 9, 14, 134189) I have no doubt about the truth of this point.
('94', 66, 9, 15, 134236) I do get [high] blood pressure and get buzzing in the ears.
('94', 66, 9, 16, 134296) This shows that I should depend on Ramanama rather than take medicines, thinking that Ramanama is not serving any purpose.
('94', 66, 9, 17, 134419) It is true that this is not easily done.
('94', 66, 9, 18, 134460) In the matter of the sacred task here, we should have recourse only to Ramanama.
('94', 66, 9, 19, 134541) Even so, I did take sarpagandha yesterday.
('94', 66, 9, 20, 134584) I do have doubts about its efficacy.
('94', 66, 9, 21, 134621) My duty is to die in peace if it is necessary to die.
('94', 66, 9, 22, 134675) Why should you be disturbed when I die?
('94', 66, 9, 23, 134715) You should work harder in that event.
('94', 66, 9, 24, 134753) I still hope to recover only with the help of Ramanama.

('94', 67, 5, 10, 135497) [March 3, 1947] 1
('94', 67, 6, 11, 135515) To a question whether Gandhiji’s stay in Noakhali had improved the situation there, Gandhiji said: This question should rather be addressed to the interested parties — people who have suffered.
('94', 67, 6, 12, 135709) I worked among the people and preached my message of love and communal amity.
('94', 67, 6, 13, 135787) 2 Personally I feel the situation has improved and there is more self confidence among the people today, but the sufferers alone can tell you whether the situation has really improved.
('94', 67, 6, 14, 135972) It is they who matter most.
('94', 67, 7, 15, 136000) Asked about the duration of his stay in Bihar, Gandhiji said: I cannot exactly say how long I shall be there.

('94', 80, 2, 3, 163778) PATNA , March 7 2, 1947
('94', 80, 3, 4, 163802) Gandhiji began his address this evening by saying that just before starting for the prayer ground he had taken a brief rest.
('94', 80, 3, 5, 163927) Today also I was wondering all the time whether we have realized that we had committed a great crime, a sin, and whether we had atoned for it.
('94', 80, 3, 6, 164070) All my waking hours during the day have been spent in listening to the reports brought in by many Muslim and Hindu friends.
('94', 80, 3, 7, 164194) All of them narrated the grievous wrongs done by us.
('94', 80, 3, 8, 164247) None of them has been able to assure me that things have now settled down to complete normalcy.
('94', 80, 3, 9, 164343) While I experienced the impact of these reports on me, I also wondered about the nature and intensity of the impact which these crimes and atrocities must have produced on the hearts of those who witnessed them.
('94', 80, 4, 10, 164555) The ideal of the sthitaprajna (man of steadfast wisdom) described in the second chapter of the Gita was always before him and he was ceaseless in his efforts to reach that ideal.
('94', 80, 4, 11, 164734) Whatever others might say of him, he knew he was yet far from it.
('94', 80, 4, 12, 164800) When one really reaches such a state, his very thought becomes charged with a power which transforms those around him.
('94', 80, 4, 13, 164919) But where was that power in him now?
('94', 80, 4, 14, 164956) He could only say that he was a common mortal, made of the same clay of which others were made, only ceaselessly striving to attain the lofty ideal which the Gita held before all mankind.
('94', 80, 4, 15, 165144) While speaking yesterday, I had quoted an English proverb.
('94', 80, 4, 16, 165203) It means the greater the sinner, the greater the saint he becomes if he really repents and decides to reform himself.
('94', 80, 4, 17, 165321) Bihar has committed a monstrous sin.
('94', 80, 4, 18, 165358) It must now make reparations of the same magnitude and become nobler.
('94', 80, 4, 19, 165428) Bihar is a land where the verses of the Ramayana are always on the lips of the people.
('94', 80, 4, 20, 165515) I have moved widely in Bihar and I know the people here very intimately.
('94', 80, 4, 21, 165588) They live a simple life and their voice ever rings with the music of the Ramayana.
('94', 80, 4, 22, 165671) Their misdeeds are of terrible proportions; but their capability for making reparations is also equally great.
('94', 80, 4, 23, 165782) I have been a witness to this.

('94', 87, 1, 2, 179893) 103. DISCUSSION WITH P. C. C. MEMBERS
('94', 87, 2, 3, 179931) PATNA, March 9, 1947
('94', 87, 3, 4, 179952) Gandhiji told them that the more he heard of the Government spokesman’s apologia, the more he felt the need for turning the searchlight inward.
('94', 87, 3, 5, 180096) He wondered if behind his earlier determination to stay on in Noakhali was not “sheer obstinacy” on his part.
('94', 87, 4, 6, 180206) ONE MEMBER: Tell us how we can wash off our sin.
('94', 87, 4, 7, 180255) What are your orders?
('94', 87, 5, 8, 180277) Gandhiji replied that he was ever averse to issuing orders.
('94', 87, 5, 9, 180337) In Noakhali he could not.
('94', 87, 5, 10, 180363) In Bihar he could but did not want to.
('94', 87, 5, 11, 180402) The very nature of the work precluded it.
('94', 87, 5, 12, 180444) What he wanted was to awaken their conscience and win their reasoned co operation.
('94', 87, 5, 13, 180527) Since the advent of power, Congressmen had forgotten the path of duty.
('94', 87, 5, 14, 180598) In a way Muslims had come to believe Jinnah’s charge that the Congress did not belong to all, that the Muslims that were with the Congress were there as mere puppets of the Congress with an axe to grind to the detriment and ruin of Islam.
('94', 87, 5, 15, 180837) If the Hindus were sincere and brave, even the few Muslims that were with them could give the lie to that calumny and enable the Muslim masses to see that they were being misled, and perhaps save them from being so misled.
('94', 87, 6, 16, 181060) He had served Bihar before.
('94', 87, 6, 17, 181088) He had now come to them on what might be his last pilgrimage.
('94', 87, 6, 18, 181150) If he died striving there, he would have done his duty.
('94', 87, 6, 19, 181206) All things hung on truth, courage and knowledge.
('94', 87, 6, 20, 181255) If none of these virtues was there, the future was dark indeed for Bihar and for India.
('94', 87, 6, 21, 181343) A Congressmen got up to say that some Congressmen had taken part in the riot.
('94', 87, 6, 22, 181421) He was interrupted by another Congressman who emphatically declared that no Congressman had taken any part in the riot.
('94', 87, 6, 23, 181541) Gandhiji felt hurt.
('94', 87, 6, 24, 181561) The gentleman, he cut in, did not seem to know what he was talking about.
('94', 87, 6, 25, 181635) Even their own colleagues had admitted that some Congressmen had taken part [in the riot].
('94', 87, 6, 26, 181726) If their confession was half hearted they would not gain anything by it.
('94', 87, 6, 27, 181799) He had said enough.
('94', 87, 6, 28, 181819) They were all responsible people.
('94', 87, 6, 29, 181853) They should search their hearts.
('94', 87, 7, 30, 181886) The Chief Minister explained the genesis of the trouble and how his Government had tried to do all they could before, during and after the outbreak.

('94', 88, 3, 12, 183482) 104. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('94', 88, 4, 13, 183514) PATNA, March 9, 1947
('94', 88, 5, 14, 183535) It is good that I have one day of silence in the week.
('94', 88, 5, 15, 183590) How beautiful it would be if everyone could spend at least a few hours in the day in silent introspection if it were not possible for them to spend a whole day in complete silence.
('94', 88, 5, 16, 183771) If people were accustomed to such spiritual exercise, then their hands could never have been stained by deeds which have actually taken place in Bihar.
('94', 88, 5, 17, 183923) But this is not the occasion for dilating upon the benefits of the practice of silence.
('94', 88, 5, 18, 184011) Today I wish to indicate in brief the duty of those who did not personally participate in the shameful killings which took place in this province.
('94', 88, 5, 19, 184158) Their first duty is to purify their own thoughts.
('94', 88, 5, 20, 184208) When thoughts are not pure, one’s actions can never be purified.
('94', 88, 5, 21, 184273) Pure action can never come from imitation.
('94', 88, 5, 22, 184316) If one tries to become good by merely imitating the good conduct of others, such conduct never succeeds in radiating any influence upon others; because it is after all not the true stuff.
('94', 88, 5, 23, 184504) But one whose heart has become really pure along with his actions, can at once sense the true character of the thoughts which influence the behaviour of his neighbours.
('94', 88, 5, 24, 184673) When thoughts and actions have both become pure there can be no repetition of the deeds which have marred the fair face of Bihar.
('94', 88, 5, 25, 184803) But the world never progresses in a straight line.
('94', 88, 5, 26, 184854) The thoughts and actions of men never follow a parallel and uniform course.
('94', 88, 5, 27, 184930) For all men these two can never be completely purified at any single point of time.
('94', 88, 5, 28, 185014) Therefore, I would wish to indicate this evening only that ideal

('94', 89, 1, 2, 185189) of duty, which the workers should keep before themselves.

('94', 93, 1, 2, 191196) 111. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('94', 93, 2, 3, 191228) PATNA, March 10, 1947
('94', 93, 3, 4, 191250) As the audience took some time to settle down during this evening’s prayer, Gandhiji remarked at the beginning of his address that it would be difficult for him to tell them all that he wanted to if they continued to behave in that manner.
('94', 93, 3, 5, 191490) He expected that they had come to the prayer ground with an earnest desire to pray and then do the work of God, not for mere sight seeing.
('94', 93, 3, 6, 191629) I have been accused of utilizing the prayer meetings for the propagation of my political ideas.
('94', 93, 3, 7, 191725) My detractors will continue to criticize me and those who have made it a habit to abuse me will continue to indulge in their pastime.
('94', 93, 3, 8, 191859) I speak of political matters in a religious spirit.
('94', 93, 3, 9, 191911) A person who leads a religious life cannot divide it in to different compartments.
('94', 93, 3, 10, 191994) As unscrupulous person who accumulates huge wealth through fraud and deceit, and thinks that he can wash off his sins by chanting the name of God at home, is deceiving himself.
('94', 93, 3, 11, 192171) God is not such a simpleton.
('94', 93, 4, 12, 192200) Indeed, it might even be said, continued Gandhiji that the Law which held together the universe was indistinguishable from the Law maker.
('94', 93, 4, 13, 192338) Speaking in human language, one might even go so far as to say that God Himself was subject to the wheel of the Law.
('94', 93, 4, 14, 192455) We were used to the saying that “the king can do no wrong”.
('94', 93, 4, 15, 192515) But in God’s universe even such a distinction was hardly permissible.
('94', 93, 4, 16, 192585) One could only say that ‘there could be no wrong in the Law, for the Law and the Law maker were one and the same’.
('94', 93, 4, 17, 192700) There was no scope for even the least little blade of grass to be free from the operation of God’s laws.
('94', 93, 4, 18, 192805) God is Himself the Law and the Law giver.
('94', 93, 4, 19, 192847) He does not transgress the Law laid down by Himself nor does He allow others to transgress it.
('94', 93, 4, 20, 192942) You should understand that in our prayers we do not merely remember him but also undertake to do His work.
('94', 93, 4, 21, 193049) If you realize this, then the meaning of my words will be easy to grasp.
('94', 93, 4, 22, 193122) A friend has written to me a frank and honest letter and that is why I like it.
('94', 93, 4, 23, 193202) He wonders why I cannot see that the quarrel between Hindus and Muslims is not on account of religious differences but is essentially political in origin.
('94', 93, 4, 24, 193357) The Hindus want a united India.
('94', 93, 4, 25, 193389) The Muslims want Pakistan so that Muslims will rule in Pakistan and Hindus in Hindustan.
('94', 93, 4, 26, 193478) I really do not understand its implications.
('94', 93, 4, 27, 193523) One thing is very clear.
('94', 93, 4, 28, 193548) Religious or political differences should not lead to
('94', 93, 5, 29, 193602) 1 The Urdu version has been collated with the report in Harijan published under “Gandhiji’s Bihar Tour Diary”.
('94', 94, 0, 1, 193713) VOL. 94: 17 FEBRUARY , 1947 29, APRIL, 1947. 95
('94', 94, 1, 2, 193761) a total war.
('94', 94, 2, 3, 193774) But what he wanted to impress upon the audience was that supposing it were only a so called political struggle, did it mean that all rules of decency and morals should be thrown to the winds?
('94', 94, 2, 4, 193966) When human conflicts are divorced from ethical considerations, the road can only lead to the use of the atom bomb where every trace of humanity is held completely in abeyance.
('94', 94, 2, 5, 194142) It is wrong to imagine that, in political warfare, one could slaughter men, women and children, innocent and guilty alike, without compunction.
('94', 94, 2, 6, 194286) This is sheer brutality.
('94', 94, 2, 7, 194311) Will forty crores of human beings descend to the level of beasts?
('94', 94, 2, 8, 194377) Will such brutality secure us freedom?
('94', 94, 2, 9, 194416) This is absolutely impossible.
('94', 94, 2, 10, 194447) We do not know what is actually happening in the Punjab.
('94', 94, 2, 11, 194504) As long as we do not get full and reliable reports, let us hope that they have not descended to the beastly level of slaughtering innocent women and children.
('94', 94, 2, 12, 194663) But even at present we must admit that brutality is very much in evidence in the Punjab.
('94', 94, 2, 13, 194752) But to what extent, will be known later on.
('94', 94, 2, 14, 194796) Brutality can neither secure Pakistan nor preserve India.
('94', 94, 2, 15, 194854) It will destroy both Pakistan and India, leaving abject slavery behind.
('94', 94, 2, 16, 194926) I used to regard Punjabis as a brave people.
('94', 94, 2, 17, 194971) I can no longer regard them as such.
('94', 94, 2, 18, 195008) Those who are burning houses, looting properties and slaughtering the innocent, do not even know why they are perpetrating these crimes and atrocities.
('94', 94, 2, 19, 195160) In a regular war both the sides know what they are fighting for.
('94', 94, 2, 20, 195225) We are all slaves and our civil war will harm only ourselves.
('94', 94, 2, 21, 195287) We should realize the teachings of our religions and act according to them.
('94', 94, 2, 22, 195363) Our politics also should be consistent with our religion.
('94', 94, 3, 23, 195421) You should contribute generously for the relief of Muslims.
('94', 94, 3, 24, 195481) I shall stand up myself and collect the money.
('94', 94, 3, 25, 195528) If you ask me whether Muslims in Noakhali contributed funds for the sake of Hindus, I have to confess that I did not get much.
('94', 94, 3, 26, 195655) The reason is I am now looked upon as an enemy by the majority of the Muslims.
('94', 94, 3, 27, 195734) Even then, some Muslims and Christians in Comilla had contributed more than Rs. 800 along with a box containing vermilion and conch shell [bangles] for distribution among women who had been forcibly deprived of these auspicious symbols.
('94', 94, 4, 28, 195971) Gandhijike Dukhe Dilki Pukar—I, pp.

('94', 97, 4, 9, 199649) PATNA, March 11, 1947
('94', 97, 5, 10, 199671) Gandhiji began his address by saying that that was perhaps his last evening prayer for the time being in the city of Patna, because his tour was going to begin on the following day.
('94', 97, 5, 11, 199853) For the next few days, he would tour with the city as the centre and return to it every night for rest, the prayers being naturally held elsewhere.
('94', 97, 5, 12, 200001) He expected, however, that the spirit in which the previous evening’s contributions to the fund for the Muslim sufferers had been made would continue unabated.
('94', 97, 5, 13, 200161) The collections had amounted to nearly Rs. 2,000, besides some ornaments which yet remained to be auctioned.
('94', 97, 5, 14, 200270) He was glad that women had given their ornaments, and he reminded them in this connection that the true ornament of woman was a pure heart, the place of which could never be taken by any physical adornment.
('94', 97, 5, 15, 200477) A friend said to me today that what the Hindus had done was no doubt very wrong, but that they had acted under great provocation.
('94', 97, 5, 16, 200607) How could they remain peaceful after such incitement and provocation?
('94', 97, 5, 17, 200677) Well, we should not try to minimize our guilt.
('94', 97, 5, 18, 200724) The above argument would mean that if someone abuses or beats you, you will also return the abuse and hit back.
('94', 97, 5, 19, 200836) Is it good to do the very thing which angers you?
('94', 97, 5, 20, 200886) You in your turn will provoke further anger.
('94', 97, 5, 21, 200931) The world has reached the stage of atomic warfare in returning violence for violence.
('94', 97, 5, 22, 201017) Let us pray to God that He may save us from this atom bomb mentality.
('94', 97, 5, 23, 201087) I have been persuading everyone to observe silence in reply to abuse or violence.
('94', 97, 5, 24, 201169) The whole world tries to suppress the coward.
('94', 97, 5, 25, 201215) Even God does not help the coward.
('94', 97, 5, 26, 201250) He says, ‘A person who is afraid of anyone except me, lacks faith in me.’ The brave man who has learnt the lesson of non violence does not return abuse for abuse, nor does he slaughter innocent children and women under any provocation.

('94', 98, 0, 1, 201598) VOL. 94: 17 FEBRUARY , 1947 29, APRIL, 1947. 99
('94', 98, 1, 2, 201646) If I am starving and you feed me, the contentment in my eyes will brighten your face too.
('94', 98, 1, 3, 201736) But take another instance.
('94', 98, 1, 4, 201763) Suppose I am starving and demand food from you by abusing you.
('94', 98, 1, 5, 201826) You will drive me away, saying: ‘Go and starve yourself to death.’ My abuses will not get me food.
('94', 98, 1, 6, 201925) They will, however, make me feel that I am a brave man.

('94', 98, 1, 8, 202104) I will say, ‘You may deny me food if I abuse you; but why did you beat me?’ The next day I shall gather a few friends and retaliate.
('94', 98, 1, 9, 202237) Or, if you manage to kill me, it will create among my relations and friends a feeling of revenge against you.
('94', 98, 1, 10, 202347) This will aggravate the quarrel.
('94', 98, 1, 11, 202380) I look upon all this as cowardice.
('94', 98, 1, 12, 202415) Even if the Muslims had incited the Hindus, they should have remained peaceful.
('94', 98, 2, 13, 202495) An evil returned by another evil only succeeded in multiplying it, instead of reducing it.
('94', 98, 2, 14, 202586) It was a universal law, he said, that violence could never be quenched by superior violence but only by non violence or non violent resistance.
('94', 98, 2, 15, 202730) But the true meaning of non violent resistance had often been misunderstood or even distorted.
('94', 98, 2, 16, 202825) It never implied that a non violent man should bend before the violence of an aggressor.
('94', 98, 2, 17, 202914) While not returning the latter’s violence by violence, he should refuse to submit to the latter’s illegitimate demand even to the point of death.
('94', 98, 2, 18, 203060) That was the true meaning of non violent resistance.
('94', 98, 2, 19, 203113) I shall now discuss Pakistan.
('94', 98, 2, 20, 203143) Jinnah Saheb is my friend.
('94', 98, 2, 21, 203170) I have gone to his house many a time.
('94', 98, 2, 22, 203208) If Jinnah Saheb says to me: ‘Concede Pakistan or I will kill you,’ I will reply: ‘You may kill me if you like; but if you want Pakistan, you should first explain it to me.
('94', 98, 2, 23, 203380) If you convince me that Pakistan is a worthy ideal and Hindus are maligning it for no reason, I shall proclaim to the Hindus from the house tops that you should get Pakistan.’
('94', 98, 3, 24, 203556) But if the demand was backed by force, then the only course open to the non violent man was to offer non violent resistance against it as long as he was not convinced of its justice.
('94', 98, 3, 25, 203739) One was not to return violence by violence but neutralize it by withholding one’s hand and, at the same time, refusing to submit to the demand.
('94', 98, 3, 26, 203883) This was the only civilized way of getting on in the world.
('94', 98, 3, 27, 203943) Any other course could only lead to a race for armaments interspersed by periods of peace brought about by exhaustion, when preparations would be going on for violence of a superior order.
('94', 98, 3, 28, 204132) Peace through superior violence inevitably led to the atom bomb and all that it stood for.
('94', 98, 3, 29, 204223) It was the complete negation of non violence and of democracy which was not possible without the former.
('94', 98, 4, 30, 204328) The non violent resistance described above required courage of a superior order to that needed in violent warfare.
('94', 98, 4, 31, 204443) Forgiveness was the quality of the brave, not of the cowardly.
('94', 98, 4, 32, 204506) Gandhiji here related a story from the Mahabharata: one of the Pandava

('94', 99, 1, 4, 204898) It was this type of forbearance and courage which Gandhiji wished every Indian to develop, whether he was a Hindu, Mussalman, Christian, Parsi or Sikh.
('94', 99, 1, 5, 205050) That alone could rescue them from their present fallen condition.

('94', 99, 1, 18, 206122) The weapon of non violence is mightier than the weapon of violence.

('94', 101, 2, 3, 208525) PATNA, March 12, 1947
('94', 101, 3, 4, 208547) Gandhiji referred, in the beginning of his address, to the decision of the British Government to quit India.
('94', 101, 3, 5, 208656) The British were a nation with a strong sense of reality: and when they realized that it did not pay to rule, they did not hesitate to withdraw their power over a country.
('94', 101, 3, 6, 208828) This had been the course of British history in the past.
('94', 101, 3, 7, 208885) If the British were going, as they surely were, what should be the duty of Indians at the same time, asked Gandhiji.
('94', 101, 3, 8, 209002) Were we to return blow for blow among ourselves, and thus perpetuate our slavery, only to tear up our motherland, in the end, into bits, which went by the name of Hindustan and Pakistan, Brahministan and Achhutistan?
('94', 101, 3, 9, 209219) What greater madness could there be than what had taken place in Bengal and Bihar, or what was taking place in the Punjab or the Frontier Province?
('94', 101, 3, 10, 209367) Today I visited a village where Hindus had caused great damage.
('94', 101, 3, 11, 209431) An old Muslim showed me his own house and those of his relations with broken door frames where bricks were removed from the door sill.
('94', 101, 3, 12, 209566) I was shocked and shaken to see that the Hindus had caused these depredations.
('94', 101, 3, 13, 209645) I had wept when I saw the ruins caused by Muslims in Noakhali.
('94', 101, 3, 14, 209708) Today also I might have wept.
('94', 101, 3, 15, 209738) But my tears cannot render any succour to the sufferers.
('94', 101, 3, 16, 209795) What I witnessed today does not behove human beings.
('94', 101, 3, 17, 209848) We are all responsible for this vandalism so close to the city of Patna.
('94', 101, 3, 18, 209921) Even if you did not participate personally in the loot, you cannot escape the charge of abett ing the marauders.
('94', 101, 3, 19, 210034) A mosque was also damaged in the village Kumarahar.
('94', 101, 3, 20, 210086) This also I consider to be a devilish deed.
('94', 101, 3, 21, 210130) It is no justification to argue that the Hindus damaged the mosque because the Muslims were desecrating the temples.
('94', 101, 3, 22, 210247) Hindus worship idols, while the Muslims do not.
('94', 101, 3, 23, 210295) But every human being does worship something or other.
('94', 101, 3, 24, 210350) God resides everywhere; not only in the Bible and the Koran, in a mosque or a temple, but in the nose, ear, nail or even a single hair of the body of man.
('94', 101, 3, 25, 210505) I have been taught ever since my childhood that God resides everywhere.
('94', 101, 3, 26, 210577) He is subtler than the air.
('94', 101, 3, 27, 210605) It is one and the same thing whether one worships Him in a mosque, a temple or a church.
('94', 101, 3, 28, 210694) I am as much an idol worshipper as an idolbreaker.
('94', 101, 3, 29, 210745) Still when I go to a temple, I am happy if I find it neat and clean.
('94', 101, 3, 30, 210814) Those who desecrated the mosque were not men but devils; because mosques, temples or churches are all houses of the Lord.

('94', 113, 5, 25, 236715) If some organization wants to render relief in its own manner, it will not be justified in expecting assistance from the Government.
('94', 113, 5, 26, 236848) This work has to be done either by the Government itself or in a manner approved by the Government.

('94', 118, 1, 2, 245501) 134. DISCUSSION WITH SWAMI ANAND AND
('94', 118, 2, 3, 245538) KEDAR NATH [March 15/16, 1947] 1
('94', 118, 3, 4, 245571) QUESTION : Why did you not, according to your wont, take your co workers into confidence and carry them with you before embarking on this novel practice 2 ?
('94', 118, 3, 5, 245728) Why this secrecy ?
('94', 118, 4, 6, 245747) GANDHIJI : No secrecy was intended.
('94', 118, 4, 7, 245783) Everything was fortuitous.
('94', 118, 4, 8, 245810) Previous consultation with friends was ruled out by the very nature of the thing.
('94', 118, 4, 9, 245892) Besides, I hold that previous consent was unnecessary.
('94', 118, 4, 10, 245947) At the same time I should have insisted on ventilating the matter thoroughly at the very start.
('94', 118, 4, 11, 246043) If I had only done that, much of the present trouble and commotion would have been avoided.
('94', 118, 4, 12, 246135) The omission was a serious flaw.
('94', 118, 4, 13, 246168) I was asking myself as to what would be an appropriate penance for it when Thakkar Bapa came 3. You know the rest of the story.
('94', 118, 5, 14, 246296) Q. The irreparable harm, if you weaken the foundation of the moral order on which society rests and which has been built up by long and painful discipline, is obvious.
('94', 118, 5, 15, 246464) But no corresponding gain is apparent to us to justify a break with established tradition.
('94', 118, 5, 16, 246555) What is your defence ?
('94', 118, 5, 17, 246578) We are not out to humiliate you or to score a victory over you.
('94', 118, 5, 18, 246642) We only wish to understand.
('94', 118, 6, 19, 246670) G. No moral progress or reform is possible if one is not prepared to get out of the rut of orthodox tradition.
('94', 118, 6, 20, 246781) By allowing ourselves to be cribbed by castiron social conventions, we have lost.
('94', 118, 6, 21, 246863) The orthodox conception of the ninefold wall of protection in regard to brahmacharya is in my opinion inadequate and defective.
('94', 118, 6, 22, 246991) I have never accepted it for myself.
('94', 118, 6, 23, 247028) In my opinion even striving after the true brahmacharya is not possible by keeping behind it.
('94', 118, 6, 24, 247122) For 20 years I was in closest touch with the West in South Africa.
('94', 118, 6, 25, 247189) I have known the writings on sex by eminent writers like Havelock Ellis and Bertrand Russell and their theories.
('94', 118, 6, 26, 247302) They are all thinkers of eminence, integrity
('94', 118, 7, 27, 247347) 1 According to My Days with Gandhi, Swami Anand and Kedar Nath came to Bihar on March 14, 1947. Their discussion was entirely private and continued the next two days.

('94', 119, 1, 2, 247848) and experience.
('94', 119, 1, 3, 247864) They have suffered for their convictions and for giving expression to the same.
('94', 119, 1, 4, 247944) While totally repudiating institutions like marriage, etc., and the current code of morals—and there I disagree with them—they are firm believers in the possibility and desirability of purity in life independently of those institutions and usages.
('94', 119, 1, 5, 248192) I have come across men and women in the West who lead pure lives although they do not accept or observe the current usages and social conventions.
('94', 119, 1, 6, 248339) My research runs somewhat in that direction.
('94', 119, 1, 7, 248384) If you admit the necessity and desirability of reform, of discarding the old, wherever necessary, and building a new system of ethics and morals suited to the present age, then the question of seeking the permission of others or convincing them does not arise.
('94', 119, 1, 8, 248645) A reformer cannot afford to wait till others are converted; he must take the lead and venture forth alone even in the teeth of universal opposition.
('94', 119, 1, 9, 248794) I want to test, enlarge and revise the current definition of brahmacharya, by which you swear, in the light of my observation, study and experience.
('94', 119, 1, 10, 248943) Therefore, whenever an opportunity presents itself I do not evade it or run away from it.
('94', 119, 1, 11, 249033) On the contrary, I deem it my duty—dharma—to meet it squarely in the face and find out where it leads to and where I stand.
('94', 119, 1, 12, 249157) To avoid the contact of a woman or to run away from it out of fear, I regard as unbecoming of an aspirant after true brahmacharya.
('94', 119, 1, 13, 249288) I have never tried to cultivate or seek sex contact for carnal satisfaction.
('94', 119, 1, 14, 249365) I do not claim to have completely eradicated the sex feeling in me.
('94', 119, 1, 15, 249433) But it is my claim that I can keep it under control.
('94', 119, 2, 16, 249486) Q. We are not aware of your ever having put before the people at large these ideas of yours.
('94', 119, 2, 17, 249579) On the contrary we have all along known you to have put before the public ideas with which we are familiar, and which we have associated with your striving.
('94', 119, 2, 18, 249736) What is the explanation ?
('94', 119, 3, 19, 249762) G. Even today, so far as the people in general are concerned, I am putting before them for practice what you call my old ideas.
('94', 119, 3, 20, 249890) At the same time, for myself, as I have said, I have been deeply influenced by modern thought.
('94', 119, 3, 21, 249985) Even amongst us there is the Tantra school which has influenced Western savants like Justice Sir John Woodroffe.
('94', 119, 3, 22, 250098) I read his works in Yeravada prison.
('94', 119, 3, 23, 250135) You have all been brought up in the orthodox tradition.
('94', 119, 3, 24, 250191) According to my definition, you cannot be regarded as true brahmacharis.
('94', 119, 3, 25, 250264) You are off and on
('94', 120, 0, 1, 250283) VOL. 94 : 17 FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947 121
('94', 120, 1, 2, 250330) falling ill; you suffer from all sorts of bodily ailments.
('94', 120, 1, 3, 250389) I claim that I represent true brahmacharya better than any of you.
('94', 120, 1, 4, 250456) You do not seem to regard a lapse in respect of truth, nonviolence, nonstealing, etc., to be so serious a matter.
('94', 120, 1, 5, 250570) But a fancied breach in respect of brahmacharya, i.e., relation between man and woman, upsets you completely.
('94', 120, 1, 6, 250680) I regard this conception of brahmacharya as narrow, hidebound and retrograde.
('94', 120, 1, 7, 250758) To me truth, ahimsa and brahmacharya are all ideals of equal importance.
('94', 120, 1, 8, 250831) They all call for an equal measure of striving on our part, and lapse in respect of any of them is to me a matter of equal concern.
('94', 120, 1, 9, 250963) I maintain that my conduct in no way constitutes a departure from the true ideal of brahmacharya.
('94', 120, 1, 10, 251061) As against it, brahmacharya which reduces itself to a system of prescriptive do’s and don’ts and which is in vogue amongst us today has a baneful effect upon society; it has lowered the ideal and robbed it of its true content.
('94', 120, 1, 11, 251288) I deem it my highest duty to put these prescriptive conventions and taboos in their proper place and to release the ideal from the fetters that have been put upon it.
('94', 120, 2, 12, 251455) Q. One last question.
('94', 120, 2, 13, 251477) If your attitude and practice constitutes such an advance in the cultivation of true selfrestraint, why does not its beneficial effect show in your surroundings ?
('94', 120, 2, 14, 251640) Why do we find so much disquiet and unhappiness around you ?
('94', 120, 2, 15, 251701) Why are your companions emotionally unhinged ?
('94', 120, 3, 16, 251748) G. I know well the shortcomings as well as virtues of my companions.
('94', 120, 3, 17, 251817) You do not know their other side.
('94', 120, 3, 18, 251851) You jump to hasty conclusions from superficial observation, which is unbecoming in a striver after truth.
('94', 120, 3, 19, 251957) I am not so lost as you seem to think.
('94', 120, 3, 20, 251996) I can only ask you to have faith in me.
('94', 120, 3, 21, 252036) I cannot give up at your bidding what to me is a matter of deep conviction.
('94', 120, 3, 22, 252112) I am sorry, I am helpless.
('94', 120, 4, 23, 252139) Q. We cannot say we have been convinced.
('94', 120, 4, 24, 252180) We feel unhappy.
('94', 120, 4, 25, 252197) We cannot leave the matter here.
('94', 120, 4, 26, 252230) We shall continue to strive with you.
('94', 120, 4, 27, 252268) Should you again feel prompted to go against the established rules, just think of your sorrowing friends.
('94', 120, 5, 28, 252374) G. I know.
('94', 120, 5, 29, 252385) But what can I do when I feel impelled by duty ?
('94', 120, 5, 30, 252434) I can imagine circumstances when I may feel it my clear duty to go against the established rules.
('94', 120, 5, 31, 252532) In such circumstances I cannot allow myself to be bound down by any commitment whatsoever.

('94', 122, 6, 12, 254871) 137. LETTER TO T. R. VENKATARAMA SASTRI
('94', 122, 7, 13, 254911) PATNA , March 16, 1947
('94', 122, 8, 14, 254934) DEAR VENKATARAMA SASTRI, I have your precious letter about the proposed Sastriar Memorial 1. Let me tell you that I have not identified myself with the Malaviyaji Memorial although I am deeply interested in the doings of the Kashi Vishwavidyalaya.
('94', 122, 8, 15, 255182) As for the proposal, whilst I am deeply concerned with everything about Sastriar I wonder if it is necessary to have an institution in memory of the deceased for political education.
('94', 122, 8, 16, 255365) Isn’t that function performed by the Servants of India Society for which he gave his life ?
('94', 122, 8, 17, 255457) Political education is today being given by so many
('94', 122, 9, 18, 255509) 1 In memory of V. S. Srinivasa Sastri who had died on April 17, 1946
('94', 123, 0, 1, 255578) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 124
('94', 123, 1, 2, 255620) parties in which I may mention the Socialist Party and the Communist Party.
('94', 123, 1, 3, 255696) However much one may differ from their way of thinking, it is not possible to withhold admiration from them for drawing to their fold people of learning, industry and self sacrifice.
('94', 123, 1, 4, 255879) I intensely dislike destructive criticism unless it is accompanied at the same time with constructive suggestions.
('94', 123, 1, 5, 255994) I claim no exemption for my criticism.
('94', 123, 1, 6, 256033) Strictly speaking mine is no criticism.
('94', 123, 1, 7, 256073) I have simply thrown out a thought for your consideration.
('94', 123, 1, 8, 256132) As at present equipped I would say that it might be a good thing to make an appeal for sustaining and expanding Sastriar’s last and best beloved institution.
('94', 123, 1, 9, 256290) That it needs expansion I have no doubt.
('94', 123, 1, 10, 256331) I haven’t thought out how.
('94', 123, 1, 11, 256358) I will add however that the donors should earmark their donations for the object to be particularized in the general appeal.
('94', 123, 1, 12, 256483) At this juncture when everything is in the meltingpot and institutions are undergoing rapid transformation it may be necessary to take the precaution.
('94', 123, 1, 13, 256634) If you think that my suggestion is worthy of consideration you will have to consult the present President 1 of the Society.
('94', 123, 1, 14, 256758) The fact that I have taken deep interest in your project should not be taken to mean that I shall identify myself with that or any other project.
('94', 123, 1, 15, 256904) My views about memorials have undergone change for some years and experience is daily strengthening them.
('94', 123, 1, 16, 257010) But this is not for engaging you in considering them.
('94', 123, 2, 17, 257064) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI SHRI T. R. VENKATARAMA SASTRI “KAUSTUBHA” EDWARD ELLIOTS ROAD MYLAPORE MADRAS

('94', 125, 1, 2, 258413) 140. ADVICE TO MUSLIM REFUGEES 1
('94', 125, 2, 3, 258446) PATNA , Sunday, March 16, 1947
('94', 125, 3, 4, 258477) You have my sympathy in your misery.
('94', 125, 3, 5, 258514) What has happened should never have happened.
('94', 125, 3, 6, 258560) But I believe that everything is futile unless there is a change of heart.
('94', 125, 3, 7, 258635) I would suggest that you should go to Noakhali.
('94', 125, 3, 8, 258683) Go there and find out for yourself if the Hindus have not been oppressed.
('94', 125, 3, 9, 258757) If you are convinced about it, engage yourselves in relief work and service in that place.
('94', 125, 3, 10, 258848) Impress upon the minority that they are your brethren, that they cannot leave the country, and that they may do so only over your dead bodies.
('94', 125, 3, 11, 258991) Tell even the oppressors — let me say they are the members of the [Muslim] League — that such tyranny would neither bring any benefit to their party nor would it protect it in any way.
('94', 125, 3, 12, 259176) And if the tyrants still continue to oppress, you must lay down your lives to protect your brethren.
('94', 125, 3, 13, 259277) You must courageously tell them that they should first strike you before striking the innocent.
('94', 125, 3, 14, 259373) Even if there is one such person among you, your fame would be matchless in all the world and God would shower flowers over you, and that fragrance would spread in the entire country.
('94', 125, 3, 15, 259557) I am merely showing you your duty, since you have come to seek my advice.
('94', 125, 3, 16, 259631) I would be the happiest man to see you rising high and to see Pakistan becoming really pak 2. And, if you do this people would come to you to learn the lessons of nonviolence and love.
('94', 125, 3, 17, 259816) [From Gujarati]
('94', 125, 4, 18, 259832) Biharni Komi Agman, p.

('94', 126, 1, 2, 260022) 141. ADVICE TO MUSLIM WOMEN 1
('94', 126, 2, 3, 260052) PATNA , Sunday, March 16, 1947 You should have faith in God.
('94', 126, 2, 4, 260113) He is the one who looks after everyone.
('94', 126, 2, 5, 260153) I am only striving [to do my duty].
('94', 126, 2, 6, 260189) You mix with the Hindu women.
('94', 126, 2, 7, 260219) Tell the children in your families things which promote love [among the two communities].
('94', 126, 2, 8, 260309) What you can do, men can never do.
('94', 126, 2, 9, 260344) Tell your husband, son or father, or whoever is there, that he should rush to the rescue of the Hindus if they are terrorized by the Muslims anywhere in the country.
('94', 126, 2, 10, 260510) Protect the Hindu women and inspire confidence in them that they are your own sisters.
('94', 126, 2, 11, 260597) I have described women as the very embodiment of nonviolence.
('94', 126, 2, 12, 260659) God has given to woman a loving heart which man does not possess.
('94', 126, 2, 13, 260725) You should put it to good use.
('94', 126, 2, 14, 260756) It is as clear to me as daylight that as long as women do not acquire qualities of refinement and do not realize their duty, the country can make no progress.
('94', 126, 2, 15, 260915) Women from numerous such Muslim families have come to me.
('94', 126, 2, 16, 260973) So many of them are just like daughters to me.
('94', 126, 2, 17, 261020) One of them is right in Noakhali.
('94', 126, 2, 18, 261054) Amtussalaam is just skin and bones, but she is putting up a brave fight.
('94', 126, 2, 19, 261127) She undertook a number of fasts.
('94', 126, 2, 20, 261160) Raihana who comes from the family of Abbas Tyabji is just as brave.
('94', 126, 2, 21, 261228) She is a devotee of Krishna.
('94', 126, 2, 22, 261257) She reads the Gita and the Koran together.
('94', 126, 2, 23, 261300) She understands the meaning of the Gita as much as she understands the meaning of the Koran.
('94', 126, 2, 24, 261393) I believe that she has more Hindus than Muslims among her friends.
('94', 126, 2, 25, 261460) There are many girls who have given up distinctions of caste and creed.
('94', 126, 2, 26, 261532) My advice to you is that you should forget distinctions of caste and community if you want to be happy.
('94', 126, 2, 27, 261636) It is one God who has endowed us with human life.
('94', 126, 2, 28, 261686) We are all human beings, all men and women belonging to the same country.
('94', 126, 2, 29, 261760) Let us justify our religion as human beings.
('94', 126, 2, 30, 261805) [From Gujarati]
('94', 126, 3, 31, 261821) Biharni Komi Agman, p.
('94', 126, 4, 32, 261844) 1 The Muslim women came clad in burqas.
('94', 126, 4, 33, 261884) Gandhiji asked : “Why do you observe purdah from me ?
('94', 126, 4, 34, 261938) Women do not observe it with me.
('94', 126, 4, 35, 261971) The real purdah should be of the heart.” The women then removed their burqas.

('94', 128, 3, 9, 264282) 144. LETTER TO SIR HUGH DOW
('94', 128, 4, 10, 264310) PATNA , March 17, 1947
('94', 128, 5, 11, 264333) DEAR FRIEND, I was so struck by your reference (strange for a bureaucrat) to individual conduct that I referred to it on Saturday at my after prayer speech.
('94', 128, 6, 12, 264490) Yesterday evening I met your Ministers and gave them the purport of our talk of last Saturday.
('94', 128, 6, 13, 264585) I told them that 1. you considered them to be dilatory about placating the Muslims who were so much the injured party; 2. permanent officials interpreted this to mean that the Ministers did not want them to be prompt in taking energetic action to restore confidence among the Muslims; 3. the guilty ones were not properly dealt with; 4. the League demands were turned down not on merits but because they were League demands.
('94', 128, 6, 14, 265010) The Ministers present totally refuted all these imputations and the Chief Minister expressed considerable surprise.
('94', 128, 6, 15, 265126) The Chief Minister said that he and his colleagues had often differed from you on several questions including the minorities.
('94', 128, 6, 16, 265252) He added, however, that on behalf of himself and his colleagues he had given you the assurance that in their handling of the minority question they would readily accept your advice even though there were differences between you and them.
('94', 128, 6, 17, 265490) I am showing this to the Chief Minister to check up my version of what the Ministers had said.
('94', 128, 6, 18, 265585) My only reason for writing this is not to advertise differences between you and your Ministers but to remove misunderstandings and to assist, wherever I can, in promoting goodwill between the retiring British official world and the Indian politicians who are, and are
('94', 128, 7, 19, 265853) 1 Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 15 3 1947

('94', 129, 1, 4, 266110) But I shall await your promised note before I can pursue it fully.

('94', 130, 2, 16, 267894) I claim that except on one occasion I have not been a victim of passions and that is why I write the harsh words above.

('94', 133, 8, 13, 273445) MASAURHI, March 17, 1947
('94', 133, 9, 14, 273470) It is not necessary, perhaps, to tell you that I have undertaken this tour not for pleasure but out of sorrow.
('94', 133, 9, 15, 273581) I visit only those places where Muslims have suffered in some way or the other at the hands of Hindus.
('94', 133, 9, 16, 273684) Everywhere I appeal to Hindus to atone for their sins.
('94', 133, 10, 17, 273739) A large number of Hindus attacked a handful of Muslims and killed women and children.
('94', 133, 10, 18, 273825) This is not bravery but cowardice.
('94', 133, 10, 19, 273860) It is cowardly to kill a person even under an apprehension that he is likely to kill us.
('94', 133, 10, 20, 273949) We have to show true repentance for whatever has happened.
('94', 133, 10, 21, 274008) If a brother of ours commits a crime, we cannot escape the responsibility.
('94', 133, 10, 22, 274083) I include myself when I say “we”.
('94', 133, 10, 23, 274117) No one should think that he has committed no crime and this old man is unnecessarily implicating him.
('94', 133, 10, 24, 274219) When one man commits a crime, all mankind becomes responsible for it.
('94', 133, 10, 25, 274289) Hence even if a single Hindu has misbehaved here, all the Hindus will be put in the dock.
('94', 133, 11, 26, 274379) What the Muslims have done in Noakhali or what the Hindus

('94', 134, 1, 4, 275084) Such people have not understood me.

('94', 134, 1, 6, 275204) Those who have committed robbery, arson or murder should come to me and make a confession.
('94', 134, 1, 7, 275295) I am no police officer; nor have I come here to prosecute you.

('94', 134, 2, 13, 275842) Now, I pose this question before you.

('94', 134, 2, 16, 276062) One who attacks another person is a coward, but it would be an act of bravery to refuse to be provoked even in the face of an attack.
('94', 134, 2, 17, 276196) One should realize that if the aggressor commits a shameful act one should not oneself commit a similar act.
('94', 134, 2, 18, 276305) I know the people of Bihar very well and I have visited this province very often.
('94', 134, 2, 19, 276387) I had built great hopes on Bihar but this time the people here have dashed them to the ground.

('94', 134, 2, 22, 276649) A Hindu friend has said, “I agree that you should have fought with those Muslims who had provoked you; but what is the justification for thousands of Hindus killing innocent women and children?
('94', 134, 2, 23, 276843) Even if you had resorted to violence, you should have done it in a brave manner.” Muslims complain that the Provincial Government’s hands are also not clean and the Ministers participated in the atrocities committed on the Muslims.
('94', 134, 2, 24, 277075) It is difficult for me to believe this; I cannot also believe that the Chief Minister had a hand in this.
