('94', 135, 1, 2, 277223) 152. LETTER TO AMRIT KAUR
('94', 135, 2, 3, 277249) PATNA, March 18, 1947
('94', 135, 3, 4, 277271) AMRIT, I had your letter.
('94', 135, 3, 5, 277297) I wanted to write to you at once but never got the chance.
('94', 135, 3, 6, 277356) It is a very strenuous time I am having here.
('94', 135, 3, 7, 277402) But do not worry.
('94', 135, 3, 8, 277420) You remember those two notebooks containing rich treasures from the Bible and other Christian literature.
('94', 135, 3, 9, 277526) If they have not taught you and me to be anxious for nothing and nobody, they have taught nothing worth learning, for our faith in the living God is to be measured by the extent of freedom from anxiety of any kind whatsoever and full faith in God requires an accurate knowledge of His laws and corresponding obedience thereto.
('94', 135, 3, 10, 277853) This is the sum total of nature cure.
('94', 135, 3, 11, 277891) The supreme law, making others superfluous, is heart assimilation of Ramanama in every fibre of our being.
('94', 135, 3, 12, 277998) The truth of this is verified in everyday experience.
('94', 135, 3, 13, 278052) I note what you say about your suffering and about Dr. Jacob’s treatment.
('94', 135, 3, 14, 278126) I hope to be able to learn some day that you have shed all your illnesses.
('94', 135, 3, 15, 278201) Tell Shummy 1 that he belies the teaching of the Bible which among our company he seems to know best.
('94', 135, 3, 16, 278303) Sardar 2 must not have any swelling whatsoever.
('94', 135, 3, 17, 278351) But his obstinacy is very great.
('94', 135, 3, 18, 278384) I have asked you to pay me a brief visit.
('94', 135, 3, 19, 278426) You might be of some use in the work that is being done here.
('94', 135, 3, 20, 278488) That means your sparing a fortnight at the most.
('94', 135, 3, 21, 278537) But I do not want you to neglect the duty you have undertaken, of course with my full consent.
('94', 135, 3, 22, 278632) Who told you that I had consented to take some rest?
('94', 135, 3, 23, 278685) That rest must certainly come some day.
('94', 135, 3, 24, 278725) Meantime I am learning day by day, though little by little, that all work, without any the slightest trace of anxiety, is true and living rest.
('94', 135, 3, 25, 278869) Jajuji 3 has sent me a copy of your letter about the Secretaryship.
('94', 135, 3, 26, 278937) I want you to give me a full and accurate account of the big tragedy that is going on in the Punjab.
('94', 135, 3, 27, 279038) Surely you cannot be called “Her Highness” as Catlin calls
('94', 135, 4, 28, 279097) 1 Shumshere Singh, addressee’s brother 2 Vallabhbhai Patel 3 Shrikrishnadas Jaju, Secretary, A. I. S. A.
('94', 136, 0, 1, 279202) VOL. 94: 17 FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL 1947 137
('94', 136, 1, 2, 279247) Lastly about myself.
('94', 136, 1, 3, 279268) I had an affectionate but mournful visit from Nathji and Swami Anand.
('94', 136, 1, 4, 279338) I gave them as much time as I was capable of giving.
('94', 136, 1, 5, 279391) Our discussions were full, frank and cordial.
('94', 136, 1, 6, 279437) You will have no difficulty in accepting at its face value my statement that not one of our company knows the full value and implications of brahmacharya, and that among these ignoramuses I am the least ignorant and the most experienced.
('94', 136, 1, 7, 279675) With one solitary exception I have never looked upon a woman with a lustful eye.
('94', 136, 1, 8, 279756) I have touched perhaps thousands upon thousands.
('94', 136, 1, 9, 279805) But my touch has never carried the meaning of lustfulness.
('94', 136, 1, 10, 279864) I have lain with some naked, never with the intention of having any lustful satisfaction.
('94', 136, 1, 11, 279954) My touch has been for our mutual uplift.
('94', 136, 1, 12, 279995) I would like those who have felt otherwise, if there are any, truly to testify against me.
('94', 136, 1, 13, 280086) Even the one solitary instance referred to by me was never with the intention of despoiling her.
('94', 136, 1, 14, 280183) Nevertheless my confession stands that in that case my touch had lustfulness about it.
('94', 136, 1, 15, 280270) I was carried away in spite of myself and but for God’s intervention I might have become a wreck.
('94', 136, 1, 16, 280368) My meaning of brahmacharya is this: One who never has any lustful intention, who by constant attendance upon God has become proof against conscious or unconscious emissions, who is capable of lying naked with naked women, however beautiful they may be, without being in any manner whatsoever sexually excited.
('94', 136, 1, 17, 280678) Such a person should be incapable of lying, incapable of intending or doing harm to a single man or woman in the whole world, is free from anger and malice and detached in the sense of the Bhagavadgita.
('94', 136, 1, 18, 280881) Such a person is a full brahmachari.
('94', 136, 1, 19, 280918) Brahmachari literally means a person who is making daily and steady progress towards God and whose every act is done in pursuance of that end and no other.
('94', 136, 1, 20, 281074) You say K. 1 and N.2 had agreed to withdraw their boycott.
('94', 136, 1, 21, 281133) From the letters I have, such is not my impression.
('94', 136, 1, 22, 281185) Nor did I gather that impression from N[athji] and S[wami].

('94', 139, 6, 22, 286338) 157. DISCUSSION WITH MUSLIM REFUGEES
('94', 139, 7, 23, 286375) MASAURHI, March 18, 1947
('94', 139, 8, 24, 286400) REFUGEES: Please give us an assurance that our lives, property and honour
('94', 139, 9, 25, 286474) will be protected.
('94', 139, 10, 26, 286493) GANDHIJI: Efforts are being made in this direction.
('94', 139, 10, 27, 286545) I shall advise the Government to hold all the Hindus in a village responsible for any harm to its Muslim minority and to punish them strictly according to law.
('94', 139, 11, 28, 286705) R. Securities should be taken from gangsters and influential people in the
('94', 139, 12, 29, 286780) locality so that they may not foment riots again.
('94', 139, 13, 30, 286830) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('94', 139, 13, 31, 286857) 2 Most of the houses in Masaurhi were razed to the ground during the riots and all but 25 out of a population of 1,000 had fled from the village.
('94', 140, 0, 1, 287003) VOL. 94: 17 FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL 1947 141
('94', 140, 1, 2, 287048) G. Those persons who had led the riots should be held responsible for law and order in the locality to prevent recurrence of riots.
('94', 140, 1, 3, 287180) As it is not right to hold everyone responsible for the riots, it would not be right to punish everyone for the riots; nor would it be easy to do so.
('94', 140, 1, 4, 287330) But if you can recognize and prove anyone’s participation in the riots, the law will certainly punish him.
('94', 140, 2, 5, 287437) R. We should be issued licenses to possess arms for self protection.
('94', 140, 3, 6, 287506) G. It is strange that I am hearing the same arguments here which I used to hear in Noakhali.
('94', 140, 3, 7, 287599) I shall certainly oppose this.
('94', 140, 3, 8, 287630) I can never understand why some or all of you should be given arms.
('94', 140, 3, 9, 287698) This is not the way of creating an atmosphere of friendship.
('94', 140, 3, 10, 287759) I had told the Hindus in Noakhali that they could not live there nor could the local Government protect them if the entire Muslim population was hostile to them.
('94', 140, 3, 11, 287921) Should the Government kill 80 per cent of the population to protect them?
('94', 140, 3, 12, 287995) No government can do this today.
('94', 140, 3, 13, 288028) I would like to tell you that my ways are different.
('94', 140, 3, 14, 288081) I believe that a man should become brave but bravery consists not in killing but in getting killed and that too without hatred for the killer.
('94', 140, 3, 15, 288224) Muslims were no cowards, but they are terrified today and that too on account of us—this makes me hang my head in shame.
('94', 140, 3, 16, 288345) If my staying here has any meaning, you should shed your anxiety.
('94', 140, 3, 17, 288411) I shall not go away till you yourself ask me to go, and assure me that Hindus and Muslims are living like brothers again.
('94', 140, 4, 18, 288533) R. There should be some arrangement so that all Muslims can live together.
('94', 140, 5, 19, 288608) G. This talk of ‘pockets’ is not new to me.
('94', 140, 5, 20, 288652) As soon as I arrived in Bihar, I went to see the leader of the Muslim League, Barrister Abdul Aziz of Patna.
('94', 140, 5, 21, 288761) He explained to me everything.
('94', 140, 5, 22, 288792) Earlier I used to oppose the idea of ‘pockets’; but now I understand the logic behind the demand.
('94', 140, 5, 23, 288890) I can very well understand that one just cannot stay at a place where one’s relations and friends have been massacred.
('94', 140, 5, 24, 289009) Hence if people want to shift to villages where there is a large number of Muslims, they can migrate there with mutual consent.
('94', 140, 5, 25, 289137) I have advised the Government to build houses for displaced persons or give them funds for the purpose if they so choose.
('94', 140, 5, 26, 289259) If you demand, however, that the Government should provide you everything, it may not be in a position to do so because it would mean acquisition of some people’s lands.
('94', 140, 5, 27, 289429) And this would lead to all sorts of complications.
('94', 140, 5, 28, 289480) If there is any vacant piece of land and you can settle
('94', 141, 0, 1, 289536) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 142
('94', 141, 1, 2, 289578) there, you may certainly do so.
('94', 141, 1, 3, 289610) A big landlord from North Bihar was ready to take as many Muslims as would like to stay on his lands.
('94', 141, 1, 4, 289712) If you agree I shall write to him.
('94', 141, 2, 5, 289747) R. We should receive compensation for whatever we have lost.
('94', 141, 3, 6, 289808) G. Even the Government would go bankrupt if it agreed to this.
('94', 141, 3, 7, 289871) Some people claim they have lost lakhs, some others claim they have lost crores.
('94', 141, 3, 8, 289952) How can we evaluate the actual loss?
('94', 141, 3, 9, 289989) I think the Government would not be in a position to pay even onefourth of the claims.
('94', 141, 3, 10, 290076) It can only provide shelter or give money to enable people to stand on their own feet.
('94', 141, 3, 11, 290163) In Noakhali, many weavers and fishermen had practically nothing to support themselves.
('94', 141, 3, 12, 290250) There I had suggested that the local Government should advance them loans which could be repaid in easy instalments.
('94', 141, 3, 13, 290367) Money alone has no value.
('94', 141, 3, 14, 290393) You are all farmers, a hard working lot.
('94', 141, 3, 15, 290434) If you take courage in both hands, you will forget in no time what you have undergone.
('94', 141, 3, 16, 290521) Moreover a commission is being set up.
('94', 141, 3, 17, 290560) Its object is not only to record whatever has happened, but also to examine the steps that are being taken and to recommend measures for the future.
('94', 141, 4, 18, 290709) R. 50 per cent of us should be taken in the police force.
('94', 141, 5, 19, 290767) G. I am totally opposed to such demands.
('94', 141, 5, 20, 290808) I told Hindus in Noakhali: “I will not put in a word for a Hindu police officer.
('94', 141, 5, 21, 290889) Does it make any sense that an officer is removed just because he is a Muslim?
('94', 141, 5, 22, 290968) Of course, he should certainly be removed if he is inefficient.
('94', 141, 5, 23, 291032) And after all, the officers are going to carry out only what the Chief Minister of Bengal, Shaheed Suhrawardy Saheb, wants them to do.
('94', 141, 5, 24, 291167) If Shaheed Saheb is good, the officers will be good; but if he himself is bad, how can they remain good?”
('94', 141, 6, 25, 291273) R. The Government or the Congress should pay us compensation or loans in
('94', 141, 7, 26, 291346) proportion to the size of our business.
('94', 141, 8, 27, 291386) G. The Government should only advance loans and not pay compensation.
('94', 141, 9, 28, 291456) R. Stolen goods are being recovered.
('94', 141, 9, 29, 291493) This work should be done swiftly and
('94', 141, 10, 30, 291530) firmly.

('94', 158, 4, 16, 327078) 169. LETTER TO SIR HUGH DOW
('94', 158, 5, 17, 327106) PATNA, March 21, 1947
('94', 158, 6, 18, 327128) DEAR FRIEND, I have your three letters for all of which I thank you.
('94', 158, 6, 19, 327197) As you know at present I am touring in the affected parts of Bihar.
('94', 158, 6, 20, 327265) But I shall bear in mind your kind offer about making use of your beautiful garden to rest a little from the din and noise that surround me.
('94', 158, 7, 21, 327406) The word “bureaucrat” was used 1 by me in its original sense.
('94', 158, 7, 22, 327468) You do not represent autocracy.
('94', 158, 7, 23, 327500) Certainly not democracy.
('94', 158, 7, 24, 327525) But, as I hold, you essentially represent bureaucracy.
('94', 158, 7, 25, 327580) Several English friends, some holding as high a place as you do, told me frankly that, representing as they did a big corporation of bureaucrats, they were unable to give effect to the full man in them.
('94', 158, 7, 26, 327783) With this thought at the back of my mind I could not help admiring your remark that experience had taught you that after all the true reformer must begin with himself.
('94', 158, 8, 27, 327951) 1 Vide “Letter to Sir Hugh Dow”, 17 3 1947 In his reply dated March 22, the addressee about this said : “I suppose, I am a bureaucrat in the sense used by you : it is not a term that I resent.
('94', 158, 8, 28, 328144) The complexity of modern life ties most rulers to their desks more than they like, and this must be true even of yourself.
('94', 158, 8, 29, 328267) But I look forward to the early day when neither half of this word will have much application to me.”

('94', 163, 6, 15, 337986) CHORHUAN, March 21, 1947 I wish that those who have assembled here would think of the damage done and the number of men, women and children brutally done to death in this village, and sit in mournful silence in memory of the deceased.

('94', 163, 6, 20, 338431) No religion teaches anyone to kill his neighbours.
('94', 163, 6, 21, 338482) Righteous wars do take place, but I do not approve of them either.
('94', 163, 6, 22, 338549) In the Bhagavadgita, too, oppressors and tyrants were resisted in a righteous war.
('94', 163, 6, 23, 338632) It is the work of ruffians to kill innocent children and blameless men and women.
('94', 163, 6, 24, 338714) A marauder wreaks destruction on others out of selfishness or ignorance.
('94', 163, 6, 25, 338787) Whatever has happened here is, in my opinion, the work of oppressors and barbarians.
('94', 163, 6, 26, 338872) Many houses have been burnt down and many others have been reduced to debris.
('94', 163, 6, 27, 338950) The houses which a few months ago were full of life, are now desolate.

('94', 168, 1, 5, 347246) We should keep up courage.
('94', 168, 1, 6, 347273) The Hindus have committed a sin.
('94', 168, 1, 7, 347306) What have they gained thereby?
('94', 168, 1, 8, 347337) You do not trust them.
('94', 168, 1, 9, 347360) But if their hearts are cleansed, if they clean your houses, if they build new houses for you and if they sincerely atone for their sins, why should you then not return to your homes?
('94', 168, 1, 10, 347544) True bravery on the part of Hindus consists in confessing their guilt and changing their hearts.
('94', 168, 1, 11, 347641) I shall be only too glad if they do this.
('94', 168, 1, 12, 347683) People should return to the houses where there had been no killing.
('94', 168, 1, 13, 347751) If the residents don’t feel like going to murder haunted houses they may shift to another place.
('94', 168, 1, 14, 347848) It would be good if lands can be exchanged by mutual consent.
('94', 168, 1, 15, 347910) It may not be possible for the Government to arrange such transfers.
('94', 168, 1, 16, 347979) In any case whether they return to their own villages or shift to some other place, Muslim brothers and sisters should eschew all anger and bear no ill will towards Hindus.
('94', 168, 1, 17, 348152) You should not think of taking revenge against those who have oppressed you.
('94', 168, 1, 18, 348229) That is true bravery.
('94', 168, 1, 19, 348251) How transitory is this life?
('94', 168, 1, 20, 348280) Everyone has to die one day.
('94', 168, 1, 21, 348309) It is difficult to comprehend the ways of God.
('94', 168, 1, 22, 348356) Is there any place where He is not present?
('94', 168, 1, 23, 348400) Some people hold God responsible for whatever has happened.
('94', 168, 1, 24, 348460) Who can understand His ways?
('94', 168, 1, 25, 348489) God cannot be talked about disparagingly.
('94', 168, 1, 26, 348531) Why should we, then, blame Him for these happenings?
('94', 168, 1, 27, 348584) I do not wish to hear such talk from the lips of those who recite the kalma.
('94', 168, 1, 28, 348661) In fact, no one should even speak in this vein.
('94', 168, 1, 29, 348709) I wish to reassure all of you that I am wandering from place to place to prevent a repetition of what has happened so that Hindus and Muslims may live like brothers.
('94', 168, 1, 30, 348875) I shall stay and strive here as long as hearts are not cleansed and fraternal feelings are not revived.
('94', 168, 1, 31, 348979) I shall do or die; I shall either succeed in my mission or perish in the effort.

('94', 169, 2, 3, 349185) PATNA, March 22, 1947
('94', 169, 3, 4, 349207) I have returned to Patna today after a five day tour.
('94', 169, 3, 5, 349261) You would have learnt from newspapers where I went and what I said.
('94', 169, 3, 6, 349329) I liked the attitude of the villagers.
('94', 169, 3, 7, 349368) They are genuinely penitent.
('94', 169, 3, 8, 349397) Liberal contributions are being made by them for the relief of their Muslim brethren.
('94', 169, 3, 9, 349483) I was very happy to see this.
('94', 169, 3, 10, 349513) Many persons have also written to me that they will not misbehave again.
('94', 169, 4, 11, 349586) In a number of places, Gandhiji said, due to the bravery of the local Hindus, no incidents had occurred.
('94', 169, 4, 12, 349691) He was told by the Muslims themselves that in Dinapore Sub division no trouble occurred though the Muslims were greatly nervous.
('94', 169, 5, 13, 349820) Gandhiji said that he had addressed the Muslim women refugees in the morning
('94', 169, 6, 14, 349897) at Pipalwan.
('94', 169, 6, 15, 349910) 2 He did not wish at present to enter into a description of the feelings of
('94', 169, 7, 16, 349986) these women and their present condition.
('94', 169, 7, 17, 350027) His heart was too heavy and he did not wish
('94', 169, 8, 18, 350071) to shed tears.
('94', 169, 8, 19, 350086) He only wanted to tell them how to repent.
('94', 169, 8, 20, 350129) He tried as best as he could
('94', 169, 9, 21, 350158) to console them and persuade them to pick up courage and return to their villages,
('94', 169, 10, 22, 350241) placing reliance on God.
('94', 169, 10, 23, 350266) At this meeting he was told that Muslim women and men
('94', 169, 11, 24, 350320) dreaded the approach of March 22, as it had been reported that Punjab Day would be
('94', 169, 12, 25, 350403) observed in Bihar on that date.
('94', 169, 12, 26, 350435) He had told them that the Bihar Government had
('94', 169, 13, 27, 350482) banned the observance of any kind of day, be it Pakistan Day or Punjab Day.
('94', 169, 14, 28, 350558) Minister who was present also gave the assurance that no celebration of any kind
('94', 169, 15, 29, 350639) would be permitted and that the ban would be strictly enforced throughout the
('94', 169, 16, 30, 350717) province.
('94', 169, 16, 31, 350727) The Bihar Government, Gandhiji said, had banned the kisan rally also.
('94', 169, 16, 32, 350797) It is a different thing that the rally should not have been tarred with the same brush.
('94', 169, 16, 33, 350885) But the situation is very delicate today.
('94', 169, 16, 34, 350927) Our people’s hearts are not clean.
('94', 169, 16, 35, 350962) Hence even a kisan rally should be abandoned.

('94', 169, 16, 37, 351103) The Ministers have issued the order after much deliberation; hence the order must be obeyed.
('94', 169, 16, 38, 351196) If one wishes to disobey a law as a satyagrahi, one can do so.

('94', 169, 16, 40, 351357) But so long as they are in authority, we must carry out

('94', 170, 1, 2, 351599) their orders.
('94', 170, 2, 3, 351613) A true satyagrahi should implicitly obey the directions of those he had himself put in power.
('94', 170, 2, 4, 351707) What Gandhiji said did not refer only to March 22. It applied to the future also and at no time should these celebrations be indulged in, so long as the atmosphere remained as it was that day.
('94', 170, 2, 5, 351900) There is a conflagration in every quarter today.
('94', 170, 2, 6, 351949) A kisan rally is not advisable in these circumstances.
('94', 170, 2, 7, 352004) You can write to the Government about the difficulties you are facing.
('94', 170, 2, 8, 352075) You can agitate through newspapers.
('94', 170, 2, 9, 352111) Rallies are intended to awaken the kisans and to organize the people.
('94', 170, 2, 10, 352181) I have been leading such activities for the past sixty years and am quite an expert in these matters.
('94', 170, 2, 11, 352283) Conditions today are not conducive for such activities.
('94', 170, 2, 12, 352339) The Gita speaks of action in inaction and inaction in action.
('94', 170, 2, 13, 352401) 1 If I apply this to the present day context, it means we can do a lot of good by keeping quiet.
('94', 170, 2, 14, 352498) We should discriminate between dharma and adharma.
('94', 170, 2, 15, 352549) There are occasions when keeping away from adharma becomes the dharma.
('94', 170, 2, 16, 352620) It is no doubt our duty to awaken the kisans.
('94', 170, 2, 17, 352666) But this is not the time for it.
('94', 170, 2, 18, 352699) It is the duty of every Hindu to follow the teachings of the Gita, although anyone in the world can derive benefit from the Gita .
('94', 170, 2, 19, 352830) No one can say that we should repeat the same action in season and out of season.
('94', 170, 2, 20, 352912) We are subserving our waking hours even when we sleep; but if we go on sleeping all the time we will be as good as dead.
('94', 170, 2, 21, 353033) This only means that every action has its appropriate time.
('94', 170, 2, 22, 353093) Desisting from an inopportune action is as good as timely action.
('94', 170, 2, 23, 353159) The 22nd March has passed off peacefully.
('94', 170, 2, 24, 353201) It is a good thing.
('94', 170, 2, 25, 353221) We should now forget all about it.
('94', 170, 2, 26, 353256) We don’t have to celebrate a Punjab Day or a Pakistan Day.
('94', 170, 2, 27, 353315) These days are intended only to make us fight.
('94', 170, 2, 28, 353362) But our Muslim brothers here do not wish to fight.
('94', 170, 2, 29, 353413) Why should we then celebrate a Punjab Day?
('94', 170, 2, 30, 353456) I concede that a kisan rally stands on a different footing.
('94', 170, 2, 31, 353516) But the times are not propitious even for a kisan rally.
('94', 170, 2, 32, 353573) Every action should be undertaken at an appropriate time.
('94', 170, 2, 33, 353631) This is an occasion for penitence.
('94', 170, 2, 34, 353666) We should first atone for our sins.
('94', 170, 2, 35, 353702) It is part of the atonement to realize that the atrocities committed on Muslim brothers and sisters constitute grave sins.
('94', 170, 2, 36, 353825) If we are convinced that the Hindu heart has been cleansed through such atonement, then we can organize a kisan rally.

('94', 173, 6, 10, 357107) 183. DISCUSSION WITH WOMEN WORKERS 2
('94', 173, 7, 11, 357144) PATNA, March 23, 1947
('94', 173, 8, 12, 357166) QUESTION: Can women take part in politics while they are working in the
('94', 173, 9, 13, 357238) Kasturba Memorial Fund?
('94', 173, 10, 14, 357262) GANDHIJI: This question can be answered in two ways: they can and cannot take part in politics.
('94', 173, 10, 15, 357358) If they want to serve, they should not take part in politics.
('94', 173, 10, 16, 357420) There is Congress rule in the country at present (it may be socialism or communism in future).
('94', 173, 10, 17, 357515) Now, supposing it is necessary to sell spinning wheels or khadi for the sake of propaganda in the villages, women can take part in such activities.
('94', 173, 10, 18, 357663) But supposing the intentions of the Congress go wrong and instead of khadi it wants to sell liquor in the villages, the sevikas 3 would certainly not take part in such an activity.
('94', 173, 10, 19, 357844) Rather, they would start a satyagraha campaign against it if it became necessary.
('94', 173, 10, 20, 357926) Women can take part in any activity which is in the interest of the country irrespective of the ‘ism’ of the ruling party.

('94', 179, 5, 23, 367533) I can say something only when you are quiet.
('94', 179, 5, 24, 367578) In the first place, I wish to address a few words to the men and women volunteers.

('94', 180, 1, 2, 368140) have told them before also what they should do during the tours.
('94', 180, 1, 3, 368205) It is the duty of women volunteers to guide women as to how they should sit and conduct themselves at public meetings.
('94', 180, 1, 4, 368324) For this they should distribute leaflets beforehand and should read them out for their benefit.
('94', 180, 1, 5, 368420) The men who are either standing or sitting are keeping quiet, but because the women are not quiet, they cannot also hear anything.
('94', 180, 1, 6, 368551) In fact, it is not women alone who are to be blamed for this.
('94', 180, 1, 7, 368613) They are over worked, poor and illiterate.

('94', 180, 1, 12, 368968) I had been asked earlier to visit that village.
('94', 180, 1, 13, 369016) I realize the Hindus have suffered but that in no way mitigates their guilt.

('94', 180, 1, 18, 369494) Just as the trouble in one eye afflicts the other too, similarly the whole of India suffers when either Hindus or Muslims suffer.
('94', 180, 1, 19, 369624) If you realize this, I would think my purpose has been fulfilled.

('94', 181, 1, 2, 370194) position is fairly correct.
('94', 181, 1, 3, 370222) But let me put it in my own language.
('94', 181, 1, 4, 370260) What I feel is that however much detached we may want to be from our surroundings and the unseen atmosphere about us, we cannot but be affected by it.
('94', 181, 1, 5, 370411) Hence I am not sure whether, whilst the British military forces are in India, we can possibly be in real Indian atmosphere of peace and tranquillity, if these are ever to be her lot during our generation.
('94', 181, 1, 6, 370616) The present distemper may continue beyond January next and if it does not I am afraid it won’t be because of sanity regained by the communities but because of the fear of the military.
('94', 181, 1, 7, 370801) What is the use of our meeting under the protection of the bayonet, whether it is British or Indian?
('94', 181, 1, 8, 370902) May it not be wise therefore for sincere peace lovers to pray in their own homes, every day if you like, even for five minutes at the same time throughout the world?
('94', 181, 1, 9, 371068) It will be easy enough for everyone to find out the hour which should correspond with the time, say, in Calcutta or any place in India.
('94', 181, 1, 10, 371204) We can even make the calculations and publish the different times for the different centres.
('94', 181, 1, 11, 371297) The value would lie in finding the exact time.
('94', 181, 1, 12, 371344) If you still think that a meeting should take place here, I suggest postponement till after the withdrawal of British arms.
('94', 181, 1, 13, 371468) These are my random thoughts, not for you to act upon unless they fully appeal to you, because in this matter I have yielded to your judgment.
('94', 181, 1, 14, 371611) If you propose to go on with your idea and want to have the meeting at the time you have conceived, send me the thirty names and I shall send you my suggestions as to whether I want to add to the list.
('94', 181, 1, 15, 371813) With reference to milk distribution in Madras you have another Ministry there now.
('94', 181, 1, 16, 371896) 1 I wonder if it will make any difference.
('94', 181, 1, 17, 371939) I hold on to my suggestion.
('94', 181, 1, 18, 371967) About my own private affair I have done and am doing all I can.
('94', 181, 1, 19, 372031) I suppose you already know that Manu no longer sleeps in the same bed with me.
('94', 181, 1, 20, 372110) This departure was made by her with my full approval in order to please Bapa who, though he saw absolutely nothing wrong, would appeal to her not to continue [it] whilst I was in Bihar and whilst I was engaged in this important work.
('94', 181, 1, 21, 372344) I do not agree with the conclusion.
('94', 181, 1, 22, 372380) But I did not wish to argue and therefore I promptly agreed.
('94', 181, 1, 23, 372441) Whilst I am dictating this letter I see that you could not know

('94', 185, 1, 2, 377179) 199. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('94', 185, 2, 3, 377209) PATNA, March 25, 1947
('94', 185, 3, 4, 377231) My third tour will commence tomorrow.
('94', 185, 3, 5, 377269) I shall go to Jahanabad and return on March 28. The prayer meeting will again be held here on the 29th.
('94', 185, 3, 6, 377373) I saw the destruction in the village which I visited and met the Hindus and the Muslims there.
('94', 185, 3, 7, 377468) Today also I have been meeting people throughout the day.
('94', 185, 3, 8, 377526) One Muslim friend said that it was very good indeed that I visited them.
('94', 185, 3, 9, 377599) Now they were convinced that nothing of this sort would recur.
('94', 185, 3, 10, 377662) But I was pained by what another Muslim friend told me.
('94', 185, 3, 11, 377718) He said that the Hindus were now boycotting the Muslims.
('94', 185, 3, 12, 377775) Sometimes boycott could be a welcome thing but it is bad if it is directed against one’s own brother.
('94', 185, 3, 13, 377877) Suppose we have been under the treatment of a Muslim doctor till today, as for instance I used to be treated by Dr. Ansari, 1 Hakim Ajmal Khan 2 or Dr. Abdul Rehman.
('94', 185, 3, 14, 378043) Should we stop being treated by him as soon as a Hindu Muslim riot breaks out?
('94', 185, 3, 15, 378122) Boycott had an important place in our struggle against the British.
('94', 185, 3, 16, 378190) But if it is adopted amongst ourselves it will amount to violence.
('94', 185, 3, 17, 378257) The Hindus have committed a sin in Bihar and today they are the guilty ones ; do they now want to persist in doing wrong?
('94', 185, 3, 18, 378379) The case of the doctor was cited only as an example.
('94', 185, 3, 19, 378432) The gentleman mentioned by me is a businessman and landlord.
('94', 185, 3, 20, 378493) Both Hindus and Muslims had their shops on his land and did business there.
('94', 185, 3, 21, 378569) It was a source of income for him.
('94', 185, 3, 22, 378604) But now the Hindus have stopped going there; this is a pernicious boycott.
('94', 185, 3, 23, 378679) It so happens sometimes that one who is engaged as a tailor does not like anyone else to take up that profession.
('94', 185, 3, 24, 378793) There was a time when a tailor’s son took to tailoring only.
('94', 185, 3, 25, 378854) But now a tailor’s son can also become a head clerk.
('94', 185, 3, 26, 378907) Such ill will and feeling of animosity should be given up.
('94', 185, 4, 27, 378966) 1 M. A. Ansari (1880 1936) ; physician and surgeon ; Member, Congress Working Committee; President, Indian National Congress, 1927 ; Chancellor, Jamia Millia Islamia, 1928 36 2 (1863 1927) ; Chief Physician to the Nawab of Rampur, 1892 1902; President, Indian National Congress, 1921 ; first Chancellor of Jamia Millia Islamia, 1920 27
('94', 186, 0, 1, 379302) VOL. 94: 17 FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947 187
('94', 186, 1, 2, 379348) Let me give you some good news too.
('94', 186, 1, 3, 379384) Today some League friends met me and expressed their wish to live with the Hindus amicably and wanted the Government to listen to them.
('94', 186, 1, 4, 379520) I said to them that though the League represented a large number of Muslims I did not agree that those who were outside the League were not Muslims or that the League was the sole representative of the Muslims.
('94', 186, 1, 5, 379731) The boycott of the League would not do.
('94', 186, 1, 6, 379771) I even asked the Noakhali Muslims to obey the orders of the League.
('94', 186, 1, 7, 379839) So long as they were in the League, it was their duty to carry out its orders.
('94', 186, 1, 8, 379918) But if the League misguided them and asked them to slit the throats of the Hindus, they should refuse to obey it and quit the League.
('94', 186, 1, 9, 380052) The League friends also said: “Though we belong to the League still we are friends of the Hindus.
('94', 186, 1, 10, 380150) If the Government does not take us into confidence, how can the Muslims trust it?
('94', 186, 1, 11, 380232) It we plead with the Muslims who had run away, they will come back.
('94', 186, 1, 12, 380300) But if we do not co operate how many Muslims can you bring back?
('94', 186, 1, 13, 380365) Maybe a few of them would return.
('94', 186, 1, 14, 380399) But all of them will not .
('94', 186, 1, 15, 380426) The Government should consult us.” I told them it was a good and straightforward suggestion.
('94', 186, 1, 16, 380519) Each should co operate with the other and do his duty.
('94', 186, 1, 17, 380574) When we work unitedly it will have its impact on India as well as on the world.
('94', 186, 1, 18, 380654) It will purify our hearts.
('94', 186, 1, 19, 380681) We should act only with a pure heart.
('94', 186, 1, 20, 380719) What is the use of our being together without unity of hearts?
('94', 186, 1, 21, 380782) I also heard some Muslims say that there were ten crore Muslims and even if one crore perished the remaining nine crores would fight for founding a nation of their own.
('94', 186, 1, 22, 380951) I told them that if they had such notions they would not serve Islam in any way.
('94', 186, 1, 23, 381032) On the contrary they would destroy it.
('94', 186, 1, 24, 381071) I had told the Hindus also in Noakhali that they should get rid of all fear.
('94', 186, 1, 25, 381148) We should fear God alone.
('94', 186, 1, 26, 381174) It is cowardice to agree to something or to bow our heads before others out of fear.
('94', 186, 1, 27, 381259) The friend from Noakhali has informed me that after my return from Noakhali the situation there has deteriorated again.
('94', 186, 1, 28, 381379) I told him that if the Hindus in Bihar co operated with me, I could work for Noakhali while I was still here.
('94', 186, 1, 29, 381489) I would appeal to the Muslims of Noakhali, if my voice could reach them, to live in unity with Hindus, wherever they may be.

('94', 188, 11, 19, 384991) 202. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('94', 188, 12, 20, 385019) PATNA, March 26, 1947
('94', 188, 13, 21, 385041) Gandhiji’s attention being drawn by the A. P. I. to a report in a section of the Press ( not The Indian Nation) about a letter said to have been received by him from the new Viceroy and his alleged reply thereto, he said that it was packed with half 
('94', 188, 14, 22, 385292) 1 To Tilhara, to ascertain the true extent of damages caused to the Muslim lives, properties and holy places of worship during commual riots in Bihar.
('94', 189, 0, 1, 385443) 190 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('94', 189, 1, 2, 385485) truths which he always held as more dangerous than full untruths and therefore, characterized half truths as “a lie and a half”.
('94', 189, 2, 3, 385614) Pressed for clarification Gandhiji said that he had no desire to run into the trap, however unconscious it might be.
('94', 189, 2, 4, 385731) He added that whoever had concocted the message had done no service to the cause of Indian independence or to honest journalism.
('94', 189, 2, 5, 385860) He would like Indian journalists not to copy the worst features of journalism of the West with which unfortunately it was reeking.
('94', 189, 2, 6, 385991) But if there was to be imitation it should be of the best in Western journalism of which he was happy to be able to testify.
('94', 189, 2, 7, 386116) Gandhiji said: There are several brilliant examples in journalism and as a journalist of long standing, though an amateur, I must conclude by the warning that journalism which is rightly called the Fourth Estate should never degrade itself by becoming a means of making money.
('94', 189, 2, 8, 386393) This caution is doubly necessary at the present critical time in the history of the country.
('94', 189, 2, 9, 386486) The Indian Nation, 27 3 1947
('94', 189, 3, 10, 386515) 203. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('94', 189, 4, 11, 386547) JEHANABAD, March 26, 1947
('94', 189, 5, 12, 386573) Gandhiji began his post prayer speech by referring to the common weakness of misunderstanding opponents, attributing to them motives which could not be proved.
('94', 189, 5, 13, 386733) Such behaviour often led to untoward results which prudent people would avoid.
('94', 189, 5, 14, 386812) Such misunderstanding was responsible for differences between the Congress and the League.
('94', 189, 5, 15, 386903) 2 Both the organizations had a large following.
('94', 189, 5, 16, 386951) The responsibility resting on them was all the greater for their popularity.
('94', 189, 5, 17, 387028) Their conduct towards each other had to be above suspicion.
('94', 189, 6, 18, 387088) Gandhiji next referred to his visit to Kako Relief Camp 3 and the village of Saistabad.
('94', 189, 6, 19, 387176) Men and women burst into tears when they saw him.
('94', 189, 6, 20, 387226) He told them that to break under one’s sorrow did not become brave people.
('94', 189, 6, 21, 387301) All religions taught that sorrow should be bravely borne.

('94', 190, 1, 4, 388107) They should take a vow never to succumb to the madness again.

('94', 190, 1, 10, 388624) No one could mistake arson and murder of innocent women and children as a brave act.

('94', 190, 3, 16, 389183) It ill became the votaries of the Ramayana to try to suppress the fourteen or fifteen per cent of the Muslims in their midst.

('94', 192, 4, 12, 392489) 206. TALK WITH MUSLIMS 2
('94', 192, 5, 13, 392514) AMTHUA, March 27, 1947 Gandhiji said that the style in which the memorandum had been written, it could not represent the views of the people who surrounded him there because when he himself understood so little of it he was sure the illiterate friends around him could not understand what it conveyed.
('94', 192, 5, 14, 392816) He asked how could the reader of the memorandum claim to represent the views of those for whom he spoke.
('94', 192, 5, 15, 392921) Referring to the complaints against the Hindus, Gandhiji said it was his mission to make people brave whether they were Hindus or Muslims and he asked the people who had submitted the memorandum not to preach cowardice among the Muslims.
('94', 192, 5, 16, 393159) He gave the example of South Africa where he led the Indians, a bare handful of 13,000 in the entire sub continent, against great odds and those Indians were courageous enough today to fight their oppressors.
('94', 192, 5, 17, 393368) In Bihar the Muslims were in a much greater majority than the Indians in South Africa and therefore they should be brave.
('94', 192, 6, 18, 393490) Gandhiji reaffirmed that he was not disloyal or unfaithful to the Muslims and that his one aim in life was to help the Muslims as long as he was alive and he would try to help them even by dying.
('94', 192, 7, 19, 393686) Before he left he invited the Muslims to come and see him and place fore him all the difficulties in their way.
('94', 192, 7, 20, 393798) The Indian Nation, 29 3 1947
('94', 192, 8, 21, 393827) 1 Y. M. Parnerkar, a dairy expert 2 Gandhiji visited Amthua at 8 a.m.
('94', 192, 8, 22, 393897) where Muslims presented to him a memorandum written in highly Persianized Urdu.
('94', 192, 8, 23, 393977) It stated among other things that Gandhiji’s visit was likely to do more harm than good and that the Government had helped rioters and Congressmen who were in league with them.

('94', 193, 1, 2, 394196) 207. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('94', 193, 2, 3, 394228) OKRI, March 27, 1947
('94', 193, 3, 4, 394249) Gandhiji uttered the warning that Indians might lose the golden apple of independence which was almost within their grasp, out of insanity, which had caused scenes of desolation and destruction, and stated that the peace that reigned in the land was only on the surface.
('94', 193, 3, 5, 394520) He said this while referring to his visit during the morning and afternoon to some riotaffected villages.
('94', 193, 4, 6, 394626) Gandhiji added that they knew the very first pronouncement that the Viceroy had made when he assumed office stated that he was sent as the last Viceroy to wind up the British rule in India.
('94', 193, 4, 7, 394816) They must have noticed that the pronouncement was deliberate, unconditional and unequivocal.
('94', 193, 4, 8, 394909) He said that we must trust British promises for it would be cowardice to say that all Britons were dishonest.
('94', 193, 4, 9, 395019) That, he explained, would mean that we were ourselves dishonest.
('94', 193, 4, 10, 395084) Gandhiji added that the jar of British sins was full and they must go but it was not right to abuse them while they were departing.
('94', 193, 4, 11, 395216) He knew that it had become a fashion, though not without cause, to distrust every British declaration.
('94', 193, 4, 12, 395319) He for one would advise the acceptance of every declaration at its face value without qualifying it in the light of past experience to the contrary.
('94', 193, 4, 13, 395468) His experience was that it was the deceiver who always lost and never the dupe if he was honest and brave.
('94', 193, 4, 14, 395575) But he very much feared on account of what had happened in the country that by their folly or, what was worse than that, insanity, they might let slip out of their hands their hard won prize before it was strongly locked in their unbreakable fist.
('94', 193, 5, 15, 395823) Gandhiji referred to Bihar and the Punjab and said that he had wisdom enough to see that they themselves might tempt the Viceroy to eat his own words, uttered solemnly on a solemn occasion.
('94', 193, 5, 16, 396013) Heaven forbid that such an occasion should arise, but, if it did, even though his might be a voice in the wilderness, he would declare that the Viceroy should firmly and truly carry out his declaration and complete the British withdrawal.
('94', 193, 6, 17, 396252) Gandhiji then referred to his tour today in villages Amthua, Belai and Ghosi, this morning and Abdal Chak, Zulfipur and Abdalpur 2. He said that the same stories of atrocities were repeated the whole day.
('94', 193, 6, 18, 396457) He advised the Congressmen who had approached him and said that innocent men were in jail as a result of communal cases, that they should produce those who were guilty and if they failed they should cease to be Congressmen.
('94', 193, 6, 19, 396681) Gandhiji also advised the guilty to confess to him, for he would not give them away to Government but then they thought to atone for their sins.
('94', 193, 6, 20, 396826) Gandhiji also requested Hindus to return all abducted women and girls, if any in their possession, at once.
('94', 193, 7, 21, 396934) 1 The reports in Harijan and The Indian Nation have been collated.
('94', 193, 7, 22, 397001) 2 In the afternoon
('94', 194, 0, 1, 397020) VOL. 94: 17 FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947 195
('94', 194, 1, 2, 397066) Gandhiji referred to the police strike 1, and said that the police, like the scavengers, should never go on strike.
('94', 194, 1, 3, 397182) Theirs was an essential service and they should render that service irrespective of pay.
('94', 194, 2, 4, 397271) There were many other effective and honourable means of getting grievances redressed.
('94', 194, 2, 5, 397357) If he were a Cabinet Minister, he would offer the strikers nothing whatever under the threat of a strike, which implied force.
('94', 194, 2, 6, 397484) He would give them the choice of an impartial arbitration, without any condition.
('94', 194, 2, 7, 397566) He said: It will be a bad day for India if the military, including the police, rule India.
('94', 194, 3, 8, 397657) He hoped the police would call off their strike unconditionally and request the Ministry to appoint an impartial arbitrator to investigate their case.
('94', 194, 4, 9, 397808) Gandhiji also appealed to the policemen not to behave in the manner in which they were behaving then.
('94', 194, 4, 10, 397910) Every policeman, he said, was a servant of the people and his duty was to behave like the Khudai Khidmatgars.
('94', 194, 4, 11, 398020) Policemen were the custodians of law.
('94', 194, 5, 12, 398058) Continuing, Gandhiji said that if every man, woman and child tried to understand his or her duty and if there was no theft or dacoity, there would be no need for policemen.
('94', 194, 5, 13, 398231) Everyone could then become a policeman and help each other.
('94', 194, 6, 14, 398291) Gandhiji expressed regret that the Bihar Government had employed British soldiers to deal with the strikers.
('94', 194, 6, 15, 398400) No matter what the cause was, and wherever it was, the Indian Governments must never requisition the services of British soldiers to deal with civil disturbances.
('94', 194, 6, 16, 398563) Otherwise it would mean that the Indian Governments were helpless without British arms.
('94', 194, 7, 17, 398651) Harijan, 13 4 1947, and The Indian Nation, 29 3 1947
('94', 194, 8, 18, 398704) 1 On March 20, 1947, a police havildar was convicted of contempt of court by the Sub divisional Officer, Gaya.
('94', 194, 8, 19, 398815) The Gaya police then gave notice of strike unless redress was given to the havildar and the Sub Divisional Officer punished.
('94', 194, 8, 20, 398940) An immediate inquiry was ordered by the District Magistrate.
('94', 194, 8, 21, 399001) The strike commenced on March 24 and the strikers refused to return to duty in spite of the inquiry which began the same day.
('94', 194, 8, 22, 399127) From Gaya the strike spread to Patna and Monghyr.

('94', 195, 7, 9, 399472) JEHANABAD, March 28, 1947
('94', 195, 8, 10, 399498) MANILAL, I got your long letter of March 7. You have given sufficient details.
('94', 195, 8, 11, 399577) You need not hesitate to write to me out of compassion for me because of the pressure of work on me.
('94', 195, 8, 12, 399678) I have not known a father who would not welcome a letter from his son or daughter.
('94', 195, 8, 13, 399761) On the contrary, every father looks forward to such letters.
('94', 195, 8, 14, 399822) It is true, of course, that if my sons were to write silly and sentimental letters, I would be pained to read them.

('94', 195, 8, 16, 400072) I, therefore, have no fear on that score.

('94', 195, 9, 20, 400331) If it is good, its benefit will be shared by millions.

('94', 196, 7, 25, 401870) One memorandum suggested that Gandhiji’s reference to the Noakhali incidents in his speeches instead of suppressing the feeling of Hindus here would aggravate them.
('94', 196, 8, 26, 402035) 1 The reference appears to be to the visit of Duke of Cornwall and York to South Africa; vide 2 Indian Opinion 3 On March 20 4 Addressee’s daughter 5 The report in Harijan, reproduced from The Searchlight, 30 3 1947, has been collated with the version in Mahatma Gandhi—The Last Phase.

('94', 197, 1, 2, 402504) Gandhiji answered that the inference was not correct for he had not spared the Hindus.
('94', 197, 1, 3, 402591) In fact there was a time when he used to be equally plainspoken with the Muslims, too.
('94', 197, 1, 4, 402678) He had even fasted for twenty one days for what they had done in 1924. 1 The Muslims did not then regard him as their enemy.
('94', 197, 2, 5, 402803) Gandhiji said that as the Muslims today generally considered him as their enemy, he was sometimes obliged to speak with restraint.
('94', 197, 2, 6, 402934) In the Punjab worse things were happening and at first he did not believe the newspaper stories but his subsequent enquiries made him believe that far more excesses than the newspapers reported were being committed in the Punjab.
('94', 197, 2, 7, 403164) Because it was the doing of a particular community, should he not speak about it?
('94', 197, 2, 8, 403246) His mission could not be successful by such suppression, he said.
('94', 197, 2, 9, 403312) As far as possible I have refrained from discussing the affairs in Noakhali in my speeches.
('94', 197, 2, 10, 403404) But whenever I have had occasion to speak about Noakhali, I claim that I have spoken with great restraint.
('94', 197, 2, 11, 403511) Do the Muslims want that I should not speak about the sins committed by them in Noakhali and that I should only speak about the sins of the Hindus in Bihar?
('94', 197, 2, 12, 403668) If I do that, I will be a coward.
('94', 197, 2, 13, 403702) To me the sins of the Noakhali Muslims and the Bihar Hindus are of the same magnitude and equally condemnable.
('94', 197, 3, 14, 403813) Gandhiji thereafter replying to another memorandum, which stated that the signatories had no confidence in the present Ministry, said: I told the Hindus of Noakhali, who also expressed lack of confidence in Mr. Shaheed Suhrawardy, that they could not remove Shaheed Saheb from the Ministry as he was returned by the separate electorate system.
('94', 197, 3, 15, 404157) So long as Shaheed Saheb enjoys the confidence of the community he represents, no one can remove him.
('94', 197, 3, 16, 404259) Similarly, how can you remove the Ministers when they have been returned by the Hindu electorate?
('94', 197, 3, 17, 404357) This unfortunate situation has been created by the communal electorate system which, you know, I have always condemned.
('94', 197, 3, 18, 404477) Dr. Khan Saheb 2 also said the same thing the other day that so long as he enjoyed the confidence of the Pathans there was no question of his resignation.
('94', 197, 3, 19, 404632) Moreover, what will happen if the Ministry goes out?
('94', 197, 3, 20, 404685) There will again be the rule of the bureaucratic Government.
('94', 197, 3, 21, 404746) That apart, I can take good work from these Ministers as my relationship with them is most friendly.
('94', 197, 4, 22, 404847) The Bihar Ministers have told me that if I asked them to resign, they would do so.
('94', 197, 4, 23, 404930) But it would be wrong on my part to ask them to

('94', 198, 1, 2, 405123) resign.
('94', 198, 1, 3, 405131) I can ask them to do only what is reasonable.
('94', 198, 2, 4, 405177) Referring to the demand that fifty per cent of the officers and constables put in charge of new thanas 1 should be Muslims, Gandhiji replied: I disapproved of the very same demand of the Noakhali Hindus.
('94', 198, 2, 5, 405381) This demand cuts across my peace mission.
('94', 198, 2, 6, 405423) If conceded, this will mean so many small Pakistans and a division of Bihar.
('94', 198, 2, 7, 405500) After all, wherever you live, you have to live by creating mutual goodwill and friendly relations with your neighbours.
('94', 198, 2, 8, 405620) Even the Quaid e Azam once said that in the Pakistan areas the majority must so behave as to win the confidence of the minority.
('94', 198, 2, 9, 405749) In the same manner, I am urging upon the Hindus here to win your confidence.
('94', 198, 2, 10, 405826) Either Pakistan or Hindustan, whichever is established, it must be based on justice and fair play.
('94', 198, 3, 11, 405925) Referring to another demand that the Muslims may be allowed to resettle in certain exclusive areas, Gandhiji said: You cannot force the Government to keep you in certain exclusive areas.
('94', 198, 3, 12, 406112) Could I tell that to Shaheed Saheb for the Noakhali Hindus?
('94', 198, 3, 13, 406172) I never gave any encouragement to the Noakhali Hindus for such a move.
('94', 198, 3, 14, 406243) I told the Hindus of Noakhali that if they were afraid, they could go anywhere if they got compensation.
('94', 198, 3, 15, 406348) And why should the Government not pay compensation when they got the properties?
('94', 198, 3, 16, 406429) Similarly, I will tell you to go anywhere provided you get adequate compensation.
('94', 198, 3, 17, 406511) But I must tell you that it is not my heart’s desire.
('94', 198, 3, 18, 406565) Leaving your homestead in such a manner is nothing but cowardice.
('94', 198, 3, 19, 406631) If the Government is not prepared to pay compensation, I should say it is unworthy of them and the Government cannot refuse it.
('94', 198, 3, 20, 406759) Moreover, if the Ministers who have been returned by the Hindu votes say that the Hindus here have gone beyond control, it is better for them to consume themselves in the flames of the Hindu rage than to continue in office.
('94', 198, 3, 21, 406983) The Government has to do justice and cannot afford injustice in any manner.
('94', 198, 4, 22, 407059) Referring thereafter to the Muslim grievances regarding the reported appointment of Mr. Justice Reuben to conduct the Bihar Riots Enquiry, Gandhiji said, the memorandum suggested that the Muslims had no faith in Mr. Reuben.
('94', 198, 4, 23, 407283) But they never suggested whom they wanted.
('94', 198, 4, 24, 407326) To hold anyone as a suspect simply because he was a non Muslim was not right.
('94', 198, 4, 25, 407404) Personally he would have liked the Judge to be a Muslim provided he was acceptable to all.

('94', 199, 1, 5, 407849) If the Muslims want, they can submit a panel of names from amongst which the commission should be appointed.
('94', 199, 1, 6, 407958) Then I can inform the authorities.

('94', 199, 2, 9, 408145) With regard to the demand of restoration and finding out of abducted women, Gandhiji said: Since my arrival in Bihar I have been telling all those Muslims who told me about the abducted girls to give me the names and the family connections of such girls in order to help find out if they were still alive.

('94', 199, 4, 18, 409126) If they found him guilty, he would submit to any punishment.
('94', 199, 4, 19, 409187) Even otherwise, he would carry out Gandhiji’s orders.

('94', 199, 5, 21, 409411) Gandhiji said: It is a challenge to the Government.
('94', 199, 5, 22, 409463) If the Government fails to arrest the culprits it will stand discredited.
('94', 199, 6, 23, 409537) Turning to the member of the Assembly in question, he told him that a special responsibility rested upon him, he being a member from the locality.
('94', 199, 6, 24, 409684) If the Muslims suspected him of complicity in the riots, he should resign his seat even though the suspicion against him was unfounded.
('94', 199, 6, 25, 409820) To the Muslims Gandhiji said that they should seek God’s truth only, prove their charges and if they could not be proved, unreservedly withdraw them.

('94', 200, 3, 4, 410167) Gandhiji agreed with them that where the Muslims had in panic sold their property at ridiculously cheap prices they should be able to get the same back at those very rates.
('94', 200, 3, 5, 410340) Police outposts should be opened at places where looting and destruction of property was still going on.
('94', 200, 3, 6, 410445) An inquiry should be held into the conduct of the officers who were guilty of gross neglect of their duty during the disturbances, and those against whom the charges were established should be dismissed.
('94', 200, 3, 7, 410649) It was further suggested to Gandhiji that attention should be paid to the irresponsible and communal minded section of the Congress.
('94', 200, 3, 8, 410782) Gandhiji replied that unlike the Muslim League and the Hindu Mahasabha the Congress was meant to serve all.
('94', 200, 3, 9, 410890) If it belied its nationalist character, it would destroy itself.
('94', 200, 4, 10, 410955) QUESTION: Does the experience that you have had and the atmosphere that you find around you lend you any hope of success in your mission of re establishing lost confidence between the Hindus and Muslims?
('94', 200, 5, 11, 411159) GANDHIJI: Man can only try.
('94', 200, 5, 12, 411187) The result is in the hands of God.
('94', 200, 6, 13, 411222) Addressing the village representatives, Gandhiji exhorted them to cleanse their hearts.
('94', 200, 6, 14, 411310) If they told him they were innocent, he would not believe them.
('94', 200, 6, 15, 411374) If a single Hindu had committed the crime, they were all responsible for it.
('94', 200, 6, 16, 411451) Could he reassure the Muslims on their behalf, he asked, that the realization of their sin had been brought home to them and their hearts had been thoroughly cleansed by genuine repentance?
('94', 200, 6, 17, 411641) If, on the other hand, they felt that in butchering the Muslims they had done the right thing, they should say so plainly, so that he might know exactly where he stood and decide his future course of action accordingly.
('94', 200, 6, 18, 411861) For, he had sworn to “do or die” in Bihar.

('94', 201, 4, 6, 412564) My faith in God, however, is not a whit shaken by it, rather it is strengthened.
('94', 201, 4, 7, 412645) These incidents have shown me the persons I trust in their true colours.
('94', 201, 4, 8, 412718) I will not be losing anything if they prove to be false, because they will be shunned wherever they go.
('94', 201, 4, 9, 412822) I am not anyone’s master, I am only an humble servant.
('94', 201, 4, 10, 412877) When the dawn of independence is on the horizon, our people are indulging in such madness.

('94', 202, 5, 8, 415021) ALLAHGANJ, March 28, 1947
('94', 202, 6, 9, 415047) Gandhiji began by saying that he had passed a very full and heavy day.
('94', 202, 6, 10, 415118) The day was begun with a long meeting 2 with the members of the local Muslim League at the bungalow of Mr. Azharul Haq, local League leader.
('94', 202, 6, 11, 415259) He was with them for over an hour and had a hearty chat with them answering all kinds of questions.
('94', 202, 6, 12, 415359) Then he had a meeting 3 at his residential quarters with Hindus and Muslims belonging to JEHANABAD and the surrounding villages.
('94', 202, 6, 13, 415488) He had then a meeting 4 with the Congressmen which included members of the various Congress Committees.
('94', 202, 6, 14, 415592) Later he met the members of the local Hindu Mahasabha.
('94', 202, 6, 15, 415647) Finally he had a heart to heart talk 5
('94', 202, 7, 16, 415686) with over 25 members of the police force on strike.
('94', 202, 7, 17, 415738) Then at half past three again he visited the villages of Malathi, Gangasagar, Bola and Allahganj, in which Muslims had suffered badly.
('94', 202, 8, 18, 415873) Referring to his visit to the villages, Gandhiji said that naturally he was full of topics on which he wanted to speak and bespeak their attention.
('94', 202, 8, 19, 416021) He was sorry to say that Hindu repentance was not open and sincere enough to inspire confidence among the Muslims.
('94', 202, 8, 20, 416136) He had told the afternoon meeting that it was open to the representative Hindus who were present at the meeting to disabuse the Muslims of their suspicion.
('94', 202, 8, 21, 416292) He was sorry to say that not one Hindu got up to give the needed assurance.
('94', 202, 8, 22, 416368) He had not the heart, therefore, to ask his Muslim hearers whether they (the Hindus) had cleansed their hearts.
('94', 202, 8, 23, 416480) Muslims were the injured party in Bihar and it was not open to anyone to expect a satisfactory answer from them unless the guilty Hindu party had led the way

('94', 203, 1, 2, 416953) by repentance.
('94', 203, 1, 3, 416968) There were, yet, ring leaders like Mathura Singh at large and successfully evading arrest.
('94', 203, 1, 4, 417059) There was, therefore, little cause for wonder if the Muslims were afraid to return to their respective villages.
('94', 203, 1, 5, 417172) Gandhiji said that he could not help feeling that the culprit could not long remain at large if the Hindu population did not give him shelter.
('94', 203, 1, 6, 417315) He asked Mathura Singh’s friends and sympathizers to advise him to discover himself and face the consequences of his action.
('94', 203, 1, 7, 417440) He would also like to tell him that it was no act of bravery for him to evade arrest.

('94', 203, 1, 9, 417603) He suggested to the Congressmen, in whose midst the inhumanities were enacted, that they could not absolve themselves from the guilt, unless they made every effort to induce all the culprits to come out into the open and to wash their guilt as publicly as they had committed the crimes.
('94', 203, 2, 10, 417890) Continuing, Gandhiji said that he had visited a mosque in the village Bola which was damaged during the disturbances.
('94', 203, 2, 11, 418008) He was told that on the day of Holi the mosque was again desecrated by some villagers who played Holi inside the mosque premises.
('94', 203, 2, 12, 418138) If it was true, Gandhiji said, it was undoubtedly a notice given by them to the Muslims not to enter their homes even when they were rebuilt, not dare to visit the mosque.
('94', 203, 2, 13, 418310) If this reported desecration on Holi day was a fact, it was a bad omen for the Hindus, for Bihar and for the whole country.
('94', 203, 2, 14, 418434) He regretted the reported action of the local Hindus and warned them to respect all places of worship alike.
('94', 203, 2, 15, 418543) He called upon the culprits to confess.
('94', 203, 2, 16, 418583) But, Gandhiji regretted, new parties and new leaders had risen who believed in all sorts of crimes and perhaps nobody was prepared to listen to him.
('94', 203, 2, 17, 418732) He recalled the theme of today’s bhajan and prayed to God for help and hoped Bihar would come out of the difficulty now facing the province.
('94', 203, 3, 18, 418873) Gandhiji went on to say that he had heard at the Muslim League meeting in the morning and at the meeting of the Hindus and the Muslims in the afternoon that Mahant Bhagwat Das who was a member of the Bihar Legislative Assembly was himself a participator in the crime and was himself present at both the meetings.
('94', 203, 3, 19, 419186) The speaker advised him whilst he was under suspicion to give up his membership.
('94', 203, 3, 20, 419267) He was glad to say that Mahant Bhagwat Das, without a moment’s hesitation, welcomed the advice and promised at once to act up to it.
('94', 203, 3, 21, 419400) He also added that Bhagwat Das was in no way a participator directly or indirectly in the crime and that he was quite ready to face an open, impartial enquiry to be made by the Muslim League itself.
('94', 203, 3, 22, 419599) If it was a sincere declaration, Gandhiji said, it was certainly a refreshing thing at a time when there was no real sign of sincere sorrow and repentance on the part of the Hindus in the affected areas.
('94', 203, 3, 23, 419803) This he was obliged to say in spite of welcome letters of repentance to which he had made reference at the previous evening’s meeting.
('94', 203, 4, 24, 419938) His attention has been drawn, Gandhiji said, to the fact that the Government lorry which had accompanied him in his tour was forcibly boarded by passers by as if they had a right to travel in it even as the authorized occupants.
('94', 203, 4, 25, 420167) He was sorry at the unmanly exhibition of authority and lawlessness.
('94', 203, 4, 26, 420236) Such licence could not be tolerated even in the freest country in the world.
('94', 203, 4, 27, 420313) Those who defied the law were digging the
('94', 204, 0, 1, 420355) VOL. 94: 17 FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947 205
('94', 204, 1, 2, 420401) grave of Indian independence before it was in their hands.
('94', 204, 2, 3, 420460) Gandhiji fervently appealed to all Bihar and through Bihar to the Indian people not to plunge the country into a turmoil in the prelude to the dawn of freedom over this land which he called the arunodaya of the new age.
('94', 204, 2, 4, 420680) Gandhiji warned the nation to awaken before the day of freedom dawned, just as all good men were up from slumber and prayed before sunrise.
('94', 204, 3, 5, 420820) Gandhiji set at rest all speculation about his visit to Delhi in response to Lord Mountbatten’s invitation by announcing that he was leaving Bihar for three or four days.
('94', 204, 3, 6, 420991) Gandhiji said he was determined to stay in Bihar and see the work he had taken up through and no man could prevent him from doing it.
('94', 204, 3, 7, 421125) God alone could keep him away if He so desired.
('94', 204, 4, 8, 421173) Harijan, 13 4 1947, The Indian Nation, 30 3 1947, and The Hindu, 31 3 1947
('94', 204, 5, 9, 421248) 215. LETTER TO J. C. KUMARAPPA
('94', 204, 6, 10, 421279) PATNA, March 29, 1947
('94', 204, 7, 11, 421301) MY DEAR KU., I wrote to you thoughtlessly a few days ago.
('94', 204, 7, 12, 421359) 2 But having now got your letter of the 22nd instant 3 I feel that the healthy rule which prevents the members of constructive organizations from becoming members of the Working Committee should not be tampered with however tempting a particular offer may be.
('94', 204, 7, 13, 421619) What the President can do however is to invite you and such other members when expert advice is wanted on village matters.
('94', 204, 7, 14, 421742) If you were a fullfledged member you would be obliged to give your thought to many other matters which did not fall within your jurisdiction as a village scavenger.
('94', 204, 7, 15, 421907) Hence my opinion is that we must resist this temptation.
('94', 204, 7, 16, 421964) However, I am likely to see the President during the next few days.
('94', 204, 7, 17, 422032) I shall discuss the matter with him and if there is anything to change my view I shall write again.

('94', 205, 7, 8, 422893) circumstances.

('94', 205, 12, 15, 423293) Committee.
('94', 205, 12, 16, 423304) A fearless fighter, Prof.

('94', 205, 20, 28, 423911) that he was a poor man and that though he had opportunities he scrupulously
('94', 205, 21, 29, 423987) maintained his integrity as far as public finances were concerned.

('94', 205, 23, 32, 424157) be administered, men of Prof.

('94', 208, 3, 10, 429105) 220. INTERVIEW WITH LORD MOUNTBATTEN 1
('94', 208, 4, 11, 429144) April 1, 1947
('94', 208, 5, 12, 429158) Gandhiji asked the Viceroy if Manu 2 could in the meantime roam about the
('94', 208, 6, 13, 429232) garden so that they could proceed with their talk uninterrupted.
('94', 208, 7, 14, 429297) “Certainly”, replied the Viceroy.
('94', 208, 7, 15, 429331) Then addressing Manu he added: “All this is
('94', 208, 8, 16, 429375) yours; we are only trustees.
('94', 208, 8, 17, 429404) We have come to make it over to you.” Gandhiji put in
('94', 208, 9, 18, 429458) laughing: You can search her person for any hidden arms.
('94', 208, 10, 19, 429515) “I am perfectly satisfied there can be no need for that in a disciple of yours,” replied the Viceroy with a smile.
('94', 208, 10, 20, 429630) The Viceroy told Gandhiji that it had always been the British policy not to yield anything to force, but the Mahatma’s non violence had won.
('94', 208, 10, 21, 429771) They had decided to quit as a result of India’s non violent struggle.
('94', 208, 10, 22, 429841) Towards the close, on being invited to do so, Gandhiji placed before the astonished Viceroy his solution to the Indian deadlock.
('94', 208, 11, 23, 429970) He reiterated what he had said often before, that he did not mind Jinnah or the Muslim League turning the whole of India into Pakistan, provided it was done by appeal to reason and not under threat of violence.
('94', 208, 11, 24, 430181) But while he had previously held that this could be properly done only after the British had quitted, and while in principle he still adhered to that view, the crux of his present proposal was that he was now prepared under Mountbatten’s umpireship—not as Viceroy but as man—to invite Jinnah to form a government of his choice at the centre and to present his Pakistan plan for acceptance even before the transfer of power.
('94', 208, 11, 25, 430605) The Congress could
('94', 208, 12, 26, 430624) 1 Gandhiji called on the Viceroy at 9 a.m.

('94', 208, 12, 28, 430834) 2 Who along with Brijkrishna Chandiwala had brought in Gandhiji’s lunch 3 For the outline of Gandhiji’s plan, vide “Outline of Draft Agreement”, 4 4 1947

('94', 209, 1, 2, 431030) give its whole hearted support to the Jinnah Government.
('94', 209, 1, 3, 431087) At the same time since the Muslim League would now be the Government, it would have no further excuse for continuing the movements of organized lawlessness, which it had launched in some of the provinces.
('94', 209, 1, 4, 431292) These must be called off.
('94', 209, 1, 5, 431318) Further, since the Viceroy had declared that he was out to do justice only and nothing would be yielded to force, if the League did not accept the offer, the same offer mutatis mutandis should be made to the Congress.
('94', 209, 1, 6, 431536) The old policy of trying to please both the parties must be given up.
('94', 209, 1, 7, 431606) Gandhiji told the Viceroy that the system of British policy of “divide and rule” had brought about a situation in which the only alternative to a continuation of the British rule, which they had found was no longer feasible, was to accept the logic of the “Quit India” demand and retire unconditionally, leaving India to her fate.
('94', 209, 1, 8, 431937) The role of peace–maker in the “communal triangle” which they had themselves helped to create was not for them.

('94', 209, 7, 15, 432397) For the present, he would answer any
('94', 209, 8, 16, 432434) questions that the members might like to put to him.
('94', 209, 9, 17, 432487) In answer to a question whether he believed in the theory of one world and
('94', 209, 10, 18, 432562) whether it would succeed under the present conditions, Gandhiji declared: I would not like to live in this world if it is not to be one world.
('94', 209, 10, 19, 432705) Certainly I should like to see this dream realized in my lifetime.
('94', 209, 10, 20, 432772) I hope that all the representatives who have come here from the different Asian countries will strive their level best to have only one world.
('94', 209, 10, 21, 432915) They will have to think out ways and means for achieving this goal.

('94', 210, 3, 7, 433726) I have really to apologize to you.
('94', 210, 3, 8, 433761) Pandit Nehru had asked me long before this Conference was scheduled to take place whether it would at all be possible for me to attend it.
('94', 210, 3, 9, 433900) It has proved to be a much more important conference than it was expected to be.

('94', 210, 3, 12, 434165) It would have been foreign to my nature to do so.

('94', 210, 3, 16, 434618) I am doubtful whether I can say anything useful but the question is one after my heart.

('94', 210, 3, 18, 434792) It is a great event that for the first time in our history such a conference takes place on the Indian soil.
('94', 210, 3, 19, 434901) I am sorry that I have to refer to the conditions that we see today.
('94', 210, 3, 20, 434970) We do not know how to keep peace between ourselves.

('94', 210, 3, 22, 435124) We think we must resort to the law of the jungle.
('94', 210, 3, 23, 435174) It is an experience which I would not like you to carry to your respective countries.
('94', 210, 3, 24, 435260) I would instead like you to bury it here.
('94', 210, 3, 25, 435302) India is now on the threshold of complete independence.
('94', 210, 3, 26, 435358) India wants to be independent of everybody who wants to own this country.
('94', 210, 3, 27, 435432) We do not want a change of masters.
('94', 210, 3, 28, 435468) We want to be masters on our own soil, though I am not quite sure how it will come about.
('94', 210, 3, 29, 435558) All that we know is that we should do our duty and leave the results in the hands of God and not in the hands of man.
('94', 210, 3, 30, 435676) Man is supposed to be the maker of his destiny.
('94', 210, 3, 31, 435724) It is only partly true.
('94', 210, 3, 32, 435748) He can make his destiny, only in so far as he is allowed by the Great Power which overrides all out intentions, all our plans and carries out His own plans.
('94', 210, 3, 33, 435905) I call that Great Power not by the name of Allah, not by the

('94', 211, 1, 3, 436102) For me, Truth is God and Truth overrides all our plans.
('94', 211, 1, 4, 436158) The whole truth is only embodied within the heart of that Great Power—Truth.
('94', 211, 1, 5, 436235) I was taught from my early days to regard Truth as unapproachable—something that you cannot reach.

('94', 211, 3, 20, 437667) 222. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('94', 211, 4, 21, 437697) NEW DELHI, April 1, 1947
('94', 211, 5, 22, 437722) Today as soon as Manu Gandhi uttered the first word of the Kalma from the Koran a young man stood up, marched right up to the stage where Gandhiji sat and said, “You go away from here.
('94', 211, 5, 23, 437907) This is a Hindu temple where we will not allow a Muslim prayer.
('94', 211, 5, 24, 437971) You have been repeatedly telling this thing to us but our mothers and sisters continue to be slaughtered.
('94', 211, 5, 25, 438077) We cannot tolerate it any longer.” Gandhiji told him: You are free to go.
('94', 211, 5, 26, 438151) If you do not want to pray let the others do
('94', 212, 0, 1, 438196) VOL. 94: 17 FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947 213
('94', 212, 1, 2, 438242) This place does not belong to you.
('94', 212, 1, 3, 438277) This is not the right way.
('94', 212, 2, 4, 438304) You did not do the right thing.
('94', 212, 2, 5, 438336) You forcibly removed the young man from the meeting.
('94', 212, 2, 6, 438389) You should not have done such a thing.
('94', 212, 2, 7, 438428) It would give him a sense of triumph.
('94', 212, 2, 8, 438466) He was very excited.
('94', 212, 2, 9, 438487) He did not wish to listen to the prayer.
('94', 212, 2, 10, 438528) But I know that you all wish to listen to it.
('94', 212, 2, 11, 438574) I do not wish to hold the prayer in spite of protests.
('94', 212, 2, 12, 438629) Now I intend to give up the rest of the prayer.
('94', 212, 2, 13, 438677) You are all familiar with the prayer I offer.
('94', 212, 2, 14, 438723) You have heard it even before I went to Noakhali.
('94', 212, 2, 15, 438773) In my sequence of prayers, the Muslim prayer is followed by the Parsi prayer.
('94', 212, 2, 16, 438851) After that this girl would have sung to you a bhajan in her melodious voice and then there would have been Ramdhun.
('94', 212, 2, 17, 438967) But now I am leaving out the Parsi prayer and also the Ramdhun.
('94', 212, 2, 18, 439031) Auz o Billahi is the beginning of one of the verses of the Koran.
('94', 212, 2, 19, 439097) You think that uttering this expression is an insult to Hinduism.
('94', 212, 2, 20, 439163) But I am a true sanatani Hindu.
('94', 212, 2, 21, 439195) My Hinduism tells me that along with the Hindu prayer I should also offer the Muslim prayer and the Parsi and Christian prayers.
('94', 212, 2, 22, 439324) True Hinduism lies in offering prayers of all religions because only he is a good Hindu who is also a good Muslim and a good Parsi.
('94', 212, 2, 23, 439456) The young man said that this was a Hindu temple and such prayers could not be held here.
('94', 212, 2, 24, 439545) But that is wild talk.
('94', 212, 2, 25, 439568) This temple belongs to the Bhangis.
('94', 212, 2, 26, 439604) Even a single Bhangi can throw me out of this place if he so desires.
('94', 212, 2, 27, 439674) But these people love me.
('94', 212, 2, 28, 439700) They know that I am a Hindu.
('94', 212, 2, 29, 439729) Jugal Kishore Birla, on the other hand, is my brother.
('94', 212, 2, 30, 439784) He is a big man in terms of money but he regards me an elder.
('94', 212, 2, 31, 439846) He has put me up here because he considers me a pious HIndu.
('94', 212, 2, 32, 439907) He also takes me to the big temple built by him.
('94', 212, 2, 33, 439956) If in spite of all this the young man insists that I should go away and I cannot pray here, it is merely his arrogance.
('94', 212, 2, 34, 440076) But you should have won him over with love.
('94', 212, 2, 35, 440120) You threw him out by force.
('94', 212, 2, 36, 440148) What is the point in offering prayers by resorting to force?
('94', 212, 2, 37, 440209) The young man was in a rage and in his anger was talking wild things.
('94', 212, 2, 38, 440279) It was out of such talk that all those things happened in the Punjab.
('94', 212, 2, 39, 440349) This rage is what starts all the fanaticism.

('94', 222, 9, 13, 461465) April 3, 1947 We must project ourselves in a better light in foreign countries.

('94', 222, 9, 18, 461913) We must live as simply as possible, conforming to our way of life.
('94', 222, 9, 19, 461980) If we do this, we shall be able to impress the people there and enhance our country’s glory.
('94', 222, 9, 20, 462073) We should demonstrate to them the advantages of our way of life.
('94', 222, 9, 21, 462138) What is the true meaning of appointing our ambassadors in those countries or their ambassadors in our country?

('94', 222, 9, 23, 462445) Such mutually advantageous exchanges would spread friendliness which in turn would promote world peace, and this

('94', 227, 7, 37, 473640) 231. OUTLINE OF DRAFT AGREEMENT 1
('94', 227, 8, 38, 473674) April 4, 19472
('94', 227, 9, 39, 473689) 1. Mr. Jinnah to be given the option of forming a Cabinet.
('94', 227, 9, 40, 473748) 2. The selection of the Cabinet is left entirely to Mr. Jinnah.
('94', 227, 9, 41, 473812) The members may be all Muslims, or all non Muslims, or they may be
('94', 227, 10, 42, 473879) 1 At the end of his interview with the Viceroy on April 4, Gandhiji dictated this to Lord Ismay, Chief of Staff.
('94', 227, 10, 43, 473992) Vide “Letter to Lord Ismay”, 5 4 1947 and “Interview with Lord Mountbatten”, 4 4 1947 2 ibid
('94', 228, 0, 1, 474085) VOL. 94: 17 FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947 229
('94', 228, 1, 2, 474131) representatives of all classes and creeds of the Indian people.
('94', 228, 1, 3, 474195) 3. If Mr. Jinnah accepted this offer, the Congress would guarantee to co operate freely and sincerely, so long as all the measures that Mr. Jinnah’s Cabinet bring forward are in the interests of the Indian people as a whole.
