('94', 387, 2, 3, 804645) PATNA, April 26, 1947
('94', 387, 3, 4, 804667) SUSHILA,
('94', 387, 4, 5, 804676) I have been working under such heavy pressure that I could not find time even to write a letter to you and send it with Sita.
('94', 387, 4, 6, 804802) I meant to write yesterday but could not.
('94', 387, 4, 7, 804844) I read just now Manilal’s letter which you had sent to Kishorelal and which the latter had for warded to me.
('94', 387, 4, 8, 804953) Such is my condition.
('94', 387, 4, 9, 804975) God, however, has preserved my health so far and will preserve it as long as He wants to take work from me.
('94', 387, 4, 10, 805083) Since Sita had come and met me, she herself told me that there was no need for me to write a letter, but that an oral message would suffice.
('94', 387, 4, 11, 805224) I agreed with her.
('94', 387, 4, 12, 805243) I have discussed the matter with her as fully as possible.
('94', 387, 4, 13, 805302) There is no need whatever for you to worry about her.
('94', 387, 4, 14, 805356) You must have seen the letter she wrote to Krishnakumar and the one I wrote to him.
('94', 387, 4, 15, 805440) You will learn everything from them.
('94', 387, 4, 16, 805477) Please therefore do not worry about her at all.
('94', 387, 4, 17, 805525) And as Kishorelal suggests, it is now desirable that you should go and join Manilal.
('94', 387, 4, 18, 805610) If you wish, you may come and see me.
('94', 387, 4, 19, 805648) I shall have to go to Delhi on May 2. You may come and see me there if you like.
('94', 387, 4, 20, 805729) But it is very hot now.
('94', 387, 4, 21, 805753) If you wish to escape the heat and don’t wish to come, you may not.
('94', 387, 4, 22, 805821) We may discuss the more important problems through correspondence and should be satisfied with that.
('94', 387, 4, 23, 805922) I am returning Manilal’s letter.
('94', 387, 4, 24, 805955) My heart endorses the different view which you two have taken.
('94', 387, 4, 25, 806018) Since I am the property of the masses, they have a perfect right to search me inside out.
('94', 387, 4, 26, 806108) But, even so, if the masses seek to press their point of view on me, I would feel suffocated.
('94', 387, 4, 27, 806202) About Kishorelal and others it is a different matter.
('94', 387, 4, 28, 806256) They are, after all, co workers who seek guidance from me.
('94', 387, 4, 29, 806315) If they disapprove of any action or views of mine today, they should have the right to discuss them fully.
('94', 387, 4, 30, 806422) The painful thing in this matter is that their approach and mine to the question seem different.
('94', 387, 4, 31, 806519) Conduct based on such [different] approach is bound to be at variance [with their views] and cannot but give pain.
('94', 387, 4, 32, 806634) My ideas and conduct are not new.
('94', 387, 4, 33, 806668) I can say that they go back to fifty five years ago.
('94', 387, 4, 34, 806721) It is possible that I might not have been able to express my ideas clearly in my writings or talks.
('94', 388, 0, 1, 806821) VOL. 94: 17 FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947 389
('94', 388, 1, 2, 806867) I don’t say positively that I have written on the subject, only because if I could spare the time to go over all my writings I might be able to quote the statements I have made from time to time.
('94', 388, 1, 3, 807063) But what is to be gained by doing so?
('94', 388, 1, 4, 807101) The action has already been abandoned for the present.
('94', 388, 1, 5, 807156) As for my views, Kishorelal and I have been discussing them [through letters].
('94', 388, 1, 6, 807235) That discussion need not be stopped, nor need it upset anybody.
('94', 388, 1, 7, 807299) If there is any error in my reasoning, the discussion may help to remove it.
('94', 388, 1, 8, 807376) Or, if there is no possibility of either of us changing his view, we will put up with the difference in our views and also in our conduct.
('94', 388, 1, 9, 807515) I am hopeful that that will not be the outcome.
('94', 388, 1, 10, 807563) One or the other will correct his error and both will come to the same view.
('94', 388, 1, 11, 807640) I am hoping, however, that Kishorelal and others who are non co operating with me partially will withdraw their non co operation.
('94', 388, 1, 12, 807770) I hope you are all unperturbed.

('94', 389, 2, 3, 808816) April 26, 1947 I have gone through your report 1. If it had been a statement expressing your personal views I would have complimented you and would have made some important suggestions too.
('94', 389, 2, 4, 809006) You are a great economist and a learned man and you are running a flourishing business.
('94', 389, 2, 5, 809094) But I know more about village industries.
('94', 389, 2, 6, 809136) Hence we have proceeded on the understanding that I am qualified to instruct you.
('94', 389, 2, 7, 809218) Even if there were no such understanding, I, at any rate, have proceeded on that assumption.
('94', 389, 2, 8, 809311) In doing so I have not been prompted by my ego.
('94', 389, 2, 9, 809359) But such is the situation today.
('94', 389, 2, 10, 809392) What I have read concerns the Committee appointed by the Government of Bombay, and you are presiding over it.
('94', 389, 2, 11, 809502) From that point of view I have much to say about the statement.

('94', 389, 2, 16, 809861) Pyarelal too has not been writing for it.
('94', 389, 2, 17, 809903) I do not approve of the very resolution which has led to the appointment of the Committee.
('94', 389, 2, 18, 809994) In my view Lakshmidas 5 and Dhotre cannot function under that resolution.
('94', 389, 2, 19, 810068) Before passing the resolution the Government of Bombay should have consulted the Charkha Sangh, the Gramodyog Sangh and the Hindustani Talimi Sangh.
('94', 389, 2, 20, 810217) You are probably not aware that all these three organizations have the backing of the Congress and are known as Congress organizations.
('94', 389, 2, 21, 810353) No other organization in India has or is likely to have more experience in the field of village industries.
('94', 389, 2, 22, 810461) But I still cannot say how such a mistake could happen.
('94', 389, 2, 23, 810517) Considering your intelligence I feel that you ought to have stopped Lakshmidas and Dhotre from signing the report.

('94', 389, 2, 25, 810827) This is what has happened with regard to this report.
('94', 389, 2, 26, 810881) At the moment I am not in a position to suggest anything more.
('94', 389, 2, 27, 810944) If you have the courage I

('94', 393, 4, 9, 815413) 397. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('94', 393, 5, 10, 815443) PATNA, April 26, 1947
('94', 393, 6, 11, 815465) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, Since I have to visit the Muslim brethren I do not wish to give you the whole of my time today.
('94', 393, 6, 12, 815583) You must have heard of Maulana Shafi Daudi.
('94', 393, 6, 13, 815627) I came to know about him when I had come to Bihar for the first time.
('94', 393, 6, 14, 815697) Later I went to his house also.
('94', 393, 6, 15, 815729) On his invitation I have promised to attend a meeting of the Jamiat e Islam.
('94', 393, 6, 16, 815806) I therefore wish to leave early.
('94', 393, 6, 17, 815839) Please remember what I told you about the cow yesterday.
('94', 393, 6, 18, 815896) I told the goshala people who came to see me today that they should all come to me together.
('94', 393, 6, 19, 815989) Then I would tell them what could be done to improve the breed of the cow.
('94', 393, 6, 20, 816064) They too agree that the condition of the cow anywhere in India is not as bad as in Bihar.
('94', 393, 6, 21, 816154) This is an exaggeration, for the condition of cattle in some other parts of India is found to be worse than in Bihar.
('94', 393, 6, 22, 816272) All the same, according to me, it would suffice to say that the condition of cattle in India is the worst in the whole world.
('94', 393, 6, 23, 816398) This is a matter of great shame and a blot on us since we call the cow our mother and worship her.
('94', 393, 6, 24, 816497) If we had been following our dharma India’s name would not have been tarnished.
('94', 393, 6, 25, 816577) We must remove this blot.
('94', 393, 6, 26, 816603) I hope you will think over what I have told you, for I shall say no more today.

('94', 396, 5, 23, 820397) GANDHI CAMP, PATNA, April 27, 1947 Now we can hope that India is shortly going to become free.
('94', 396, 5, 24, 820492) If women were to make a resolve, they could demonstrate the remarkable strength bestowed on them by God.
('94', 396, 5, 25, 820597) And it is essential for it that you should pray daily.
('94', 396, 5, 26, 820652) But today prayer has come to be regarded either as a pastime of old women or of those who have retired from life.
('94', 396, 5, 27, 820766) And I can quote such instances where young men and women regard prayer, bhajans or discourses as something ridiculous and worthless.
('94', 396, 5, 28, 820899) This has led to our present degeneration.
('94', 396, 5, 29, 820941) But if we can understand the secret of prayer, we would realize its wonderful power.
('94', 396, 5, 30, 821026) Our indepen dence will be stable if we attain it through prayer.
('94', 396, 5, 31, 821091) But spiritually in clined men and women should also

('94', 397, 1, 2, 821213) understand the secret of non violence.
('94', 397, 1, 3, 821252) We should realize that if our non violence is the non violence of the weak, our independence will not be stable.
('94', 397, 1, 4, 821365) And it will further prove that we cannot protect ourselves even with weapons, for we have neither arms nor training in their use.
('94', 397, 1, 5, 821495) We have the wonderful and unrivalled weapon of truth and non violence.
('94', 397, 1, 6, 821566) Not only for winning freedom but also for preserving it there is no alternative to ahimsa.
('94', 397, 1, 7, 821657) Those who regard us as their enemies, can be won over by love and non violence alone.
('94', 397, 1, 8, 821743) Women can easily accomplish this.
('94', 397, 1, 9, 821777) Let me give a simple example.
('94', 397, 1, 10, 821807) You marry your daughter aged fourteen, fifteen or sixteen into a strange new family and hand her over to a stranger; the girl becomes one with the new family or after a short while even becomes the mistress of that household.
('94', 397, 1, 11, 822033) How does this happen?
('94', 397, 1, 12, 822055) God has blessed her with a loving heart.
('94', 397, 1, 13, 822096) She can win over everyone with her love, affection and non violence.
('94', 397, 1, 14, 822165) This is our every day experience.
('94', 397, 1, 15, 822199) Similarly in the larger context of society, if you learn to treat your Hindu sisters as your friends and try to emulate their good qualities they will certainly reciprocate.
('94', 397, 1, 16, 822373) Women have the remarkable capacity for sacrifice.
('94', 397, 1, 17, 822423) Under varying situations in life and in order to advance or strengthen your country you should learn to efface the self and meet death bravely with prayer in your heart, whenever the occasion demands it.
('94', 397, 1, 18, 822627) In order to cultivate the courage to meet death, prayer is the first and the last mantra of the art of dying.
('94', 397, 1, 19, 822737) Implicit faith is essential for it.
('94', 397, 1, 20, 822773) Without faith, no satyagrahi can ever succeed.
('94', 397, 1, 21, 822820) Rama, Rahim, God or Allah—call Him by any name you like, His Law is universal.
('94', 397, 1, 22, 822899) Think over what I have said.
('94', 397, 1, 23, 822928) You have come in purdah but the real meaning of observing purdah is that you should guard against lust, anger and attachment.
('94', 397, 1, 24, 823054) That is, one has to exercise restraint over oneself.
('94', 397, 1, 25, 823107) This outward purdah is mere hypocrisy.
('94', 397, 1, 26, 823146) Its observance is meaningless if one’s heart is impure.

('94', 399, 4, 8, 826255) April 27, 1947
('94', 399, 5, 9, 826270) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, The bhajan 1 you heard just now was sung before also.
('94', 399, 5, 10, 826346) I want to give you something of the background of this bhajan.
('94', 399, 5, 11, 826409) It first echoed in my ears when I went on a fast while in jail.
('94', 399, 5, 12, 826473) But while fasting one’s memory becomes weak.
('94', 399, 5, 13, 826518) None of my co workers remembered the bhajan fully either.
('94', 399, 5, 14, 826576) And so I sent a telegram and the bhajan was sent to me telegraphically in the Roman script.
('94', 399, 5, 15, 826668) The bhajan delighted me so much that I forgot my fast.
('94', 399, 5, 16, 826723) My grandson Kanu was with me at the time.
('94', 399, 5, 17, 826765) At my request he sang it for me.
('94', 399, 5, 18, 826798) There is nothing special about this bhajan by Tulsidas.
('94', 399, 5, 19, 826854) He only says that he lives by two syllables 2. Everything, he says, is accomplished only with the help of Rama.
('94', 399, 5, 20, 826966) All other gods are amenable to offerings.
('94', 399, 5, 21, 827008) For, when people go to worship the deities they offer a couple of pice before offering their prayers.
('94', 399, 5, 22, 827110) The mother of a sick child offers a little money before praying for the recovery of her child.
('94', 399, 5, 23, 827205) Another woman offers money to Lord Mahadeva pleading to be spared the nightmares she goes through.
('94', 399, 5, 24, 827304) Some other woman who has too many daughters prays for a son.
('94', 399, 5, 25, 827365) But all this is futile.
('94', 399, 5, 26, 827389) Tulsidas says that God needs no flattery.
('94', 399, 5, 27, 827431) I told you yesterday that I was going to a meeting of Muslims.
('94', 399, 5, 28, 827494) It was a function of Jamiat e Islam.

('94', 400, 1, 17, 829213) Although there are many other epics in India they are not so steeped in devotion.
('94', 400, 1, 18, 829295) On seeing an image of Krishna, Tulsidas is believed to have said: “Tulsi’s head would bow down to you only if you take up the bow and arrow 1.” He was a devotee of Rama.
('94', 400, 1, 19, 829465) Hence he insisted that he would bow to Krishna only if he appeared before him in the form of Rama.
('94', 400, 1, 20, 829564) Even you, if you are worshippers of Rama, should love everyone.
('94', 400, 1, 21, 829628) There was a time when it used to be said that if one wanted to know what true religion was, one should visit India.
('94', 400, 1, 22, 829744) That was because the Hindus did not kill anyone.
('94', 400, 1, 23, 829793) But now there are robbers, dacoits and also murderers among the Hindus.

('94', 401, 3, 7, 830465) 405. A NOTE
('94', 401, 4, 8, 830477) PATNA, April 28, 1947 I have read the note left with me by Mr. Houlton 1 .
('94', 401, 4, 9, 830552) I am quite clear in my mind that those Muslims in the affected areas who by reason of fear or the distressing memory of their dead kinsmen do not wish to return to their homes should have the option of settling where they like even outside Bihar against compensation being given to them for loss of land and tenements, which will revert to the State.
('94', 401, 4, 10, 830903) Compensation will consist of the sum fixed by valuators at the present rates of land and habitable tenements in place of those destroyed by the rioters.
('94', 401, 4, 11, 831056) The valuation of the tenements must not exceed Rs. 1,000 at the outside.
('94', 401, 4, 12, 831129) The above having been conceived purely in the interests of the sufferers, it presumes every previous effort being made by the State to dispel all fear of repetition of tragedy by adequate police protection and ridding the place of known marauders, etc.
('94', 401, 5, 13, 831382) M. K. GANDHI
('94', 401, 6, 14, 831395) From a photostat: C. W. 10561

('94', 404, 7, 16, 836469) 411. ADVICE TO STUDENTS
('94', 404, 8, 17, 836493) PATNA, April 28, 1947
('94', 404, 9, 18, 836515) If we could shake off our lethargy we would be true socialists.
('94', 404, 9, 19, 836579) But we haven’t yet done that.
('94', 404, 9, 20, 836609) If I were to ask you I am sure to get the reply that all fifteen of you have servants in your homes.
('94', 404, 10, 21, 836710) Well, then I fail to understand your desire to serve others — which you call socialism—when you do not do your own personal work in your homes.
('94', 404, 10, 22, 836854) If you want my advice, I may tell you that students while they are studying should not involve themselves in any ism.
('94', 404, 10, 23, 836972) They may by all means read about every school of thought, think over it, put as much of it into practice as possible, but they should not endeavour to become leaders.
('94', 404, 10, 24, 837139) If we want to banish exploitation and violence from our society, we ought to do body labour and manual work.
('94', 404, 10, 25, 837248) And naturally it ought to be undertaken by all.
('94', 404, 10, 26, 837296) Unemployment is rampant in our villages which were [once] regarded as happy and self sufficient units; this is because of our subjugation and feelings of high and low as also caste distinctions.
('94', 404, 11, 27, 837491) 1 All the fifteen students replied in the affirmative.
('94', 405, 0, 1, 837546) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 406
('94', 405, 1, 2, 837588) Our political slavery is now nearly coming to an end.
('94', 405, 1, 3, 837642) Hence we now need to become all the more vigilant and in this process the students can prove very helpful.
('94', 405, 1, 4, 837749) For example, (1) when you get up in the morning you can roll up your own bedding; (2) help in preparing your breakfast and milk, etc., whatever you take, without waiting for your mother or anyone else to prepare it and serve you; (3) give a helping hand in sweeping and scrubbing; (4) do your own laundering; (5) help your mother with the cooking and cleaning the dishes; (6) make your own cloth by spinning regularly every day; (7) keep your books clean and neatly arranged, economize on exercise books as much as possible; (8) learn to do with a pen holder and ink costing two annas, instead of a fountain pen costing Rs. 50. If you adopt a number of such rules in your life you will not need to bother with any ism.
('94', 405, 1, 5, 838468) And if every student in the country does it, I am sure the guardians’ burden will be lightened a thousand times and without making any other effort we will be called socialists.
('94', 405, 1, 6, 838646) But I doubt if you will follow what I say.
('94', 405, 1, 7, 838689) All the same, when you return home please reflect if there is any sense in the few lines that this experienced old fellow wrote out for you on his day of silence.
('94', 405, 2, 8, 838852) [From Gujarati]
('94', 405, 3, 9, 838868) Biharni Komi Agman, pp.
('94', 405, 4, 10, 838892) 412. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('94', 405, 5, 11, 838924) PATNA, April 28, 1947
('94', 405, 6, 12, 838946) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('94', 405, 7, 13, 838968) I am sorry to let you know that I shall have to go to Delhi by the morning train the day after tomorrow.
('94', 405, 7, 14, 839073) There is a call from Pandit Nehru.
('94', 405, 7, 15, 839108) Congress President Shri Kripalani has also sent a telegram from Rajputana that I should be in Delhi by the first of May.
('94', 405, 7, 16, 839229) The Congress Working Committee is to meet there the next day.
('94', 405, 7, 17, 839291) It pains me to have to leave you at this stage.
('94', 405, 7, 18, 839339) I do not relish the idea of leaving Bihar unless the Mussalmans have completely shed their fear and both the communities allow me to leave cheerfully.
('94', 405, 7, 19, 839490) I felt the same thing when I left Noakhali.
('94', 405, 7, 20, 839534) For both these places I have the same motto before me “Do or Die”.
('94', 405, 7, 21, 839601) The cause in both the places is the same.
('94', 405, 8, 22, 839643) 1 It being his day of silence, Gandhiji’s written speech was read out.
('94', 406, 0, 1, 839714) VOL. 94: 17 FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947. 407
('94', 406, 1, 2, 839761) non violence bids me dedicate myself to the service of the minorities.
('94', 406, 1, 3, 839832) It would be a new birth for me and would give me new strength if the Hindus and the Mussalmans of both these places become friends and shed their animosity.
('94', 406, 1, 4, 839989) God alone knows what will happen ultimately.
('94', 406, 1, 5, 840034) Man can only try and perish in the attempt to do God’s work.
('94', 406, 1, 6, 840095) God is all in all.
('94', 406, 1, 7, 840114) We are only zeroes.
('94', 406, 1, 8, 840134) The same mission takes me to Delhi, that is, to work for Hindus and Muslims.
('94', 406, 1, 9, 840211) I hope to return within a short time and be among you.
('94', 406, 1, 10, 840266) You may be astonished to learn that I continue to receive letters charging me with having compromised the interests of the Hindus by acting as a friend of the Muslims.
('94', 406, 1, 11, 840434) How can I carry conviction with the people by mere words if the sixty years of my public life have failed to convince them that by trying to befriend Muslims I have only proved myself a true Hindu and have rightly served the Hindus and Hinduism?
('94', 406, 1, 12, 840680) The essence of true religious teaching is that one should serve and befriend all and should be enemy of none.
('94', 406, 1, 13, 840790) I learnt this in my mother’s lap.
('94', 406, 1, 14, 840824) You may refuse to call me a Hindu.
('94', 406, 1, 15, 840859) I would only quote a line from Iqbal’s famous song which means “Religion does not teach us to bear ill will towards one another”.
('94', 406, 1, 16, 840989) 1 It is easy enough to be friendly to one’s friends, but to befriend the one who regards himself as your enemy is true religion.
('94', 406, 1, 17, 841118) All else is mere business.

('94', 407, 1, 2, 841237) 413. REMARK TO MANU GANDHI 1
('94', 407, 2, 3, 841266) GANDHI CAMP, PATNA, April 28, 1947
('94', 407, 3, 4, 841301) How can we afford to forget the charkha?
('94', 407, 3, 5, 841342) The spirit behind spinning implies equality of all.
('94', 407, 3, 6, 841394) The charkha teaches us the unique lesson of identifying ourselves with the forty crores and be in perfect harmony with them.
('94', 407, 3, 7, 841519) It will not admit of any distinction of high and low, master and servant, which is the cause of conflict in the world today, isn’t it?
('94', 407, 3, 8, 841654) The charkha warns us against it.
('94', 407, 3, 9, 841687) How can we, therefore, fail to worship God in the form of the charkha?

('94', 408, 3, 5, 843441) 415. LETTER TO MANILAL GANDHI
('94', 408, 4, 6, 843471) PATNA, April 29, 1947
('94', 408, 5, 7, 843493) MANILAL,
('94', 408, 6, 8, 843502) Yesterday I got your letter of the 14th.
('94', 408, 6, 9, 843543) Who knows when the final deluge will come?
('94', 408, 6, 10, 843586) Sooner or later that day also will come.
('94', 408, 6, 11, 843627) Why need we worry whether, when it does come, one or two will have survived or all will have perished?
('94', 408, 6, 12, 843730) If we but do our duty from moment to moment, we shall be able to face the Supreme Judge.
('94', 408, 6, 13, 843819) I think Sushila will now join you at the earliest opportunity.
('94', 408, 6, 14, 843882) If Sita keeps her promise, four or five years will soon pass.
('94', 408, 6, 15, 843944) I think she will keep her promise.
('94', 408, 6, 16, 843979) I will look after her.
('94', 408, 6, 17, 844002) None of you, therefore, need worry about her.
('94', 408, 6, 18, 844048) I should, of course, be very happy if you could live on boiled vegetables and fruit.
('94', 408, 6, 19, 844133) It should be quite easy to do without ghee, oil and butter, since you eat curds.
('94', 408, 6, 20, 844214) If you eat them in sufficient quantity, together with vegetables and fruit they make a balanced diet.
('94', 408, 6, 21, 844316) That diet will sustain your energy and keep your brain perfectly clear.
('94', 408, 6, 22, 844388) The vegetables and fruit to be consumed should be properly selected.
('94', 408, 6, 23, 844457) Do you eat dry fruit or nuts?
('94', 408, 6, 24, 844487) If you do, which ones?
('94', 408, 6, 25, 844510) I shall be happy if you write to me in detail, for am I not taking special interest in nature cure?
('94', 408, 6, 26, 844610) This diet must make a change in your complexion too.
('94', 408, 6, 27, 844663) Dadoo and Naicker have not called again.
('94', 408, 6, 28, 844704) I am leaving for Delhi tomorrow.
('94', 408, 6, 29, 844737) Perhaps they may look me up there.

('94', 411, 4, 7, 847183) But I do feel that I have come nearer to God and Truth.
('94', 411, 4, 8, 847239) It has cost me quite a few of my old friends but I do not regret it.
('94', 411, 4, 9, 847308) To me it is a sign of my having come nearer to God.
('94', 411, 4, 10, 847360) That is why I can write and speak frankly to everyone.
('94', 411, 4, 11, 847415) I have successfully practised the eleven vows undertaken by me.
('94', 411, 4, 12, 847479) This is the culmination of my striving for the last sixty years.
('94', 411, 4, 13, 847544) You have become an instrument in this.
('94', 411, 4, 14, 847583) In this yajna I got a glimpse of the ideal of truth and purity for which I had been aspiring.
('94', 411, 4, 15, 847677) And you have fully contributed towards it.
('94', 411, 4, 16, 847720) Still, being so young, you cannot at present realize the implications of this yajna.
('94', 411, 4, 17, 847805) I daily go through your diary which reminds me of Mahadev.
('94', 411, 4, 18, 847864) Seeing what you write and study these days and the ability you have to understand the yajna I feel that had Mahadev been alive this girl would have developed differently.
('94', 411, 4, 19, 848035) I can’t give you enough time much as I would like to.
('94', 411, 4, 20, 848089) Mahadev surpassed me in certain qualities.
('94', 411, 4, 21, 848132) Since no one is accompanying me during the walk today, I had the time to tell you all this.

('94', 412, 0, 1, 848263) VOL. 94: 17 FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947. 413
('94', 412, 1, 2, 848310) 420. DISCUSSION AT PEACE COMMITTEE MEETING 1
('94', 412, 2, 3, 848355) PATNA, April 29, 1947
('94', 412, 3, 4, 848377) Q. What should be the attitude of the Peace Committee towards the culprits who have not been arrested and those who are under suspicion?
('94', 412, 3, 5, 848514) Should the workers of the Committee co operate in getting such persons arrested and prosecuted and in carrying on the investigations ?
('94', 412, 4, 6, 848649) GANDHIJI: The duty of the Peace Committee is to supply all the information to the authorities.
('94', 412, 4, 7, 848744) If the officers are corrupt the Ministers should be informed.
('94', 412, 4, 8, 848806) The matter should be brought to the notice of the Press.
('94', 412, 4, 9, 848863) Let those who have seen with their own eyes murders or other criminal acts being committed give the culprits’ names to the police.
('94', 412, 4, 10, 848994) The members of the Peace Committee could even try to reform the offender and persuade him to go to the police and confess his crime.
('94', 412, 4, 11, 849127) The Government should take public opinion into consideration.
('94', 412, 4, 12, 849189) Suhrawardy Saheb says that the police who are the eyes and ears of the Government do not report any untoward incident, whatever Satis Babu might say.
('94', 412, 4, 13, 849339) I say that the police are the deaf ears and blind eyes of the Government.
('94', 412, 4, 14, 849413) It is our task to awaken the police.
('94', 412, 4, 15, 849450) If in the face of arson, murder and abduction of women an officer maintains that for want of evidence culprits cannot be arrested he deserves to be dismissed.
('94', 412, 4, 16, 849609) How can a helpless victim produce any evidence?
('94', 412, 4, 17, 849657) And if anybody says that he himself set his house on fire, it is sheer nonsense.
('94', 412, 4, 18, 849738) Would the poor man burn his own house?
('94', 412, 4, 19, 849777) He is too terror stricken to do so.
('94', 412, 4, 20, 849813) If the Government were not to trust public opinion it would mean heavy expenditure and inconvenience.
('94', 412, 4, 21, 849915) It would then need C.I.D. men in large numbers.
('94', 412, 4, 22, 849963) That is the way of the alien Government.
('94', 412, 4, 23, 850004) Under a swadeshi government the people are the C.I.D. for the government.
('94', 412, 4, 24, 850078) If there is popular rule there would be fewer rogues.
('94', 412, 4, 25, 850132) Otherwise, the Government would be in the hands of rogues.
('94', 412, 4, 26, 850191) A government full of rogues can also function, but where I cannot say.
('94', 412, 4, 27, 850262) Even the Congress Government can turn out to be such a government.
('94', 412, 5, 28, 850329) 1 The meeting held at Gandhiji’s camp in the evening was attended among others by Sarju Prasad, Secretary, Peace Committee.
('94', 413, 0, 1, 850453) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 414
('94', 413, 1, 2, 850495) You have mentioned lack of workers for the Peace Committee.
('94', 413, 1, 3, 850555) It only means that we have no influence over the masses.
('94', 413, 1, 4, 850612) And if we haven’t, what is the reason behind it?
('94', 413, 1, 5, 850661) It implies that something is lacking in us.
('94', 413, 1, 6, 850705) And we ought to get over our limitations.
('94', 413, 2, 7, 850747) Q. Occasionally we receive news about trouble in various places.
('94', 413, 2, 8, 850812) Even where there have been no riots people are in panic because of the vitiated atmosphere, and are running away.
('94', 413, 2, 9, 850926) Some mischief mongers have gone into hiding in other places and are misleading the people.
('94', 413, 2, 10, 851017) How should the workers of the Peace Committee proceed under these circumstances ?
('94', 413, 3, 11, 851099) A. Whatever news we receive is not all correct.
('94', 413, 3, 12, 851147) But no doubt there is trouble in some places.
('94', 413, 3, 13, 851193) The Peace Committee should help the Government in every way.
('94', 413, 3, 14, 851254) Most of the people present here would, of course, be Congressmen.
('94', 413, 3, 15, 851320) If so, it is their duty to help the Government.
('94', 413, 3, 16, 851368) And if they do not do so it means that the Government does not have popular support.
('94', 413, 3, 17, 851453) If would be shameful to say that our public opinion reflects a mob mentality.
('94', 413, 3, 18, 851531) It is our duty, not the Government’s, to mould public opinion.
('94', 413, 3, 19, 851594) The Government’s responsibility is to quell the riots and punish the offenders.
('94', 413, 3, 20, 851674) But a government obliged constantly to mete out punishment for every little thing cannot be called a good government.
('94', 413, 3, 21, 851792) If some work could be done in the riot affected areas, things would settle down even in places where the situation is tense and people are fleeing in panic.
('94', 413, 3, 22, 851949) Vitiated atmosphere implies that we have not done our duty well.
('94', 413, 3, 23, 852014) It is a function of the Peace Committee to trace the offenders and inform the police.
('94', 413, 3, 24, 852100) If some mischief mongers have gone into hiding in some other places and are misleading the people the members of the Peace Committee should also go and work there.
('94', 413, 3, 25, 852264) I had heard that the [Hindu] Mahasabha President had been giving protection to Mathura Singh.
('94', 413, 3, 26, 852358) The former is the Secretary to the Maharaja of Darbhanga and is a big shot in his own right.
('94', 413, 3, 27, 852451) When he had come to me I had asked him if my information was correct.
('94', 413, 3, 28, 852521) He told me it was not.
('94', 413, 3, 29, 852544) Being President of the Mahasabha how could he do such a thing, he protested.
('94', 413, 4, 30, 852621) Q. People come to us saying that a particular person under arrest is innocent and that we should have him released.
('94', 413, 4, 31, 852737) What should we do in such matters ?
('94', 413, 5, 32, 852773) A. If innocent persons happen to be arrested, you can arrange legal help for them.
('94', 414, 0, 1, 852856) VOL. 94: 17 FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947. 415
('94', 414, 1, 2, 852903) Q. How far can the Government help the Peace Committee in its work ?
('94', 414, 2, 3, 852972) A. The Government can give financial help to the Peace Committee.
('94', 414, 2, 4, 853038) But such help would be given not for everything but for what the Government considers proper.
('94', 414, 2, 5, 853132) The Government’s resources are limited.
('94', 414, 2, 6, 853172) If the Government is not discreet in disbursing help we have to bring it to their notice.
('94', 414, 2, 7, 853262) But necessities have got to be provided by the Government and whatever they cannot provide, should be arranged for by the Peace Committee.
('94', 414, 2, 8, 853401) This is a function of private charity.
('94', 414, 2, 9, 853440) The Friends’ mission 1 is functioning along these lines.
('94', 414, 2, 10, 853497) They are working in the places where the Government cannot reach.
('94', 414, 2, 11, 853563) The work of the Friends’ mission can serve as a model for us.
('94', 414, 2, 12, 853625) They have done a good deal of work in Midnapore and Noakhali.

('94', 418, 3, 4, 860437) CLEMENT ATTLEE’S STATEMENT 1
('94', 418, 4, 5, 860466) February 20, 1947
('94', 418, 5, 6, 860484) It has long been the policy of successive British Governments to work towards the realization of self government in India.
('94', 418, 5, 7, 860607) In pursuance of this policy, an increasing measure of responsibility has been devolved on Indians, and today the civil administration and the Indian armed forces rely, to a very large extent, on Indian civilians and officers.
('94', 418, 5, 8, 860833) In the constitutional field, the Acts of 1919 and 1935 passed by the British Parliament, each represented a substantial transfer of political power.
('94', 418, 5, 9, 860982) In 1940, the Coalition Government recognized the principle that Indians should themselves frame a new constitution for a fully autonomous India and, in the offer of 1942, they invited them to set up a Constituent Assembly for this purpose as soon as the war was over.
('94', 418, 6, 10, 861250) The declaration of the Prime Minister of 15th March last, which met with general approval in Parliament and the country, made it clear that it was for the Indian people themselves to choose their future status and constitution and that, in the opinion of His Majesty’s Government, the time had come for responsibility for the Government of India to pass into Indian hands.
('94', 418, 7, 11, 861623) The Cabinet Mission .
('94', 418, 7, 12, 861645) proposals, made public in May last, envisaged that the future Constitution of India should be settled by a Constituent Assembly composed in the manner suggested therein, of representatives of all communities and interests in British India and of the Indian States.
('94', 418, 8, 13, 861910) Since the return of the Mission, an Interim Government has been set up at the Centre.
('94', 418, 8, 14, 861996) In all the Provinces, Indian Governments, responsible to legislatures, are in office.
('94', 418, 9, 15, 862082) His Majesty’s Government are anxious to hand over their responsibilities to a government which, resting on the sure foundation of the support of the people, is capable of maintaining peace and administering India with justice and efficiency.
('94', 418, 9, 16, 862324) It is therefore essential that all parties should sink their differences, in order that they may be ready to shoulder the great responsibilities which will come upon them next year.
('94', 418, 9, 17, 862506) Cabinet Mission .
('94', 418, 9, 18, 862524) obtained .
('94', 418, 9, 19, 862535) the method by which a Constitution
('94', 418, 10, 20, 862570) 1 Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 23 2 1947. Only extracts are reproduced here.
('94', 419, 0, 1, 862651) 420 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('94', 419, 1, 2, 862693) should be worked out.
('94', 419, 1, 3, 862715) His Majesty’s Government there agreed to re commend to Parliament a constitution worked out in accordance with the proposals made therein by a fully representative Constituent Assembly.
('94', 419, 1, 4, 862901) But if it should appear that such a constitution will not have been worked out by a fully representative Assembly, before the time mentioned in paragraph 7, His Majesty’s Government will have to consider to whom the powers of the Central Government in British India should be handed over, on the due date, whether as a whole to some form of Central Government for British India or, in some areas, to the existing Provincial Governments, or in such other way as may seem most reasonable and in the best interests of the Indian people.
('94', 419, 2, 5, 863435) Although the final transfer of authority may not take place until June 1948, preparatory measures must be put in hand in advance.
('94', 419, 2, 6, 863565) It is important that the efficiency of the civil administration should be maintained and that the defence of India should be fully provided for.
('94', 419, 2, 7, 863710) But, inevitably, as the process of transfer proceeds, it will become progressively more difficult to carry out, to the letter, all the provisions of the Government of India Act of 1935. Legislation will be introduced in due course to give effect to the final transfer of power.
('94', 419, 3, 8, 863988) In regard to the Indian States, as was explicitly stated by the Cabinet Mission, His Majesty’s Government do not intend to hand over their powers and obligations under Paramountcy to any government of British India.
('94', 419, 3, 9, 864204) It is not intended to bring Paramountcy, as a system, to a conclusion earlier than the date of the final transfer of power, but it is contemplated that for the intervening period, the relations of the Crown with individual States may be adusted by agreement.
('94', 419, 4, 10, 864463) His Majesty’s Government will negotiate agreements in regard to matters arising out of the transfer of power with representatives of those to whom they propose to transfer power.
('94', 419, 5, 11, 864642) His Majesty’s Government believe that British commercial and industrial interests in India can look forward to a fair for field their enterprise under the new conditions.
('94', 419, 5, 12, 864813) The commercial connection between India and the United Kingdom has been long and friendly and will continue to be to their mutual advantage.
('94', 419, 6, 13, 864954) His Majesty’s Government cannot conclude this statement without expressing, on behalf of the people of this country, their goodwill and good wishes towards the people of India as they go forward to this final stage in their achievement of self government.
('94', 419, 6, 14, 865210) It will be the wish of everyone in these islands that, notwithstanding constitutional changes, the association of the British and Indian peoples should not be brought to an end; and they will wish to continue to do all that is in their power to further the well being of India.
('94', 419, 7, 15, 865488) The Indian Annual Register, 1947, Vol. I, pp.
('94', 420, 0, 1, 865534) VOL. 94: 17 FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947. 421

('94', 420, 5, 12, 866159) But then I take consolation in the thought that that consideration cannot be absent from your mind and that if you are sure of yourself, no harm can come to them.
('94', 420, 5, 13, 866322) Then knowing you to be a great student of the Gita I have wondered if you are not doing violence to the principle of lokasangraha (conservation of social good), wisely propounded therein.
('94', 420, 5, 14, 866510) But this consideration, too, I am sure, must not be absent from your calculations, in this experiment of yours.

('94', 420, 5, 16, 866765) You have never exploited her.

('94', 420, 8, 19, 866851) LETTER FROM SIR HUGH DOW 2
('94', 420, 9, 20, 866878) GOVERNOR’S CAMP, BIHAR,
('94', 420, 10, 21, 866902) March 17, 1947
('94', 420, 11, 22, 866917) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('94', 420, 12, 23, 866934) Thank you for your letter of today’s date.
('94', 420, 12, 24, 866977) I have always held that no public man can hope to reform other people and make them better unless he searches his own heart and devotes his first attention to trying to become a better man himself.
('94', 420, 12, 25, 867175) I do not know why you should have been so surprised at this view being held by what you call a bureaucrat: it is probably not rarer among them than among other loosely labelled classes.
('94', 420, 13, 26, 867361) 1 Vide “Letter to J. B. Kripalani”, 24 2 1947. Only extracts are reproduced here.
('94', 420, 13, 27, 867443) 2 Vide “Letter to Sir Hugh Dow”, 17 3 1947
('94', 421, 0, 1, 867486) 422 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('94', 421, 1, 2, 867528) I do not wonder that my Ministers reacted strongly to your summary of our conversation.
('94', 421, 1, 3, 867616) May I put your points a little more fully:
('94', 421, 2, 4, 867659) (1) From the beginning of the riots I thought my Ministers should have at once declared their intention to compensate those who had suffered damage in them.
('94', 421, 2, 5, 867816) Had it been done immediately, I think a good deal of the organized hostility against the Ministry’s measures would not have arisen.
('94', 421, 2, 6, 867948) At it was, it was only after considerable delay that an announcement was made.
('94', 421, 3, 7, 868027) The Prime Minister is well aware of my views about this.
('94', 421, 3, 8, 868084) On my part, I quite realized the difficulties he felt about making a commitment of unknown financial liability.
('94', 421, 4, 9, 868196) (2) I think it is true that some officials drew from this the inference that the Ministry did not regard the matter as urgent.
('94', 421, 4, 10, 868323) When I visited Chapra in the middle of January, no money or materials had actually been distributed, although the riots had taken place at the end of October, and the debris was just as the rioters had left it.
('94', 421, 5, 11, 868534) I told the Prime Minister my impressions on my return, and I am glad to say that he took the necessary steps at once by impressing on district officers that rehabilitation was the most urgent work before them.
('94', 421, 5, 12, 868744) I believe the Prime Minister has always realized this, and I certainly did not intend to convey to you, that the Ministry themselves were in any way half hearted about it.
('94', 421, 5, 13, 868916) But for some months, in my opinion, this view was held by many subordinate officials, because of the original delay in getting off the mark.
('94', 421, 6, 14, 869057) (3) I have no recollection of having touched at all on the topic of punishment of the guilty.
('94', 421, 6, 15, 869151) Perhaps, as you have been seeing so many people in rapid succession, you have attributed to me views given by some of your visitors.
('94', 421, 7, 16, 869284) Actually, my views on this are rather the reverse of those suggested.
('94', 421, 7, 17, 869354) I do not think it is going to be possible to punish, judicially, any but a tiny fraction of the culprits, and that a lot of time of police and magistrates, that might be better spent, is likely to be entirely wasted in the attempt.
('94', 421, 7, 18, 869586) In my opinion, the only effective way in which this matter could have been effectively dealt with was by the imposition of collective fines.
('94', 421, 8, 19, 869727) (4) I do not think the Ministry has turned down League demands merely because they were League demands.
('94', 421, 8, 20, 869831) But I think the Hindu public of Bihar was, and perhaps is, averse from treating Muslim refugees more generously than they think Hindu refugees are treated in Bengal, and in
('94', 422, 0, 1, 870004) VOL. 94: 17 FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947. 423
('94', 422, 1, 2, 870051) the beginning there was a tendency to wait and see.
('94', 422, 2, 3, 870103) I think we have been unwise in taking a hostile attitude to “pockets”.
('94', 422, 2, 4, 870174) What we should have done was to have been prepared to consider such proposals on their merits, and to place on the Muslims themselves the responsibility for suggesting definite schemes and carrying them out if they were sanctioned.
('94', 422, 2, 5, 870406) I have discussed this with the Prime Minister who is aware of my views and I think not hostile to them.
('94', 422, 2, 6, 870510) When we have paid compensation to a sufferer, it should be left to him to decide where and how he will spend it, just as it would be if he had drawn his compensation from an insurance company.
('94', 422, 3, 7, 870703) As regards the question of minorities in general, differences between me and my Ministers have never, I think, gone to a stage when they were not resolved by friendly discussions.
('94', 422, 3, 8, 870883) In this particular matter of the recent disturbances, I have never had occasion to think of exercising any special powers in opposition to ministerial advice.
('94', 422, 3, 9, 871042) The question of restoring confidence between the two great communities is one of extraordinary difficulty, and I should not like you to get the impression that there has been any lack of co operation between me and the Ministers on this subject.
('94', 422, 4, 10, 871288) As regards the mica industry, I will send you a note as soon as I can prepare it.
('94', 422, 4, 11, 871370) But my personal concern in this is not about the condition of the working men in the industry, about which I know little, but about the way in which child labour is exploited.
('94', 422, 4, 12, 871546) Yours sincerely, HUGH DOW M. K. GANDHI, ESQ.

('94', 422, 6, 14, 871651) APPENDIX IV
('94', 422, 7, 15, 871663) N. K. BOSE’S LETTER TO KEDAR NATH AND OTHERS
('94', 422, 8, 16, 871708) PATNA March 16, 1947 MY DEAR .
('94', 422, 8, 17, 871739) Swami Anand asked me this morning if he could say to his friends that I disapproved of Gandhiji’s action.
('94', 422, 8, 18, 871845) It is with reference to this question that I should try to make my position clear.
('94', 422, 8, 19, 871928) Hence this letter.
('94', 422, 8, 20, 871947) From a serious study of Gandhiji’s writings I had formed the opinion, which was perhaps not unjustified, that he represented a hard, puritanic form of self discipline, something which we usually associate with mediaeval Christian ascetics of Jain recluses.
('94', 423, 0, 1, 872204) 424 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('94', 423, 1, 2, 872246) So, when I first learnt in detail about Gandhiji’s prayog or experiment, I felt genuinely surprised.
('94', 423, 1, 3, 872347) I was informed that he sometimes asked women to share his bed and even the cover which he used, and then tried to ascertain if even the least trace of sensual feeling had been evoked in himself or his companion.
('94', 423, 2, 4, 872559) But when I learnt about this technique of self examination employed by Gandhiji, I felt that I had discovered the reason why some regarded Gandhiji as their private possession; this feeling often leading them to a kind of emotional unbalance.
('94', 423, 2, 5, 872802) The behaviour of A, B or C, for instance, is no proof of healthy psychological relationship.
('94', 423, 2, 6, 872895) Whatever may be the value of the prayog in Gandhiji’s own case it does leave a mark of injury on the personality of others who are not of the same moral stature as he himself is, and for whom sharing in Gandhiji’s experiment is no spiritual necessity.
('94', 423, 3, 7, 873147) This has been the reason why I have sometimes spoken or written strongly to Gandhiji on the subject of repression and its effects upon those who come under his influence either in private or in public life.
('94', 423, 3, 8, 873354) But, you will see, this charge is quite different from the one to which you or your friends subscribe.
('94', 423, 3, 9, 873457) This is also the reason why I have drawn a distinction in the case of Manu, whose relation to Gandhiji is of a completely different order.
('94', 423, 4, 10, 873596) I hope my position is quite clear.
('94', 423, 4, 11, 873631) But if it is not, please do not hesitate to write.
('94', 423, 5, 12, 873682) Yours sincerely, NIRMAL KUMAR BOSE
('94', 423, 6, 13, 873717) Post script
('94', 423, 7, 14, 873729) Even with regard to the ‘experiment’, I would stand by Gandhiji, if—
('94', 423, 8, 15, 873798) 1. the other party were a willing agent, voluntarily entering into the experiment with a knowledge of the possible consequences upon her own personality;
('94', 423, 9, 16, 873952) 2. and the public knew about the experiment and expressed their mind over it.
('94', 423, 10, 17, 874030) The second is otherwise unnecessary, but has only been called for because Gandhiji himself invited public opinion on this subject twice in his prayer speeches in Noakhali.
('94', 423, 10, 18, 874202) He expected the public to express an opinion even when they did not know the entire details of the situation.
('94', 423, 10, 19, 874312) But, even if after knowing everything, the public thought that Gandhiji was in the wrong, while he considered himself to be right, I would stand by him.
('94', 423, 11, 20, 874465) My Days with Gandhi, pp.

('94', 424, 2, 3, 874548) LETTER FROM N. K. BOSE1
('94', 424, 3, 4, 874572) MASAURHI,
('94', 424, 4, 5, 874582) March 18, 1947
('94', 424, 5, 6, 874597) BAPUJI,
('94', 424, 6, 7, 874605) After receiving your letter written yesterday in the train, I had about an hour’s talk with you in which I tried to refute the charge against me that I had formed judgement hastily without giving A or others any chance of presenting their case fully.
('94', 424, 7, 8, 874856) Personally, I have practised the Freudian technique of dream analysis on myself and have derived immense benefit, as it has helped to bring to the surface submerged desires which had been causing trouble, and thus helped me to deal with them satisfactorily.
('94', 424, 8, 9, 875114) Bapuji, you originally called me to service under you while you were in Bengal.
('94', 424, 8, 10, 875194) The University gladly granted me indefinite leave so long as you needed my services.
('94', 424, 8, 11, 875279) But the interest of my students has also been suffering.
('94', 424, 8, 12, 875336) When I have to choose between the amount of service I can render to you here in Bihar and for science in the University, I would place the latter first.
('94', 424, 8, 13, 875489) But if it had been in Bengal, I would have sacrificed the latter interest, because I would then have known that so far as translating your speeches into Bengali was concerned, I would have been more useful than most of your other assistants.
('94', 424, 8, 14, 875731) But now that you are in Bihar, men like Pyarelalji or others would be in their elements with their mastery over Hindustani and their undoubtedly great ability for secretarial work.
('94', 424, 8, 15, 875912) So I would love to make room for anyone whom you may choose.
('94', 424, 9, 16, 875973) When once more you are in Bengal and feel the need of my services, the University will gladly grant me leave for service under you without hesitation.
('94', 424, 10, 17, 876124) Hence my plan is to leave for Calcutta even tonight if you do not object.
('94', 424, 11, 18, 876198) Yours affectionately, N. K. B.
('94', 424, 12, 19, 876229) My Days with Gandhi, pp.
('94', 424, 13, 20, 876254) 1 Vide “Letter to Nirmal Kumar Bose”, 18 3 1947. Only extracts are reproduced here.
('94', 425, 0, 1, 876338) 426 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('94', 425, 1, 2, 876380) APPENDIX VI
('94', 425, 2, 3, 876392) CONGRESS WORKING COMMITTEE’S RESOLUTION ON THE PUNJAB1
('94', 425, 3, 4, 876447) During the past seven months India has witnessed many horrors and tragedies which have been enacted in the attempt to gain political ends by brutal violence, murder and coercion.
('94', 425, 3, 5, 876626) These attempts have failed, as all such attempts must fail, and have only led to greater violence and carnage.
('94', 425, 4, 6, 876737) The Punjab, which had thus far escaped this contagion, became six weeks ago the scene of an agitation, supported by some people in high authority, to coerce and break a popular ministry which could not be attacked by constitutional methods.
('94', 425, 4, 7, 876978) A measure of success attended this, and an attempt was made to form a ministry dominated by the group that had led the agitation.
('94', 425, 4, 8, 877108) This was bitterly resented and has resulted in increased and wide spread violence.
('94', 425, 4, 9, 877191) There has been an orgy of murder and arson and Amritsar and Multan have been scenes of horror and devastation.
('94', 425, 5, 10, 877302) These tragic events have demonstrated that there can be no settlement of the problem in the Punjab by violence and coercion, and that no arrangement based on coercion can last.
('94', 425, 5, 11, 877479) Therefore, it is necessary to find a way out which involves the least amount of compulsion.
('94', 425, 5, 12, 877571) This would necessitate a division of the Punjab into two provinces, so that the predominantly Muslim part may be separated from the predominantly non Muslim part.
('94', 425, 6, 13, 877734) The Working Committee commend this solution, which should work to the advantage of all the communities concerned, and lessen friction and fear and suspicion of each other.
('94', 425, 6, 14, 877906) The Committee earnestly appeal to the people of the Punjab to put an end to the killing and brutality that are going on, and to face the tragic situation, determined to find a solution which does not involve compulsion of any major group and which will effectively remove the causes of friction.
('94', 425, 7, 15, 878202) The Indian Annual Register, 1947, Vol. I, pp.
('94', 425, 8, 16, 878248) 1 Vide “Letter to Jawaharlal Nehru”, 20 3 1947
('94', 426, 0, 1, 878295) VOL. 94: 17 FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947. 427
('94', 426, 1, 2, 878342) APPENDIX VII
('94', 426, 2, 3, 878355) INTERVIEW WITH LORD MOUNTBATTEN 1
('94', 426, 3, 4, 878389) Top Secret April 1, 1947
('94', 426, 4, 5, 878414) Mr. Gandhi .
('94', 426, 4, 6, 878427) gave me his views on the origin of Hindu Muslim animosity, and though he did not hold the British responsible for its origin, he said their policy of “Divide and Rule” had kept the tension very much alive, and that I should now reap what my predecessors had deliberately sown.
('94', 426, 5, 7, 878704) He urged me whatever happened to have the courage to see the truth and act by it, even though the correct solution might mean grievous loss of life on our departure on an unprecedented scale.
('94', 426, 6, 8, 878896) Finally, he gave me the first brief summary of the solution which he wishes me to adopt:
('94', 426, 7, 9, 878985) Mr. Jinnah should forthwith be invited to form the Central Interim Government with members of the Muslim League.
('94', 426, 7, 10, 879098) This Government to operate under the Viceroy in the way the present Interim Government is operating.
('94', 426, 8, 11, 879199) Any difficulty experienced through Congress having a majority in the Assembly to be overcome by their able advocacy of the measures they wished to introduce.
('94', 426, 9, 12, 879357) I need not say that this solution coming at this time staggered me.
('94', 426, 9, 13, 879425) I asked “What would Mr. Jinnah say to such a proposal?” The reply was, “If you tell him I am the author he will reply ‘Wily Gandhi’.” I then remarked, “And I presume Mr. Jinnah will be right?” To which he replied with great fervour, “No, I am entirely sincere in my suggestion.”
('94', 426, 10, 14, 879704) At this moment the A. D. C. reported that the Tibetan Mission had arrived, and our conversation therefore had to be terminated until the following day.
('94', 426, 11, 15, 879856) I did however obtain Mr. Gandhi’s permission to discuss the matter with Pandit Nehru and Maulana Azad, in strict confidence, the next time they came to see me.
('94', 426, 12, 16, 880016) ADDENDUM: During the course of the discussion Mr. Gandhi gave it as his consi dered opinion as a student of history and of world politics that never before, in any case of history he had read about in recent or past times, had so difficult or responsible a task been imposed on any one man as that which now faced me.
('94', 426, 12, 17, 880334) I thanked him sincerely for realising the position in which I was placed.

('94', 427, 1, 2, 880666) APPENDIX VIII
('94', 427, 2, 3, 880680) INTERVIEW WITH LORD MOUNTBATTEN 1
('94', 427, 3, 4, 880714) Top Secret April 2, 1947
('94', 427, 4, 5, 880739) The meeting lasted from 2.30 p.
('94', 427, 4, 6, 880771) to 4.30 p.
('94', 427, 5, 7, 880782) To begin with we discussed the question of holding enquiries in Bihar and Bengal.
('94', 427, 5, 8, 880864) I told him the views of the Governor of Bihar, of Sardar Patel and of myself, that enquiries were a waste of time and money, as well as a potential source of further communal strife.
('94', 427, 5, 9, 881047) He flatly disagreed, and said that it was, in his opinion, essential that the Congress Government in Bihar should in all events show good faith by holding an enquiry which would reveal the appalling excesses committed by the Hindus in Bihar.
('94', 427, 5, 10, 881289) We both agreed, however, that this was really a matter for the Provincial Government to settle, and I suggested that he should discuss the matter in the meanwhile with the Home Member, Sardar Patel.
('94', 427, 5, 11, 881488) After this Mr. Gandhi came down firmly for his great plan, which he had revealed to me originally on Tuesday.
('94', 427, 5, 12, 881598) I will repeat it here in greater detail.
('94', 427, 5, 13, 881639) He wants me to invite Mr. Jinnah to form a new Central Government for India, which will be the Government to which I am to turn over power.
('94', 427, 5, 14, 881779) He suggests I should leave it to Mr. Jinnah to select the Ministers, if necessary entirely from the Muslim League, but if he feels so inclined he can of course then make it a coalition Government by including Nehru and other Congress Ministers as well as representatives of Minorities.
('94', 427, 5, 15, 882065) In fact he suggests that Jinnah would be well advised to try and get the highest class team together and one likely to enjoy the greatest confidence of the Assembly.
('94', 427, 5, 16, 882231) He assured me that the Muslim League had many men of greater calibre than, for example, Nishtar and Ghazanafar Ali Khan.
('94', 427, 5, 17, 882352) The essence of the scheme was that it should be put through quickly in order that I might have as many months as possible as Viceroy and Pre sident of the Cabinet, and, by retaining the right of veto, continue to exercise complete control in the interests of fair play.
('94', 427, 5, 18, 882622) The fact that I should be there to see fair play for the first few months would ensure Mr. Jinnah’s Govern ment not doing anything foolish which would prejudice its reputation in the Assembly or in the country; and he felt that I could guide them along in a manner which would ensure their continuing along the straight and narrow path after I left in
('94', 427, 6, 19, 882974) 1 As recorded by Lord Mountbatten.
('94', 427, 6, 20, 883009) Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 3 4 1947
('94', 428, 0, 1, 883051) VOL. 94: 17 FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947. 429
('94', 428, 1, 2, 883098) June 1948.
('94', 428, 2, 3, 883109) If Mr. Jinnah refused this offer, then, Mr. Gandhi pointed out, the offer would have to be made to the only other great party in India—Congress.
('94', 428, 2, 4, 883254) He hoped that Congress would invite Ministers from all shades of opinion including the Muslim League to participate in a Coalition Government.
('94', 428, 3, 5, 883397) I twitted him that he really desired me to form a Central Government run by Congress, to whom I would turn over power, and that the preliminary offer to Jinnah was merely a manoeuvre.
('94', 428, 4, 6, 883581) He assured me with burning sincerity that this was so far from being the case that he then and there volunteered to place his whole services at my disposal in trying to get the Jinnah Government through, first by exercising his influence with the Congress to accept it, and secondly by touring the length and breadth of the country getting all the peoples of India to accept the decision.
('94', 428, 4, 7, 883970) He convinced me of his sincerity, and I told him so.
('94', 428, 5, 8, 884023) He agreed that I should discuss this plan with Maulana Azad and Nehru.
('94', 428, 6, 9, 884094) Finally, he said that he proposed also to discuss it with those two and with Mr. Kripalani.
('94', 428, 6, 10, 884186) He agreed as to the supreme importance of complete secrecy, particularly as far as the Press were concerned.
('94', 428, 7, 11, 884295) He asked if he might quote me as being in favour of this plan, to which I replied that the most he could say was that I was very interested by it, but that I would require an assurance from some of the other leaders that they considered it capable of being implemented before I would commit myself to its support.
('94', 428, 8, 12, 884609) We discussed alternatives, and I told him I favoured the Cabinet Mission plan most of all, and he replied that he too would be in favour of it if it could be revised.
('94', 428, 9, 13, 884776) Finally I discussed the possibility of turning over power to the areas of India in accordance with the wishes of the majority of the residents in those areas.
('94', 428, 9, 14, 884935) Broadly speaking this would make a Hindu India with a Congress Government in Delhi, a truncated Pakistan, and the large states like Mysore, Travancore, Hyderabad, Kashmir, and groups of States, each having separate power turned over to them, owing allegiance to a Central authority for Defence, External Affairs, Communications, and possibly food.
('94', 428, 10, 15, 885283) He agreed that whatever the decision, it should be taken soon and implemented as early as possible, and that meanwhile it would be an excellent thing if I remained in charge of the Central Government with the power of veto until June 1948.

('94', 429, 2, 3, 885710) INTERVIEW WITH LORD MOUNTBATTEN 1
('94', 429, 3, 4, 885744) Top Secret April 3, 1947 The meeting lasted from 2.30 p.
('94', 429, 3, 5, 885801) to 4.30 p.
('94', 429, 3, 6, 885812) We continued our talks on Mr. Gandhi’s great scheme for the All India Jinnah Government.
('94', 429, 3, 7, 885901) He informed me that those of the leaders of the Congress he had spoken to had all agreed that it was feasible and would support him, but that he had not yet had time to talk to Pandit Nehru, which he intended to do that evening.
('94', 429, 3, 8, 886130) He was more than ever intense about his scheme as being the best solution.
('94', 429, 3, 9, 886205) But he agreed that if I was unable to decide on that solution, he would support me in any other solution which I could put before him as being in the best interests of the Indian people.
('94', 429, 3, 10, 886392) He agreed that if the Muslim League were completely intransigent, partition might have to come, though he was most anxious to retain as strong a Centre as possible in this case.
('94', 429, 3, 11, 886570) He agreed that an early decision was vital to end communal conflict and to give time to implement the decision.
('94', 429, 3, 12, 886682) And finally he reiterated his desire that whatever happened I should retain firm charge at the Centre till June 1948 at the very earliest, in order to act as an umpire and exercise a guiding hand during the early stages of self government.
('94', 429, 3, 13, 886922) He said that his great friend Badshah Khan was staying with him.
('94', 429, 3, 14, 886987) I had never heard the name and asked him to elucidate.
('94', 429, 3, 15, 887042) He referred to him as the Frontier Gandhi, and I then recognized him to be the same person as I knew under the name of abdul Ghaffar Khan, brother of Dr. Khan Sahib the Premier of the Congress Muslim Government in the N. W. F. P. Mr. Gandhi said that Abdul Ghaffar Khan had informed him that the Governor, Sir Olaf Caroe, had demanded the resignation of his brother, Dr. Khan Sahib and had shown himself to be very partial towards the Muslim League and to influence the British officials in that Province accordingly.
('94', 429, 3, 16, 887560) In view of the fact that Lord Ismay had just returned from a visit to the N. W. F. P. I sent for him, and Mr. Gandhi repeated his allegation.
('94', 429, 3, 17, 887702) Lord Ismay explained the position as he saw it, and pointed out that there must have been misunderstanding.
('94', 429, 3, 18, 887810) I invited Mr. Gandhi to bring Abdul Ghaffar Khan at 2.30 the following day to meet Lord Ismay and myself.

('94', 430, 2, 3, 888184) INTERVIEW WITH LORD MOUNTBATTEN 1
('94', 430, 3, 4, 888218) Top Secret April 4, 1947
('94', 430, 4, 5, 888243) The meeting lasted from 2.30 p.
('94', 430, 4, 6, 888275) to 4.30 p.
('94', 430, 5, 7, 888286) Mr. Gandhi brought with him as promised Abdul Ghaffar Khan.
('94', 430, 5, 8, 888346) Lord Ismay attended the meeting.
('94', 430, 6, 9, 888379) Abdul Ghaffar Khan gave a very forthright denunciation of the Governor of the N. W. F. P. and all his officials, particularly the political officers dealing with the tribes.
('94', 430, 7, 10, 888553) I asked Mr. Gandhi for his views.
('94', 430, 7, 11, 888587) He said he feared that there were many British members of the I. C. S., particularly among the highly placed ones, who cold not bear to see the British leave India, and who had clung all along to the theory that if they could only support the Muslim League actively, to the point at which it could be held that the British could not leave India to civil war, then the British would be compelled to stay.
('94', 430, 8, 12, 888991) He pointed out that the views held by Mr. Winston Churchill were so well known that had he been in power or had there been any chance of his returning to power, the line taken by all those I. C. S. officials would have achieved its object.
('94', 430, 9, 13, 889231) I asked Mr. Gandhi for some more examples of biassed officials.
('94', 430, 9, 14, 889295) He said that although he did not know Sir Francis Mudie personally, all his friends in Sind told him that he was extremely pro Muslim League and much too friendly with his Government.
('94', 430, 10, 15, 889479) I pointed out that he had previously agreed with Abdul Ghaffar Khan that Sir Olaf Caroe was insufficiently friendly with his Congress Government in the N. W. F. P., and now he accused Sir Francis Mudie of being too friendly with the Muslim League Government in Sind.
('94', 430, 11, 16, 889746) Mr. Gandhi replied that he did not wish Governors to be biassed one way or the other; their friendliness with their Government should be the impartial friendliness which a constitutional monarch should bestow upon any government which came to power.
('94', 430, 12, 17, 889996) He advised me most strongly to get rid of any officials who could not be brought to see that they must remain impartial and helpful during the final stages.
('94', 430, 12, 18, 890153) After this Mr. Gandhi spoke about the Princes.
('94', 430, 12, 19, 890200) He said that the Princes were really the creation of the British; that many of them had
('94', 430, 13, 20, 890288) 1 As recorded by Lord Mountbatten.
('94', 430, 13, 21, 890323) Vide “Outline of Draft Agreement”, 4 4 1947
('94', 431, 0, 1, 890367) 432 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('94', 431, 1, 2, 890409) been gradually created up from small chieftains to the position they now held, because the British realized that they would become strong allies of the British under the system of paramountcy
('94', 431, 2, 3, 890601) In fact he maintained that the British had, from the imperialistic point of view, acted very correctly in backing the Princes and the Muslim League, since between these two, had we played our cards really well, we could have claimed it was impossible for us even to leave India.
('94', 431, 2, 4, 890880) He appreciated that my task was rendered all the more difficult by the line taken by my predecessors.
('94', 431, 3, 5, 890982) He considered it wicked of Sir Stafford Cripps not to have recommended the turning over of paramountcy to the Central Government representing the sovereignty of the Indian nation.
('94', 431, 4, 6, 891162) I replied that although I could see the argument for turning over paramountcy to a really strong Central Government representing the whole of the Indian nation, I had not yet seen any workable scheme for producing a really strong Central Government, and in fact the chances of there being anybody to whom paramountcy could be turned over seemed to me to be remote.
('94', 431, 5, 7, 891527) Only one scheme would achieve this, and that was the famous Gandhi scheme.
('94', 431, 5, 8, 891602) I therefore asked him to explain this once more for Lord Ismay’s benefit.
('94', 431, 5, 9, 891676) On conclusion I asked Abdul Ghaffar Khan if he really thought that Congress would accept this scheme, and that it would be workable.
('94', 431, 5, 10, 891809) To this he gave a very definitely affirmative reply.
('94', 431, 6, 11, 891862) I then invited Lord Ismay to take Mr. Gandhi to his room and put his scheme in writing.

('94', 433, 5, 10, 895609) THE VICEROY’S HOUSE, NEW DELHI, April 7, 1947
('94', 433, 6, 11, 895655) DEAR MR. GANDHI, Many thanks for your letter of today.
('94', 433, 6, 12, 895710) I find it difficult to advise you.
('94', 433, 6, 13, 895745) Though the root causes of the disturbances in the Punjab still exist there has been a considerable measure of success in dealing with immediate disturbances, and I doubt whether you ought to exhaust yourself by undertaking any tour in the Punjab at this time of the year.
('94', 433, 6, 14, 896017) I quite agree that those outbreaks of violence are not a mere detail.

('94', 433, 6, 16, 896213) It is the effort to find a solution which will occupy all my efforts in the near future, and I know I can rely on help from you wherever you may be.

('94', 434, 1, 2, 896672) APPENDIX XIV
('94', 434, 2, 3, 896685) INTERVIEW WITH LORD MOUNTBATTEN 1
('94', 434, 3, 4, 896719) Top Secret April 12, 1947
('94', 434, 4, 5, 896745) The meeting lasted from 11.45 a.
('94', 434, 4, 6, 896778) to 1.45 p.
('94', 434, 5, 7, 896789) I thanked him for the letter he had sent me the previous day saying that he had been unable to get his great plan for a Jinnah government through responsible members of Congress, and had therefore had to withdraw it.
('94', 434, 5, 8, 897006) He regretted his failure very much, but said he thought I could still go ahead on the plan myself if I ardently believed in it.
('94', 434, 6, 9, 897134) I told him that however much I believed in it I couldn’t possibly go ahead with success in a matter in which he had already failed himself with the Congress.
('94', 434, 7, 10, 897292) I then told him I wanted to report to him in strict confidence all my conversations with Mr. Jinnah, to put him in the picture.
('94', 434, 8, 11, 897420) I then said that although my mind was still open I was now particularly studying two alternative solutions:
('94', 434, 9, 12, 897528) (a) the Cabinet Mission plan; (b) a truncated Pakistan.
('94', 434, 9, 13, 897584) I asked him how much he personally favoured a united India, and of course he said he was extremely anxious for it.
('94', 434, 9, 14, 897699) I asked him how far he thought Congress would go towards accepting the Cabinet Mission plan and warned him that Mr. Jinnah was bitterly opposed to the Cabinet Mission plan and therefore Congress would have to go at least as far as Mr. Jinnah wanted before he would even consider it.
('94', 434, 10, 15, 897982) Mr. Gandhi said that the whole bone of contention was the interpretation of the meaning of the Cabinet Mission plan, and he suggested that I should call in the High Court to interpret it.
('94', 434, 10, 16, 898170) I told him that the differences of opinion had already been resolved by the statement of the Cabinet of the 6th December; but he held that the people who drafted the statement were not the people who had to interpret it, and gave as an analogy Acts of Parliament.
('94', 434, 10, 17, 898434) He said that if a difference of opinion arose as to the meaning of a particular clause in law, it was the judge who settled the meaning and who interpreted the law and not the people who framed the law.
('94', 434, 10, 18, 898637) He seemed convinced that the Congress would accept any interpretation the High Court gave.
('94', 434, 11, 19, 898728) I told him I did not see how we could possibly have a different inter pretation put on the meaning of the Cabinet Mission plan to that which the Cabinet Mission themselves had announced on December the 6th after

('94', 435, 0, 1, 899052) 436 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('94', 435, 1, 2, 899094) taking legal advice.
('94', 435, 1, 3, 899115) I then discussed the joint statement calling for a truce and a denunciation of the use of force to obtain political ends.
('94', 435, 1, 4, 899237) He said he would gladly sign the statement shown to him or any similar statement if Mr. Jinnah and I wished him to do so; though he must point out that the statement, to have any value, should be signed by Mr. Kripalani on behalf of the Congress as a whole.
('94', 435, 1, 5, 899495) He said he had told Pandit Nehru that if indeed I could get Mr. Jinnah to sign and abide by this statement, I should have taken the greatest step politically in the recent history of India, and one which he hoped he had been instrumental in putting into my head.
('94', 435, 1, 6, 899758) Although I have absolutely no recollection of Mr. Gandhi making any such suggestion, I felt it would be politic not to point this out.
('94', 435, 1, 7, 899893) For although I believed it to have been my own idea, I am only too delighted that he should take the credit.
('94', 435, 1, 8, 900002) In the meanwhile Lord Ismay came down at my request with the Cabinet Mission plan and the Statement of December the 6th.
('94', 435, 1, 9, 900123) Mr. Gandhi appeared never to have read this statement although he knew of its existence.
('94', 435, 1, 10, 900212) He thought he was at Noakhali at the time and did not have time to read it.
('94', 435, 1, 11, 900288) After reading it very carefully he came back to his original point of view that the Cabinet Mission statement should be submitted to the High Court for interpretation, and he felt sure the Congress would abide by their decision.
('94', 435, 1, 12, 900517) Lord Ismay pointed out that it was less a matter of finding out what the actual legal interpretation was than of ascertaining what common interpretation would be acceptable both to the Muslim League and the Congress; and to this Mr. Gandhi unreservedly agreed.
('94', 435, 1, 13, 900778) Meanwhile he called upon me to renounce the use of the British Army, and said that he included the British officers of the Indian Army in that term; in other words any of the armed forces under my orders.
('94', 435, 1, 14, 900983) I pointed out that except for the Punjab, which is under a Section 93 Government, in all other provinces it was the local Government that called out the troops, and that if he wanted that practice to stop why didn’t he make a start by talking to the Congress Government in Bihar where he was off to that evening.
('94', 435, 1, 15, 901296) He said sadly he had already spoken to them, and that if they had had a strong conviction of non violence they would offer themselves as sacrifices rather than allow these massacres to continue of trying to stop them by the use of troops I did not altogether follow his argument here, and may have misquoted him.
('94', 435, 1, 16, 901609) But since it appeared to be purely academic, and a matter he was going to put before the local Congress Government in Bihar, I did not pursue it.
('94', 435, 1, 17, 901755) He then said that he advised me to go on strengthening the Interim Government, and making them function correctly for the next 14 months; after which he considered I should hand over power to the Interim Government.
('94', 436, 0, 1, 901971) VOL. 94: 17 FEBRUARY, 1947 29 APRIL, 1947. 437
('94', 436, 1, 2, 902018) staggered Lord Ismay and myself, and we both pointed out that that meant handing over power to one party, namely Congress, to the grave disadvantage of the other party, the Muslim League, which would not fail to produce strife, possibly leading to civil war.
('94', 436, 1, 3, 902277) Mr. Gandhi, with a wily smile, pointed out that if Mr. Jinnah indeed signed the paper we were sending round to him he could not again use force for political purposes.
('94', 436, 1, 4, 902445) I must say I was speechless to find that he proposed, if Mr. Jinnah indeed meant to sign and stick to the statement, to take advantage of this to impose a Congress Government over the Muslims.
('94', 436, 1, 5, 902638) Here again I find it hard to believe that I correctly understood Mr. Gandhi.
('94', 436, 1, 6, 902715) Finally, after substituting the word “communities” instead of “peoples” and having the declaration of truce retyped, Mr. Gandhi appended his signature in all three scripts: English, Urdu and Gujarati; and Lord Ismay took the paper for Sir Eric Mieville to take round to Mr. Jinnah.
